questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the services provided by this organisation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Water supply and sanitation:

  • Water supply and sanitation are services provided by the United States Agency for International Development not UNICEF.

Incorrect Options:

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with difficulty swallowing and intermittent chest pain. A barium swallow study shows abnormal esophageal motility. Which of the following mechanisms is most likely disrupted in this patient?

choices.text: Coordinated contraction of the circular and longitudinal muscle layers
Relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter
Neural coordination by the enteric nervous system
Secretion of digestive enzymes by the esophageal glands

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Neural coordination by the enteric nervous system:

  • The patient's symptoms and the findings of abnormal esophageal motility on the barium swallow study suggest a disruption in the neural coordination of peristalsis, which is primarily managed by the enteric nervous system. This disruption can lead to the ineffective movement of food through the esophagus, resulting in the clinical presentation observed.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Coordinated contraction of the circular and longitudinal muscle layers: Peristalsis involves these muscle layers' coordinated contraction and relaxation to propel food through the digestive tract. Disruption in this coordination can lead to motility disorders, causing symptoms like difficulty swallowing and chest pain.

Option B - Relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter: Relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter is crucial for allowing food to enter the stomach from the esophagus. If the lower esophageal sphincter does not relax properly, it can cause motility issues, leading to the retention of food in the esophagus and associated symptoms.

Option D - Secretion of digestive enzymes by the esophageal glands: Although the esophagus does secrete mucus to aid in lubrication, it does not secrete digestive enzymes. Therefore, this option is not directly related to peristalsis or esophageal motility.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the Nazer prognostic index used in evaluating patients with the findings shown below on naked eye examination?
questions.solution:
Option D - Urine copper:

  • A greenish-brownish ring, known as a KF ring, is indicative of Wilson's disease.
  • The Nazer Index is utilized for assessing the severity and prognosis of Wilson's disease, particularly in determining candidacy for orthotopic liver transplantation due to copper toxicity.
  • The 24-hour urine copper test is commonly employed as a screening tool for Wilson's disease but is not included in the components of the Nazer prognostic index.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Serum bilirubin: Elevated levels can indicate liver dysfunction, which is relevant to the assessment of liver health in Wilson's disease.

Option B - Serum aspartate aminotransferase: This enzyme is released when there is liver damage, making it pertinent to liver function evaluation in Wilson's disease.

Option C - Prothrombin time: A measure of blood clotting ability, which can be affected by liver dysfunction, hence important in Wilson's disease assessment.

questions.text: A primigravida is seen at 26 weeks, and an OGTT is advised. Her values are deranged, and she is started on a diabetic diet. She has no past or family history of diabetes. Which of the following is the best explanation for such a presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option A: Increase in human placental lactogen

  • HPL is secreted by syncytiotrophoblast of the placenta and is detectable in maternal serum as early as the third week after fertilization. It is demonstrable in cytotrophoblast before 6 weeks.
  • This, however, increases exponentially around 24 weeks and is responsible for the insulinase action and the predisposition to GDM (Gestational Diabetes Mellitus) around that time. Hence, the screening protocol of OGTT is recommended between 24-28 weeks of gestation.
  • The composition of human placental lactogen (HPL) resembles growth hormone, causing changes in insulin receptors and resulting in insulin resistance. It stimulates maternal lipolysis and also plays a role in angiogenesis, contributing to fetal vascular development.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Activation of diabetogenic genes

  • While genetics can play a role in the development of diabetes, gestational diabetes is primarily influenced by physiological changes during pregnancy rather than genetic predisposition.

Option C: Fetal insulinase

  • Fetal insulinase is not a recognized factor in the development of gestational diabetes. Insulin resistance in the mother due to hormonal changes is the primary mechanism.

Option D: Downregulation of glucagon

  • Downregulation of glucagon is not a common mechanism in the development of gestational diabetes. Insulin resistance and hormonal changes are more significant contributors.

questions.text: A 3-month-old baby boy is brought to the pediatrician due to a noticeable swelling on the left side of his neck. On examination, a soft, compressible mass is palpated in the posterior triangle of the neck. Which syndrome is commonly associated with this presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Turner syndrome:

  • Cystic hygroma is frequently associated with Turner syndrome, a genetic condition in females caused by a complete or partial absence of one X chromosome.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, C, and D are not associated with cystic hygroma.

questions.text: During the caloric test, if the patient experiences nystagmus when warm water is irrigated into the right ear, what would be the expected direction of the nystagmus?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B- Nystagmus towards the right:

  • When warm water is irrigated into the right ear, it causes an increase in temperature resulting in nystagmus towards the right (same side of irrigation) as a response to the temperature gradient.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- Nystagmus towards the left: The direction of nystagmus is same to the side of irrigation, not the oppositee side.

Option C- Random direction of nystagmus: The direction of nystagmus is same as the side of irrigation, not random.

Option D- Absence of nystagmus: Nystagmus is expected in response to the temperature changes during the caloric test in normal individuals. The absence of nystagmus is seen if labyrinth is not functional, and is a dead labyrinth.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with complaints of bloody diarrhea up to 15 times per day, anemia, and puffy eyes. A colonoscopy reveals proctitis without granulomas on biopsy. Which condition is most likely to be responsible for this clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Ulcerative colitis (UC): 

  • The patient's symptoms of bloody diarrhea, anemia, and puffy eyes, along with colonoscopic findings of proctitis without granulomas, are highly indicative of ulcerative colitis (UC).
  • UC is a type of inflammatory bowel disease characterized by chronic inflammation and ulceration of the colon and rectum. The hallmark feature of UC is bloody diarrhea, which can occur frequently throughout the day.
  • Anemia is common due to chronic blood loss, and protein-losing enteropathy can lead to hypoalbuminemia, manifesting as puffy eyes.
  • The most common site of involvement in UC is the rectum, and colonoscopy with biopsy is the preferred diagnostic method.

Incorrect Options:
Option A - Crohn's disease:

  • While Crohn's disease is another form of inflammatory bowel disease, it typically presents with skip lesions, transmural inflammation, and granulomas on biopsy, which are not characteristic findings of ulcerative colitis.

Option B - Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS):

  • Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) can present with symptoms of diarrhea, but it does not typically cause bloody diarrhea, anemia, or puffy eyes. Additionally, colonoscopic findings in IBS are typically normal.

Option D - Diverticulitis:

  • Diverticulitis is characterized by inflammation of the diverticula, typically in the colon, and is not associated with the findings of proctitis seen in ulcerative colitis.
  • Additionally, diverticulitis does not typically cause bloody diarrhea to the extent seen in ulcerative colitis.

questions.text: In a 58-year-old chronic smoker with a persistent cough, unintentional weight loss, muscle weakness improving with activity, and a central lung mass positive for chromogranin on biopsy, which statement regarding the underlying condition is false?

choices.text: The tumor shows positive staining for Neuron-specific enolase and Synaptophysin.
The tumor displays an amplification of L Myc
The tumor marker p40 is considered to be confirmatory

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - The tumor marker p40 is considered to be confirmatory:

  • The patient is probably suffering from squamous cell and small cell carcinoma of the lung.
  • Smoking history is a significant risk factor for small cell carcinoma of the lung.
  • Clinical features: persistent cough, unintentional loss of weight, paraneoplastic syndrome: Lambert-Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome
    • Lambert-Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome:
    • Small cell lung carcinoma (SCLC) cells often express voltage-gated calcium channels (VGCCs) on their surface. The expression of VGCC by tumor cells triggers the immune system to produce autoantibodies directed against these channels. The autoantibodies produced against VGCCs in the tumor tissue can cross-react with presynaptic VGCC antigens at the neuromuscular junction, leading to impaired neurotransmitter release and muscle weakness characteristic of Lambert-Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome (LEMS).
  • Pathogenesis: SCLC carcinogenesis can arise from pathways disrupting DNA repair mechanisms, with prevalent mutations including loss of the RB1 tumor suppressor gene and TP53 mutations reducing cancer cell apoptosis. Additionally, nearly all SCLC tumors exhibit a deletion in chromosome 3p's short arm, encompassing the tumor suppressor gene FHIT.
  • Biopsy of the lung mass revealing poorly differentiated nests of cells that stain positive for chromogranin is characteristic of small cell lung cancer (SCLC).
  • Small cell lung cancer being a neuroendocrine tumor, shows a Zellballen pattern (nesting) of cells that stain positive for chromogranin, Synaptophysin, and Neuron-specific enolase (NSE).

( Zellballen pattern (nesting) of cells).

  • On arriving at a diagnosis of Small cell lung carcinoma,
    • Option A: The tumor showing positive staining for Neuron-specific enolase and Synaptophysin is true. These markers are commonly used in the diagnosis of neuroendocrine tumors, including SCLC.
    • Option B: The tumor displaying an amplification of L Myc is also true. L-Myc amplification is a common genetic alteration seen in SCLC.
    • Option C: The tumor marker p40 is not considered to be confirmatory for SCLC. While p40 staining is useful in distinguishing squamous cell carcinoma from other lung cancers.

Incorrect Options:

All options have been explained under the correct option.

questions.text: What condition is related to a 3-year-old with diarrhea, runny nose, fever, erythematous rash on the face, and upper limb pain, whose mother had a history of blood transfusion during pregnancy?

choices.text: Affects erythroid progenitors but individuals who totally lack Blood Group P antigen are resistant to infection.

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Affects erythroid progenitors but individuals who totally lack Blood Group P antigen are resistant to infection:

  • People who do not have P antigen, which is the cellular receptor for parvovirus B19, are naturally resistant to infection with this pathogen.
  • Parvoviruses are the smallest viruses. 
  • They belong to the family Parvoviridae.
  • Shows tropism for erythroid progenitor cells. → aplastic crises in Sickle cell anaemic patients
  • Tropism for RBCs: It infects RBC precursors by using P blood group Ag as a receptor.
  • Transmission: Most commonly by the respiratory route, followed by blood transfusion and transplacental transmission (occurs in 30% of cases with maximum risk in the second trimester).
  • Associated with:
    • NIHF (non-immune hydrops fetalis).
    • Polyarthralgia syndrome- Pain is more in upper limb joints than lower limb joints.
    • Erythema infectiosum /5th disease- slapped check appearance.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - <10% spread by transplacental route:

  • The most common mode of transmission is the respiratory route.
  • The transplacental transmission occurs in 30% or higher cases with maximum risk in the second trimester.

Option B - Parvovirus B19 exclusively infects animals:

  • Parvovirus only infects humans.

Option C - It is an RNA virus:

  • It is not a RNA virus.
  • Parvovirus is a non-enveloped single-stranded DNA virus.

questions.text: Which of the following is the arthropod involved in Endemic typhus which R. Typhus causes?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Flea:

  • The arthropod involved in Endemic typhus which R. Typhus causes is Flea

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Tick:

  • Tick is the arthropod involved in Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever, Indian tick typhus, and African tick typhus

Option C - Mite:

  • Mites are the arthropods involved in Rickettsial pox and Scrub typhus

Option D - Louse:

  • Louse is the arthropod involved in Epidemic typhus

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the given condition is true?

choices.text: They are more prevalent in Caucasian populations
Asymptomatic Bluish macules are seen in sacral areas.
Treatment is typically required for resolution.

questions.solution:
Correct C - Asymptomatic Bluish macules are seen in sacral areas.:

  • Asymptomatic Bluish macules are seen in sacral areas.:
  • Bluish macules in sacral areas are a characteristic feature of Mongolian spots. These spots are benign and asymptomatic, often resolving spontaneously over time.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - They appear during early childhood: Mongolian spots are present at birth, not during early childhood. They appear as bluish macules, typically in sacral areas, soon after birth.

Option B - They are more prevalent in Caucasian populations.: Mongolian spots are more commonly seen in mongoloid races, such as Asian, Native American, and Hispanic populations, rather than in Caucasian populations.

Option D - Treatment is typically required for resolution.: Treatment is generally not necessary, as Mongolian spots typically fade on their own without intervention.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis of the image given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Ureterocele:

  • Bulging of the distal end of the ureter into the bladder, often associated with obstruction, recurrent UTIs, and hydronephrosis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Vesicoureteral reflux (VUR): Reflux of urine from the bladder into the ureters, potentially causing recurrent UTIs and hydronephrosis.

Option C - Posterior urethral valves (PUV): Congenital obstructive membranes in the urethra, leading to bladder outlet obstruction, hydronephrosis, and recurrent UTIs.

Option D - Renal agenesis: Absence of one or both kidneys due to developmental abnormalities, leading to unilateral or bilateral absence of kidney function.

questions.text: Which statement about scrub typhus is false?

choices.text: Scrub typhus is transmitted by larval trombiculid mites.
It's the larval mites that feed on vertebral hosts, not the adults.
Rickettsia tsutsugamushi is the causative agent of scrub typhus.
Tetracycline antibiotics are effective in treating scrub typhus infections.

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - It's the larval mites that feed on vertebral hosts, not the adults.:

  • Adult mite feeds on vertebral host: The larval stage of the mite feeds on vertebral hosts, not the adult mite.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Scrub typhus is transmitted by larval trombiculid mites: Mite is a vector- Scrub typhus is transmitted by the bite of larval trombiculid mites (chiggers)

Option C - Rickettsia tsutsugamushi is the causative agent of scrub typhus.: Caused by R. Tsutsugamushi- Scrub typhus is caused by the bacterium Orientia tsutsugamushi.

Option D - Tetracycline antibiotics are effective in treating scrub typhus infections.: Tetracycline is treatment- Tetracycline antibiotics are commonly used to treat scrub typhus infections.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a motor vehicle accident. He is conscious but in severe respiratory distress. Physical examination reveals paradoxical chest wall movement, with inward collapse during inspiration and outward bulging during expiration. Chest X-ray confirms multiple fractures of three consecutive ribs bilaterally with associated pulmonary contusions. What is the preferred management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Intermittent positive pressure ventilation (IPPV):

  • Flail Chest, characterized by multiple fractures of consecutive ribs at multiple sites, leads to paradoxical chest wall movement and respiratory compromise. Initial management of flail chest with respiratory failure involves Intermittent positive pressure ventilation.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and D are not preferred in the management of the flail chest with respiratory failure.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy presents to the pediatric clinic with a history of recurrent infections, persistent eczema, and frequent episodes of bleeding with petechiae. Laboratory investigations reveal small platelets, decreased platelet count, low IgM levels, and elevated IgE and IgA levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome:

  • Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome is an X-linked recessive disorder presenting with the triad of recurrent infections, eczema, and thrombocytopenia. The laboratory findings of small platelets, low IgM, and elevated IgE and IgA are consistent with this diagnosis.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and D do not present with a triad of recurrent infections, eczema, and thrombocytopenia.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to the outpatient department with a fever, cough, and difficulty breathing for three days. During the exam, coarse crepitation is heard in his left lower chest. He's prescribed azithromycin 500mg once daily. Which parameter from a plasma concentration vs time graph best indicates the drug's absorption rate?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A- Tmax:

  • Tmax is the time a drug takes to reach maximum concentration in plasma after oral administration.
  • At Tmax, the rate of absorption is equal to the rate of elimination of the drug. It is a rough marker for an average rate of drug absorption.

Incorrect Options: 

Option B - Cmax:

  • Cmax is the maximum plasma concentration of a drug that can be obtained after giving a particular dose.
  • It depends on the dose administered, the rate constant for absorption and the elimination constant of the drug.

Option C- Area under the curve:

  • The area under the curve tells us the extent to which an administered drug reaches the systemic circulation, i.e., the total amount of drug absorbed.

Option D- Minimum effective concentration:

  • It represents the minimum concentration of the drug needed to saturate the receptors and produce the required pharmacological effect.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old male presents to the emergency department with complaints of persistent nasal congestion, purulent nasal discharge, headache, and swelling on his forehead. On examination:



Which condition is most likely responsible for the patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Pott's puffy tumor:

  • In this case, the patient presents with symptoms suggestive of frontal sinusitis, including congestion, purulent nasal discharge, headache, and swelling on the forehead. The swelling on the forehead corresponds to the Pott's puffy tumor which is characterized by subperiosteal cellulitis or abscess of the frontal bone associated
    with frontal osteomyelitis, often secondary to sinusitis.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Mucocele: A Mucocoele of the frontal sinus is associated with the eye being displaced forward, downward, laterally, proptosis, and cystic swelling, which is non-tender and exhibits eggshell cracking. Treatment is frontoethmoidectomy with free drainage of frontal sinus into the middle meatus.

Option C - Cavernous sinus thrombosis: Cavernous sinus thrombosis is not associated with the given clinical presentation.

Option D - Orbital cellulitis: Orbital cellulitis is not associated with the given clinical presentation.

questions.text:
Match the following


	
		
			
			Grading

			a. Mild polyhydraminos

questions.text: In which of the following procedures, is the instrument given in the image used?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Episiotomy:

  • The image shows Busch’s scissors, also known as the Episiotomy scissors, which are used during episiotomy. They are specifically designed for making controlled incisions in the perineum to enlarge the vaginal opening during childbirth.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, C, and D do not involve the use of episiotomy scissors.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the orthopedic clinic with a painless swelling on his right hand's index finger. He reports no history of trauma. An X-ray of the right hand is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Enchondroma:

  • Enchondroma is a benign tumor arising from hyaline cartilage, most commonly affecting the phalanges of the hand. The X-ray findings of an expanded lytic lesion with stippled calcification and no breakage of the cortex and O-ring sign are characteristic of an enchondroma.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and D do not show an O-ring sign on X-ray.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient with a history of hypertension and previous myocardial infarction presents to the emergency department with complaints of dizziness and near-fainting episodes. An electrocardiogram is performed, revealing a pattern consistent with Mobitz II. Which of the following is not seen in this condition?

choices.text: PR interval is normal before a missed beat
PR interval is increased before a missed beat
PR intervals before and after the missed beat are equal

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - PR interval is increased before a missed beat:

  • Typically, there is a sudden skipped beat without a change in the PR interval in Mobitz type II heart block.
  • This results in intermittent failure of conduction from the atria to the ventricles. 

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Infranodal block: In Mobitz II/Infranodal heart block, the conduction block occurs below the AV node, specifically within the Bundle of His.

Option B - PR interval is normal before a missed beat: Mobitz II/Infranodal heart block is characterized by sudden skipped beats without a change in the PR interval.

Option D - PR interval before and after the missed beat are equal: In Mobitz II/Infranodal heart block, the PR interval after the missed beat is usually longer than the PR interval before the missed beat.

questions.text: Which of the following adverse effects is least likely to be expected with the use of canagliflozin?
questions.solution:
Option D: Angioedema

  • Canaligliflozin is an antidiabetic drug that exerts its effect by inhibiting the sodium glucose co transporter -2 (SGLT 2) present in the proximal convoluted tubules of nephrons.
  • Angioedema is not a typically adverse event in patients that use SGLT2 inhibitor. SGLT2 inhibitors are more likely to cause dehydration rather than oedema.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Orthostatic Hypotension

  • SGLT2 inhibitors cause decreased reabsorption of sodium and glucose in the kidneys
  • The unabsorbed glucose in urine causes osmotic diuresis, which can cause dehydration and subsequently orthostatic hypotension.

Option B: Urosepsis

  • The excess glucose in urine caused by inhibition of sodium-glucose co-transporter acts as a nidus of microbial growth, which may result in urosepsis.

Option C: Fournier Gangrene

  • Fournier gangrene is a necrotising soft tissue infection of the external genitalia and the perineum.
  • It is a rare but serious complication of SGLT2 inhibitor use and is caused by glucosuria disrupting the epithelial barriers of skin and mucosa

questions.text: Which of the following muscles attach to the anterior surface of the greater trochanter of the femur?
questions.solution:
Option C: Gluteus Minimus

  • Gluteus Minimus originates from the area in between the anterior gluteal line and inferior gluteal line of gluteal surface ilium, under gluteus medius and insert into the anterior surface of the greater trochanter of the femur.
  • It is innervated by the superior gluteal nerve
  • Works with gluteus medius in the abduction and medial rotation of the hip.
  • Gluteus Minimus is most anterior in attachment & Gluteus Medius is on the lateral surface of the femur.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Gluteus maximus

  • Gluteus maximus is the main extensor muscle of the hip.
  • It is the largest and outermost of the three gluteal muscles and makes up a large part of the shape and appearance of each side of the hips.
  • It originates from the gluteal surface of the ilium, lumbar, fascia, sacrum, and sacrotuberous ligament and inserts into the gluteal tuberosity and iliotibial tract.
  • It is innervated by the inferior gluteal nerve.
  • Gluteus maximus is a major extensor and external rotator of the hip joint.

Option B: Gluteus medius

  • Gluteus medius, one of the three gluteal muscles, is a broad, thick, radiating muscle. It is situated on the outer surface of the pelvis.
  • It originates from the gluteal surface of the ilium, under the gluteus maximus and inserts into the lateral surface of the greater trochanter of the femur.
  • It Is innervated by the superior gluteal nerve.
  • Action: Medial/internal rotation and flexion of the hip (anterior fibres). Extension and Lateral/external rotation of the hip (posterior fibres).

Option D: Piriformis

  • Piriformis muscle passes through the greater sciatic foramen.
  • It originates at the internal surface of the sacrum and inserts at the superior border of the greater trochanter of the femur.
  • It functions in helping lateral rotation of the hip joint, abducting the thigh when the hip is flexed, and assisting stability of the head of the femur in the acetabulum.

questions.text:
After subarachnoid analgesia for delivery, a 24-year-old woman experiences progressively worsening throbbing pain in the back of her head, radiating to the neck and shoulder, nausea, vomiting, and neck stiffness. In what order were the following structures pierced during the analgesia?

a) Epidural space

b) Interspinous ligament

c) Supraspinous ligament

d) Ligamentum flavum

e) Subarachnoid space
questions.solution:
Correct Option D: c-b-d-a-e

  • Structures pierced in sequence:
    • Skin
    • Fat
    • Supraspinous & interspinous ligaments
    • Ligamentum flavum
    • Epidural space
    • Dura mater
    • Arachnoid
    • Subarachnoid space
  • When carrying out lumbar puncture, the needle passes between adjacent vertebral spinous processes, through the supraspinous and interspinous ligaments, and enters the extradural space.
  • The needle continues through the dura and arachnoid mater and enters the subarachnoid space containing CSF.
  • Lumbar puncture is usually done to obtain a sample of CSF for examination and to inject antibiotics, chemotherapeutic drugs, and some anesthetics into the subarachnoid space.
  • The lumbar region is the best site to access the subarachnoid space because the spinal cord terminates around the level of discs between L1 and L2 in adults.
  • The subarachnoid space usually extends to the region of the lower border of the S2 vertebrae.
  • Therefore, there is a large CSF-filled space containing lumbar and sacral roots but no spinal cord.

questions.text: A patient develops a right-to-left shunt. The oxygen content of the arterial and venous sides are 18 ml/dl and 14 ml/dl, respectively. The oxygen content at the pulmonary capillary is 20 ml/dl. What is the percentage shunting of cardiac output?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 33%

  • The venous blood reaching the alveoli volume is Qt which is equal to cardiac output  Since there is a pathological shunt here, some blood is getting delivered to the alveoli, where the exchange of gases will occur, and some blood is going away from the alveoli this is nothing but a shunt fraction. So, the shunt portion of the blood is Qs. Therefore, the total volume of the blood passing through the exchange zone is (Qt – Qs ).
  • The oxygen concentration at the level of the shunt portion is Cv O2 and at the pulmonary capillary is Cc O2

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 25%:

  • This option would be correct if the calculated shunt fraction using the given oxygen contents was 0.25. However, in this case, it isn't, hence this is incorrect.

Option C - 50%:

  • This option would be correct if the calculated shunt fraction was 0.50. However, based on the given oxygen contents, the fraction is lower, making this incorrect.

Option D - 66%:

  • This option would be correct if the calculated shunt fraction was approximately 0.66. However, with the given values, the calculation does not support this, hence it is incorrect.

questions.text: A 25-year-old pregnant woman presents at the 20th week with polyhydramnios and incomplete brain development. When do the anterior and posterior neuropores close during embryonic development, considering the potential prevention of neural tube defects with early folic acid supplementation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Week 4:

  • Anterior & posterior neuropores close during week 4 of development—the anterior neuropore by day 25, the posterior neuropore by day 28.
  • Failure of the Fusion of anterior neuropore results in Anencephaly.
  • Failure of the fusion of posterior neuropore results in Rachischisis.
  • Failure of fusion of both anterior and posterior neuropore results in Craniorachischisis.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Week 2:

  • Week Two is a bilaminar stage
  • On day 20, fusion at the cervical occipital region occurs forming the first pair of somites [Neural tube formation begins]

Option B - Week 3:

  • Neural Tube is formed in the 3rd week from the neural groove. It then elongates to form primary and secondary brain vesicles while the posterior part forms the spinal cord.

Option D - Week 5:

  • By 5th week the neural tube closes and further development starts to form the proper nervous system

questions.text: After engaging in unprotected intercourse 5 hours ago, a 28-year-old woman is brought to the gynecology outpatient department by her partner seeking advice. She took a tablet of levonorgestrel 0.75mg because she does not want to become pregnant. Given the situation, what is the appropriate next dosage of the medication?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option B: 1 tablet (0.75mg) after 12 hours

  • As the first dose is taken another tablet should be taken after 12 hours

  • Levonorgestrel (E. Pills) 0.75 mg, two doses given at 12-hour intervals, is very successful and without any side effects. The two tablets (1.50 mg) can be taken as a single dose also. The first dose should be taken within 72 hours

  • 0.75 mg stat and after 12 hours

Incorrect Options:

Option A: 1 tab after 24 hours

Option C: 2 tabs after 12 hours

Option D: 2 tabs after 24 hours

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl named Emily is brought to the clinic by her parents due to concerns about her development. Her parents mention that Emily had been developing normally in the first few months after birth. However, they noticed a sudden loss of acquired motor skills and speech. Emily now frequently engages in stereotypic hand movements, such as hand wringing. Her head circumference growth has decelerated, and she appears to have poor muscle coordination and an unsteady gait. Additionally, Emily experiences seizures, and an EEG has revealed abnormal findings. Based on the presented scenario, what is the most likely diagnosis for Emily?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Rett syndrome

  • This is the most likely diagnosis for Emily based on the presented scenario. Rett syndrome primarily affects females and is caused by a mutation in the MECP2 gene. The symptoms described, including the loss of acquired motor skills and speech, stereotypic hand movements, decelerated head circumference growth, seizures, abnormal EEG findings, and potential respiratory irregularities, align with the characteristics of Rett syndrome.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Intellectual disability syndrome: Intellectual disability, formerly known as mental retardation, is a condition characterized by limitations in cognitive functioning and adaptive behavior. It typically manifests during childhood and results in difficulties with learning, problem-solving, and independent daily living.

Option B - Down syndrome: Down syndrome is a genetic disorder caused by an extra copy of chromosome 21. It is characterized by distinct physical features, intellectual disability, and delayed development. The symptoms described in the scenario, such as loss of acquired skills and hand movements, are not consistent with Down syndrome.

Option D - Cerebral palsy: Cerebral palsy is a group of neurological disorders that affect movement, muscle tone, and coordination. While some symptoms, such as poor muscle coordination and an unsteady gait, overlap with the scenario, the sudden loss of acquired skills, stereotypic hand movements, and decelerated head circumference growth are more characteristic of Rett syndrome.

questions.text: Which structure is the most medial content of the cubital fossa?
questions.solution:
Option D: Median nerve

  • The most medial content of the cubital fossa is the median nerve

  • The contents of the cubital fossa from medial to radial side (mnemonic MBBR) are:
    • Median nerve
    • Brachial artery
    • Bicep brachii tendon
    • Radial nerve

  • Cubital fossa is bisected by the tendon of the biceps brachii, almost in the midline.
  • Radial nerve enters the fossa laterally in the groove between brachioradialis and brachialis, and in the fossa, it divides into superficial and deep branches.
  • Brachial artery gives radial and ulnar arteries in the lower part of the fossa.
  • Median nerve is the most median content of the cubital fossa.

Option A: Bicep brachii tendon

  • Bicep brachii tendon is present laterally in the cubital fossa. Therefore, injury to the medial aspect of the fossa does not damage the bicep brachii tendon

Option B: Radial nerve

  • Radial nerve is the lateral most content in the cubital fossa, and a wound on the medial aspect of the cubital fossa does not damage it.

Option C: Radial artery

  • The radial artery is the terminal branch of the brachial artery and is formed in the inferior portion of the cubital fossa. It runs along the lateral aspect of the forearm. Hence, a stab wound in the medial aspect of the cubital fossa would not damage it.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman with dysmenorrhea for the past 4 menstrual cycles with USG, shown below, was prescribed a drug. After use for 6 months, an increase in hepatic enzyme and an adverse lipid profile is noted. Which is the most probable drug used?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option A:

  • This patient has presented with congestive type dysmenorrhea and an ovarian cyst with a ground glass appearance suggestive of endometriosis. Out of the mentioned drugs, only OCP and GnRH analogues are used for endometriosis.
  • OC pills (progesterone components) are associated with increased LDL and decreased HDL cholesterol, but estrogens have the opposite effect. Cholestasis and cholestatic jaundice are occasional side effects of OC pills.

Incorrect Options:

Option B:

  • Rifampicin is an anti-tubercular drug that is known to cause hepatotoxicity but has no role in the management of endometriosis

Option C:

  • GnRH analogues are used to manage endometriosis by causing down-regulation of pituitary receptors and GnRH activity, resulting in low LH and FSH. This suppresses ovarian steroid production, causing a medically induced reversible state of menopause. Their side effects include hypoestrogenic symptoms of hot flashes, headache, loss of libido, vaginal dryness, and osteoporosis. These are not hepatotoxic.

Option D:

  • Methotrexate is a chemotherapeutic agent used to treat cancers, autoimmune diseases, ectopic pregnancy, and medical abortions. They have no role in the management of endometriosis.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Focal Nodular Hyperplasia of the liver is correct?

choices.text: It is the most common benign tumor of the liver.
It is predominantly seen in males and correlates strongly with alcohol consumption.
Hepatic architecture is disrupted in Focal Nodular Hyperplasia.
The investigation of choice for diagnosing FNH is contrast-enhanced CT (CECT)

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - The investigation of choice for diagnosing FNH is contrast-enhanced CT (CECT):

  • The investigation of choice for diagnosing FNH is contrast-enhanced CT (CECT), which typically shows a central stellate scar and a spoke wheel or cartwheel pattern on angiography.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - It is the most common benign tumor of the liver: FNH is actually the 2nd most common benign tumor of the liver, with hepatic hemangiomas being the most common.

Option B - It is predominantly seen in males and correlates strongly with alcohol consumption: FNH is more common in females and is associated with oral contraceptive pill use.

Option C - Hepatic architecture is disrupted in Focal Nodular Hyperplasia: FNH is characterized by maintained hepatic architecture.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most sensitive indicator for evaluating the implementation of family planning services in a country?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Net Reproduction Rate (NRR):

  • Reflects the number of daughters a woman can expect to have over her lifetime, providing a sensitive indicator for family planning services as it accounts for mortality and fertility.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Total Fertility Rate (TFR): While widely accepted and indicating complete family size, it primarily measures the average number of children born per woman.

Option B - Generalized Reproductive Rate (GRR): Specifically measures TFR for an older child, focusing on fertility within a specific age range.

Option D - Age-Specific Fertility Rate (ASFR): Tracks changes in fertility rates within specific age groups over time, useful for understanding fertility patterns but not as directly linked to family planning service evaluation as NRR.

questions.text: A local health department in a village is investigating an outbreak of vector-borne diseases. Several patients have presented with symptoms, including high fever, severe joint pain, and rash. The health authorities suspect the involvement of Aedes mosquitoes,  infamous vectors for transmitting various diseases. Among the listed diseases below, which is NOT caused by the Aedes mosquito?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - West Nile fever:

  • Aedes mosquitoes, particularly Aedes aegypti, are responsible for transmitting several diseases. 
  • Dengue fever, Chikungunya, and Yellow fever are all transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes. 
  • Aedes is NOT a vector for West Nile virus. This virus is transmitted by Culex mosquitoes.
  • The clinical picture shows that the patients in a rural area presented with nonspecific symptoms such as fever, joint pain, and a rash.
  • Further history and lab investigations are required to comment on the diagnosis.
  • Mosquito control measures should be initiated when an outbreak is recognized.
  • Common methods include:
    • Environmental sanitation
    • Larvicides
    • Biological control using aquatic predators
    • Chemical control using spraying methods
Diseases transmitted by mosquitoes
Anopheles Malaria
Culex Japanese encephalitis, Filariasis, West Nile fever
Aedes Dengue, Chikungunya, Rift Valley fever, Zika virus
Mansonia Brugian filariasis

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Dengue Fever:

  • Dengue fever is caused by dengue virus, transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes.
  • DF manifests as fever with a headache, retro-orbital pain, arthralgia, and myalgia.
  • It can progress to more severe forms - dengue hemorrhagic fever and dengue shock syndrome.

Option B - Zika: 

  • Zika virus is transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes. 
  • Most infected patients are asymptomatic.
  • Others present with a maculopapular rash and arthralgia.

Option D - Rift Valley Fever:

  • Rift Valley fever is a viral zoonotic disease that primarily affects animals but also has the capacity to infect humans. 
  • It is transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes and blood-feeding flies. 
  • In humans, the disease ranges from a mild flu-like illness to severe hemorrhagic fever that can be fatal.

questions.text: Which is the common amino acid between the urea cycle and TCA?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Aspartate:

  • Aspartate provides the second nitrogen of urea in the Urea cycle, derived from an amino acid.
  • Fumarate, while present in both the Urea cycle and TCA cycle, is not an amino acid.
  • In the TCA cycle, fumarate is converted to malate and then oxaloacetate, which forms aspartate via transamination.
  • Aspartate subsequently enters the urea cycle in the arginosuccinate synthetase step.

Incorrect Options:

Option B -  Alanine:

  • Alanine does not connect the urea cycle and the TCA cycle.
  • It undergoes transamination to form pyruvate, contributing to energy production.
  • Alanine is primarily involved in acid and sugar metabolism, providing energy to various tissues.

Option C - Asparagine:

  • Asparagine is not the link between the urea cycle and the TCA cycle.
  • Its precursor is oxaloacetate, and its synthesis involves aspartate and glutamate.
  • Asparagine synthase catalyzes its formation.

Option D - Fumarate:

  • It is an intermediate of the TCA cycle. It is converted into malate in the TCA cycle.
  • Fumarate is derived from phenylalanine, tyrosine, aspartate, etc., for input to the TCA cycle.
  • Fumarate and aspartate are common links in the urea cycle & TCA, but aspartate is an amino acid whilefumarate is not.

questions.text: Which statement accurately identifies an exception within the Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (JSSK) program?

choices.text: Free diet to mothers during their hospital stay
Free transport for patients from home to the hospital and vice versa
Free treatment for sick infants up to 6 months of age?

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Free treatment of sick infants up to 6 months of age: 

  • However, the program does not offer free treatment for sick infants up to 6 months of age.
  • Services provided under Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (JSSK) program

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and C accurately describe components of the Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (JSSK) program, which aims to provide free maternal and neonatal health services.

questions.text: What is the main characteristic of the stretch reflex pathway?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Monosynaptic pathway:

  • The main characteristic of the stretch reflex pathway is that it is a monosynaptic pathway. In the case of the stretch reflex, when a muscle is stretched, the sensory neuron (Ia fiber) directly synapses with the motor neuron (alpha motor neuron) in the spinal cord, leading to a rapid and automatic muscle contraction, which helps maintain posture and balance.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D - Bisynaptic pathway, Polysynaptic pathway and Oligosynaptic pathway: are incorrect, as explained above.

questions.text: Which among the following is not included in the triad of Isoniazid toxicity?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Alkalosis:

  • Alkalosis is not seen in triad of isoniazid toxicity.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B and D:

  • Triad of isoniazid toxicity includes
    • Seizures
    • Acidosis
    • Coma
  • Isoniazid toxicity includes
    • Neurotoxicity
    • Optic neuritis
    • Hepatotoxicity
    • Anemia
    • SLE or DLE
    • Hallucination
    • Transient memory loss due to neurotoxicity in the brain
    • Arthralgia
    • Gynaecomastia

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with the highest risk of aspiration?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Bilateral SLN palsy:

  • Bilateral superior laryngeal nerve (SLN) palsy results in abduction of the vocal cords, leading to a high risk of aspiration.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Bilateral RLN palsy: Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve is not associated with an increased risk of aspiration compared to bilateral SLN palsy.

Option C - Bilateral SLN and RLN palsy: Bilateral SLN and RLN palsy have a moderate risk of aspiration.

Option D - Unilateral SLN and RLN palsy: Unilateral SLN and RLN palsy have a mild risk of aspiration.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents to the cardiology clinic with complaints of palpitations and shortness of breath. On examination, an elevated jugular venous pressure (JVP) is noted, along with a cannon "A" wave. This is seen in which of the following condition?
questions.solution:
Correct option D - Ventricular tachycardia:

  • Ventricular tachycardia is a condition where a cannon A wave is seen in JVP
  • Other conditions where a cannon A wave is seen in JVP are:
  1. Complete Heart block (3rd degree Heart block)
  2. Junctional Tachycardia (Retrograde P wave)

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B & C:

questions.text: A 40-year-old obese woman presents to the clinic for her annual check-up and weight loss assistance. She had lost her father last month due to cardiac arrest. On physical examination, it is noticed that she has a few yellow raised lesions over her body. The physician ordered electrophoresis of lipoprotein to detect abnormalities in her lipid profile. A broad beta band in the electrophoretic pattern of her serum indicates which of the following disorders?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Type III hyperlipoproteinemia:

  • Also known as familial dysbetalipoproteinemia or broad beta disease.
  • Inherited most often in an autosomal recessive pattern.
  • Defect in remnant lipoprotein clearance by the liver due to abnormal apo E.
  • Electrophoresis reveals a broad beta band, indicating high levels of VLDL and chylomicron remnants.
  • Yellow lesions (xanthomas) develop due to accumulation of triglycerides and cholesterol.
  • Features include elevated chylomicron and VLDL remnants, hypercholesterolemia, xanthomas, atherosclerosis, and increased risk of premature cardiovascular diseases.

Figure: Electrophoresis showing the broad beta band.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Type-I hyperlipoproteinemia:

  • Type-1 hyperlipoproteinemia does not show a broad beta band.
  • There are high levels of Chylomicron ↑↑ VLDL ↑ and normal cholesterol in this disease.
  • It is due to a mutation of Lipoprotein Lipase or Apo C- II.

Option B - Type-IIa hyperlipoproteinemia:

  • Type IIa hyperlipoproteinemia does not show a broad beta band.
  • There are high levels of VLDL ↑ but normal TG in this disease.
  • It is due to mutation of LDL-receptor or Apo B10.

Option D - Type IV hyperlipoproteinemia:

  • Type IV hyperlipoproteinemia has high TG in VLDL.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female with a known history of Crohn's disease visits the clinic with intermittent episodes of redness, grittiness, and mild discomfort in both eyes. The symptoms resolve spontaneously without treatment. Which of the following conditions is the likely cause of her ocular findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Episcleritis:

  • Episcleritis is the likely cause of the patient's ocular findings. Episcleritis is an inflammation of the episclera a thin but dense layer of connective tissue consisting mainly of collagen bundles. It is a benign and recurrent condition that commonly affects middle-aged individuals, more common in females. The patient's intermittent episodes of redness and mild discomfort in both eyes, which resolve spontaneously without treatment associated with Crohn's disease, are characteristic of episcleritis.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Allergic conjunctivitis: Allergic conjunctivitis typically presents with itching, tearing, and bilateral redness. It is commonly associated with a history of allergies and may be triggered by exposure to allergens such as pollen or animal dander.

Option C - Dry eye syndrome: Dry eye syndrome is characterized by a lack of tear production or poor quality tears, leading to symptoms of dryness, burning, and foreign body sensation. It may cause intermittent redness but is not typically associated with the resolving episodes described in the scenario.

Option D - Uveitis: Uveitis is inflammation of the uvea, which includes the iris, ciliary body, and choroid. It presents with symptoms such as eye pain, photophobia (sensitivity to light), and decreased vision. Uveitis is usually more persistent and requires treatment, unlike the self-limiting nature of the patient's symptoms.

questions.text: Which statement helps to differentiate rigidity from spasticity?

choices.text: It is caused by a lesion in the pyramidal tract
It affects both flexor and extensor muscles
More resistance in one direction than in the other direction

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - It affects both flexor and extensor muscles:

  • Rigidity is characterized by increased muscle tone affecting both the flexor and extensor groups of muscles. In contrast, spasticity primarily affects the anti-gravity muscles.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - It is caused by a lesion in the pyramidal tract: Rigidity is caused by extra-pyramidal lesions rather than the pyramidal tract.

Option B - It is velocity-dependent: Velocity-dependent resistance is a characteristic feature of spasticity, not rigidity.

Option D - More resistance in one direction than in the other direction: Spasticity exhibits increased resistance in one direction, not rigidity.

questions.text: Which of the following anatomical facts is true about the stomach?

choices.text: Lymph from the superior two third of the stomach drains into the supra-pancreatic nodes.
All lymphatic drainage from the stomach drains through the celiac nodes.
The gastric branches of the vagus are given at the greater curve.
The lower esophageal sphincter is supplied by the nerves of Latarjet.

questions.solution:
Option B: All lymphatic drainage from the stomach drains through the celiac nodes.

  • All the lymph from the stomach eventually drains into the celiac nodes and then into the cisterna chyli.
  • The lymph from the stomach drains into the right and left gastric nodes on the right side, pancreaticosplenic nodes and supra-pancreatic nodes on the left side, and the inferior portion drains into the pyloric nodes.
  •  

Option A: Lymph from the superior two-thirds of the stomach drains into the supra pancreatic nodes

  • Lymph from the superior portion of the left side drains into the inferior pancreaticoduodenal and supra pancreatic lymph nodes.

Option C: The gastric branches of the vagus are given at the greater curve.

  • Gastric branches of the vagus are given at lesser curvature.

Option D: The lower esophageal sphincter is supplied by the nerves of Latarjet

  • Nerves of Latarjet supply the pylorus and pyloric sphincter.

questions.text:
Match the following:


	
		
			
			
				Ghon’s Method
				Rokitansky Method
				Lettule’s Method
				Virchow’s Method
			
			
			
			A. Most common method

			B. Targeted blocks are removed while maintaining inter-organ relations

			C. Used in infectious diseases like COVID-19

			D. Complete viscera is taken out in large masses, maintaining blood vessels and vascular supply
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 1-B, 2-C, 3-D, 4-A:

Ghon’s Method - B:

  • This method involves removing targeted blocks such as cervical, thoracic, abdominal, and pelvic blocks while maintaining inter-organ relations. This approach allows for the study of the relationships between organs.

Rokitansky Method - C:

  • This method is used for inside dissection, particularly in cases of highly infectious diseases like COVID-19, HIV, and Hepatitis. It minimizes the risk of spreading the infection during the autopsy.

Lettule’s Method - D:

  • In this method, the complete viscera (all organs) are taken out in large masses, maintaining the integrity of blood vessels and vascular supply.

Virchow’s Method - A:

  • This is the most common method of autopsy, involving the removal of organs one by one.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and C are incorrectly matched.

questions.text:
Pick the option with the correct statements regarding the treatment of pulmonary embolism

a. Primary therapy is pneumatic compression stockings

b. Secondary prevention can be done by using anticoagulation or IVC filters

c. The target aPTT of 30–40 seconds is required for unfractionated heparin therapy

d. Warfarin and oral anticoagulants are to be started early

e. Enoxaparin and Fondaparinux require no monitoring

f. Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia induced by unfractionated heparin is controlled by bivalirudin
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A - b, e and f:

  • b - Secondary prevention can be done by using anticoagulation or IVC filters
  • e - Enoxaparin and Fondaparinux require no monitoring
  • f - Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia induced by unfractionated heparin is controlled by bivalirudin

Incorrect options: B, C and D

Option B: a, e and d:

  • a - Primary therapy is by pharmaco mechanical (alteplase + catheter-directed thrombolysis) approach and not by pneumatic compression stockings
  • d - Warfarin takes 5 days to work so can not be started early - For the first 5 days UFH / Enoxaparin/ Fondaparinux can be given parenterally with warfarin

Option C: a, c and d:

  • c - The target aPTT is 60-80 seconds with unfractionated heparin (normal reference range for aPTT in healthy adults is 30-40 seconds)

Option D: a, e and f - Refer to the above explanation

questions.text: In a manufacturing unit, several workers reported excessive workloads and incidents of fatigue to their supervising officer. The officer has reviewed all the complaints and noticed a significant reduction in the progress achieved in terms of work output. He reports the analyzed date to his manager. Which of the following statements regarding work hours under the Factory Act is false?

choices.text: 48 hours per week or 9 hours per day
Adolescents can work for up to 6.5 hours/per day
Women and adolescents can be employed anytime between 6 am to 7 pm

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Adolescents can work for up to 6.5 hours/per day:

  • This violates the Factory Act, which limits adolescents' work hours to a maximum of 4.5 hours per day.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 48 hours per week or 9 hours per day: The Factory Act allows for a maximum of 48 hours of work per week or 9 hours per day.

Option B - 60 hours per week including overtime: Overtime allows for a maximum of 60 hours per week, including regular working hours.

Option D -Women and adolescents can be employed anytime between 6 am to 7 pm: Women and adolescents are generally allowed to work between 6 a.m. and 7 p.m. to ensure their safety and security, with exceptions and provisions for proper facilities during night shifts.

questions.text: Which of the following transport media is used for Streptococcus pyogenes?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B -Pikes medium:

  • The transport medium used for Streptococcus pyogenes is Pikes medium
  • Transport medium is used to maintain vitality of bacteria

Incorrect Options:

Option A -Sach’s buffered glycerol saline:

  • Sach’s buffered glycerol saline is used for the transport of Salmonella and Shigella

Option C - VR medium:

  • VR medium is used for the transport of Vibrio. Another medium used for the transport of Vibrio is Cary Blair medium

Option D - Stuart’s medium:

  • Stuart’s medium and Amies medium are used for the transport of Neisseria

questions.text: Which conditions are associated with the "Light Bulb Sign" on Xray?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Posterior dislocation of the shoulder:

  • The "Light Bulb Sign" can be observed in posterior dislocations where the humeral head appears rounded and resembles a light bulb due to its posterior displacement.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Anterior dislocation of the shoulder: Anterior dislocations typically do not display the "Light Bulb Sign" as the humeral head is displaced anteriorly.

Option C - Fracture of the humerus: While fractures can cause changes in the shape of the humerus, they do not typically result in the specific appearance associated with the "Light Bulb Sign".

Option D - Rotator cuff tear: Rotator cuff tears primarily affect the tendons and muscles around the shoulder joint, and do not typically involve changes in the shape of the humeral head that would resemble a light bulb.

questions.text: A patient presents with a unilateral throbbing headache, photophobia, and excessive lacrimation. He also complains of hemifacial pain on the clenching of teeth. On examination, pupillary reaction, light reflex, and accommodation reflex are normal. Which of the following marked nerves is involved in the above scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 3

  • 3 is the right choice since the side effects depicted involve the Trigeminal nerve ophthalmic division (V1), which supplies sensation to the forehead, scalp, and eye. 

Cluster headaches are known for one-sided pain around the eye or temple, followed by autonomic symptoms like lacrimation, nasal blockage, and ptosis. Hemifacial pain triggered by teeth clenching is also common in trigeminal neuralgia, affecting any of its divisions but usually the maxillary or mandibular.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Is an incorrect choice since the ophthalmic nerve (V1) is a branch of the trigeminal nerve (V), not the first cranial nerve (I), which is the olfactory nerve.

Option B - Is an incorrect choice since the optic nerve (II) is capable of visual work, not the symptoms described within the scenario.

Option D - Is an incorrect choice since the facial nerve (VII) supplies the muscles of facial expression and the lacrimal and salivary glands but isn't included in the sensory symptoms portrayed within the scenario.

questions.text: What are the developmental stages in the life cycle of parasitic trematodes known for infecting humans and snails exclusively, with separate sexes and eggs characterized by spines?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A- Miracidia - Cysts - Cercaria:

  • Trematodes are parasitic flatworms that involve an intricate life cycle.
  • The provided information indicates that the trematodes infect humans and snails, penetrate the skin, have separate sexes, and their eggs have spines suggests the infection from schistostoma.
  • All trematodes shows life cycle of Miracidia- Sporocysts- Redia- Cercaria larva- metacercaria larvae except schistostoma.
  • The life cycle typically involves three main larval stages: miracidia, cyst, and cercaria.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option A for an explanation.

questions.text: Which arteries contribute to the plexus that is a common site for anterior epistaxis in children?

choices.text: Anterior ethmoidal artery, posterior ethmoidal artery, sphenopalatine artery, greater palatine artery
Anterior ethmoidal artery, septal branch of the superior labial artery, septal branch of sphenopalatine artery, greater palatine artery
Anterior ethmoidal artery, septal branch of the superior labial artery, greater palatine artery, nasal branch of anterior superior dental artery
Anterior ethmoidal artery, posterior ethmoidal artery, the nasal branch of the anterior superior dental artery, branches of the facial artery to nasal vestibule

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Anterior ethmoidal artery, septal branch of the superior labial artery, septal branch of sphenopalatine artery, greater palatine artery:

Kiesselbach's plexus, also known as Little's area, is a vascular plexus located in the anterior inferior part of the nasal septum. It is a common site for epistaxis particularly in children. The plexus is formed by the anastomosis of four arteries.:

  • Anterior ethmoidal artery
  • Septal branch of superior labial artery
  • Septal branch of sphenopalatine artery
  • Greater palatine artery

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Anterior ethmoidal artery, posterior ethmoidal artery, sphenopalatine artery, greater palatine artery.:

  • The posterior ethmoidal artery is not part of Kiesselbach's plexus. The posterior ethmoidal artery is a branch of the ophthalmic artery and supplies the nasal septum as well as the lateral wall of the nose.

Option C - Anterior ethmoidal artery, septal branch of the superior labial artery, greater palatine artery, the nasal branch of the anterior superior dental artery.:

  • The superior labial artery and the nasal branch of the anterior superior dental artery are not part of Kiesselbach's plexus.

Option D - Anterior ethmoidal artery, posterior ethmoidal artery, the nasal branch of the anterior superior dental artery, branches of the facial artery to nasal vestibule:

Anterior ethmoidal artery, nasal branch of the anterior superior dental artery, greater palatine artery, septal branch of the superior labial artery.

  • The nasal branch of the anterior superior dental artery are not part of Kiesselbach's plexus.

questions.text: A 24-year-old female, primigravida, at 33 weeks of gestation, presents to the medical outpatient department with complaints of itching on her body for the last 08 days. The itching is more intense over the hands and feet and is not associated with fever or rashes. Liver function tests reveal normal bilirubin and liver enzymes except for a raised serum Alkaline phosphatase. Which of the following is involved in the pathogenesis of this patient's underlying condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option D: Increased bile salts

  • Intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy (ICP) is a cholestatic disorder characterized by:
  • 1. pruritus with onset in the second or third trimester of pregnancy.
  • 2. elevated serum aminotransferases and bile acid levels,
  • 3. spontaneous relief of signs and symptoms within 2-3 weeks after delivery.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Increased conjugated bilirubin

  • Conjugated bilirubin may rarely be raised in patients with intrahepatic cholestasis during pregnancy, but doesn't exceed 6 mg/dL. This is more commonly seen in obstructive jaundice secondary to bile outflow obstruction due to CBD stones etc.

Option B: Increase Prothrombin Time

  • An increase in prothrombin times is more a finding in cases of hepatocellular jaundice resulting from liver cell injury like in viral hepatitis and is seen very rarely in patients with intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy.
  • it is seen in HELLP, AFLP.

Option C: Increased IgE

  • Raised serum IgE levels causing type I hypersensitivity and a cause of pruritis in many conditions are not involved in the pathogenesis of intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy.

questions.text: Which among the following causes epidemic dropsy?
questions.solution:
Correct option A - Argemone mexicana flower:

  • Argemone Mexicana, commonly known as Mexican poppy or prickly poppy, contains toxic alkaloids, mainly sanguinarine, dihydrosanguinarine, and protopine.
  • Consumption of Argemone Mexicana-contaminated food or cooking oil (mainly mustard oil) has been associated with epidemic dropsy, characterized by pitting peripheral edema, diarrhea pleural effusion, ascites, and respiratory distress.
  • The toxic alkaloids present in the plant can cause endothelial damage leading to capillary leak syndrome and fluid accumulation in various body compartments, resulting in the clinical manifestations described in the scenario.
  • It is a consequence of food adulteration.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Khesari dal:

  • Khesari dal (Lathyrus sativus) is known to contain a neurotoxic amino acid, β-oxalyl amino acid (BOAA), which can cause a neurological disorder known as lathyrism.
  • Lathyrism typically presents with spastic paralysis, affecting primarily the lower limbs. It is not associated with epidemic dropsy.

Option C - Crotalaria:

  • Crotalaria species contain pyrrolizidine alkaloids, which are hepatotoxic and can cause hepatic veno-occlusive disease (VOD).
  • However, Crotalaria ingestion is not associated with epidemic dropsy.

Option D - Aspergillus flavus:

  • Aspergillus flavus is a fungus known to produce aflatoxins, which are potent hepatotoxic and carcinogenic compounds.
  • Caused by the contamination of groundnuts, maize, and/or jowar with the fungus.
  • Chronic ingestion of aflatoxin-contaminated food can lead to hepatocellular carcinoma and other liver diseases, but it is not associated with epidemic dropsy.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient with a history of asthma presents with recurrent episodes of cough, wheezing, and increased dyspnea. The patient's serum IgE levels are elevated, and sputum examination reveals fungal hyphae. A high-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) scan of the chest is performed to further evaluate the respiratory findings. What characteristic finding is expected on the HRCT scan in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Central bronchiectasis:

  • The clinical presentation, elevated serum IgE levels, and the presence of fungal hyphae in sputum suggest Allergic Bronchopulmonary Aspergillosis (ABPA). On high-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) of the chest in patients with ABPA, central bronchiectasis is a characteristic finding. This refers to the dilation and distortion of the bronchi in the central or mid-lung zones.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A (Peripheral consolidations) and Option B (Ground-glass opacities) are not typical findings in ABPA. Peripheral consolidations are often associated with other conditions, and ground-glass opacities are seen in various lung diseases but are not specific to ABPA.

Option C - Subpleural blebs: It is not a typical feature of ABPA on HRCT. Subpleural blebs are more commonly associated with conditions like spontaneous pneumothorax rather than ABPA.

questions.text:
A newborn infant is brought to the paediatrician for a routine check-up. The parents mention that the baby appears cyanotic, especially during feeding and crying episodes. Physical examination reveals a  murmur and diminished femoral pulses. A chest X-ray is obtained and is given below.



Which of the following congenital heart defects is most likely responsible for the clinical presentation and X-ray findings in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Transposition of great arteries:

The X-ray finding of "egg on side/string" appearance, characterized by an abnormal positioning of the heart within the chest, is indicative of Transposition of the Great Arteries (TGA). TGA is a congenital heart defect where the positions of the pulmonary artery and aorta are switched. This abnormality results in severe cyanosis and diminished peripheral pulses.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Atrial septal defect: Atrial septal defect is characterized by an abnormal opening between the atria. It typically presents with a wide, fixed splitting of the second heart sound (S2). 

Option B - Ventricular septal defect:It presents with a holosystolic murmur at the left sternal border.

Option C - Constrictive pericarditis: Constrictive pericarditis is characterized by fibrous thickening and calcification of the pericardium, leading to impaired diastolic filling of the heart. The classic X-ray finding of "egg in the cup" appearance represents the calcified and shrunken pericardium causing restriction of the cardiac chambers.

questions.text: Which of the following characteristics make teduglutide a favourable drug in a patient diagnosed with short bowel syndrome?

choices.text: It is used to speed up defecation

questions.solution:
Option B: It is a GLP-2 agonist

  • Glucagon-like peptide (GLP)-2 analogs, such as teduglutide, are used for the treatment of patients with short bowel syndrome (SBS) who require additional support in the form of intravenous nutrition and fluids. These medications work by enhancing intestinal and gastric absorption, reducing the need for parenteral support in SBS patients.
  • Glucagon-like peptides (GLP-1 and GLP-2) are secreted by enteroendocrine cells in the gastrointestinal tract in response to nutrient ingestion.. GLP-1 is primarily involved in enhancing insulin secretion in response to elevated blood glucose levels, suppressing glucagon release, and promoting satiety. GLP-2, on the other hand, promotes intestinal growth and enhances intestinal and nutrient absorption, making it particularly relevant for conditions like short bowel syndrome (SBS).
  • GLP-1 agonist: Exenatide, Liraglutide
  • GLP-2 agonist: Teduglutide

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of Option B.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents to the pediatric ophthalmology clinic with congenital ptosis and abnormal movements of the upper eyelid that occur with jaw movements such as chewing. The child's parents report noticing these abnormal eye movements since infancy. What is the underlying pathology associated with this presentation?

choices.text: Dysfunction of the levator palpebrae superioris muscle
Aberrant innervation between the oculomotor and trigeminal nerves

questions.solution:
Correct Option B – Aberrant innervation between the oculomotor and trigeminal nerves:

  • The patient is suffering from Marcus Gunn Jaw winking syndrome i.e., with the movement of the jaw there will be winking of the lid in the ptotic eye. The underlying pathophysiological mechanism involves aberrant innervation between the oculomotor (CN III) and trigeminal (CN V) nerves. This results in synchronous movements between jaw activity and eyelid elevation.

Incorrect Options:

Option A – Dysfunction of the levator palpebrae superioris muscle: This is not the primary mechanism in Marcus Gunn Jaw-Winking Syndrome. The levator palpebrae superioris muscle is functional, but there is aberrant innervation causing abnormal movements.

Option C – Deficiency in acetylcholine receptor function: This option does not apply to Marcus Gunn Jaw-Winking Syndrome. Acetylcholine receptor deficiency is more relevant to conditions like myasthenia gravis which is a cause of myogenic ptosis.

Option D – Hypoplasia of the extraocular muscles: Hypoplasia of extraocular muscles is not the underlying mechanism in Marcus Gunn Jaw-Winking Syndrome. The primary issue lies in the neural connections, not muscle development.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents to the cardiology clinic with complaints of exertional dyspnea and fatigue. On auscultation, a diastolic murmur is heard at the apex of the heart. An echocardiogram confirms severe aortic regurgitation. Which of the following is the murmur typically associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Austin Flint Murmur:

  • Austin Flint murmur is a mid-diastolic murmur heard at the apex of the heart and is due to severe aortic regurgitation.
  • This murmur results from the regurgitant flow from the aorta impinging on the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve, leading to vibration and turbulence in the left ventricular inflow.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Graham Steele murmur: Associated with pulmonary artery hypertension leading to mild pulmonic regurgitation.

Option C - Seagull murmur: Associated with mild aortic regurgitation.

Option D - Carey Coombs murmur: Associated with rheumatic heart disease and acute rheumatic fever.

questions.text: A 31-year-old man comes to the physician with a 1-month history of pain in his right arm and numbness and tingling in his right hand. He recently started his job as a painter. One month ago, he had to quit his job because the symptoms worsened whenever he tried to reach above his head. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. He does not smoke and drinks two beers per day. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows decreased sensation to fine touch in his right hand's 4th and 5th fingers. Radial pulse intensity decreases when the patient's right arm is abducted and externally rotated. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Option B: Cervical rib

  • A cervical rib is a common cause of thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS), which results from the compression of the lower trunk of the brachial plexus (derived from the C8–T1 nerve roots) and subclavian vessels in the area of the scalene triangle as illustrated in the image below:

 

  • The compression of the lower trunk of the brachial plexus can cause neuropathic pain, paresthesias, and sensory loss in the C8 and T1 dermatomes (i.e., fourth and fifth fingers, medial aspect of the arm), as seen in this case.
  • Weakness of the intrinsic muscles of the hand can also be present.
  • The symptoms of a cervical rib are usually exacerbated by overhead arm elevation. Compression of the subclavian vessels is less common; subclavian vein compression results in arm swelling and subclavian artery compression can cause acute or chronic limb ischemia and, possibly, subclavian steal syndrome.
  • A positive Adson's test is a provocative test for thoracic outlet syndrome. It is accompanied by a cervical rib compression of the subclavian artery or tightened anterior and middle scalene muscles.
  • The other high-yield causes of TOS are:
    • Pancoast tumour
    • Muscular anomalies such as supernumerary scalene muscles, neck muscle hypertrophy)
    • Clavicle fracture.

Option A: Carpal tunnel syndrome

  • Carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS) results in median nerve compression and often manifests with paresthesia of the fingers, which can worsen with prolonged overhead hand elevation (positive hand elevation test).
  • However, this paresthesia would be present in the 1st, 2nd, and 3rd digits rather than the 4th and 5th digits.
  • Moreover, this patient's arm pain and the positive Adson test are inconsistent with CTS.

Option C: Polymyositis

  • Patients with polymyositis have progressive symmetric proximal muscle weakness and report difficulty reaching for objects above their head rather than worsening pain and paresthesia when performing this action.
  • Moreover, this patient's positive Adson test is not consistent with polymyositis.

 Option D: Upper trunk compression

  • Compression of the upper trunk of the brachial plexus (Erb's palsy) can also result in pain and paresthesia.
  • However, the paresthesia would occur in the lateral aspects of the arm, forearm, and hand (C5 and C6 dermatomes), not the fourth and fifth (medial) digits.
  • In addition, patients with Erb's palsy typically present with an internally rotated and adducted arm, extended forearm, and a flexed wrist ("waiter's tip posture") as illustrated in the image below:

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with features of a fistula above the lacrimal sac after abscess drainage by interns. What is the next step for the management of fistula?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – Dacryocystorhinostomy:

  • The most appropriate treatment for lacrimal fistula is dacryocystorhinostomy. This is a surgical procedure that creates a new passageway between the lacrimal sac and the nasal cavity for the drainage of tears.

Incorrect Options:

Option A – Fistulectomy:

  • This involves the surgical removal of a fistula, which is an abnormal connection between two hollow structure of the body.

Option C - Nasolacrimal duct probing:

  • This is a less invasive procedure used to treat nasolacrimal duct obstruction, which can cause symptoms like tearing not preferred for lacrimal fistula.

Option D - Warm compresses:

  • Warm compresses are a non-invasive, conservative measure often used to alleviate symptoms associated with inflammation and swelling. Therefore, the definitive treatment of lacrimal fistula is Dacryocystorhinostomy.

questions.text: Which complications are most likely associated with cyclophosphamide use, and what is the appropriate management strategy?

choices.text: Acrolein-induced hemorrhagic cystitis, managed with Mesna
Nephrotoxicity, managed with hydration and diuretics

questions.solution:
Option A - Acrolein-induced hemorrhagic cystitis, managed with Mesna:

  • Cyclophosphamide is metabolized in the liver to produce acrolein, which can cause irritation and inflammation of the bladder, leading to hemorrhagic cystitis.
  • Mesna (sodium 2-mercaptoethane sulfonate) is a uroprotective agent that binds to acrolein in the urine, reducing its toxicity and protecting the bladder epithelium.
  • Therefore, the correct answer is A, as it aligns with the expected complication of cyclophosphamide use and the appropriate management strategy.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Pulmonary fibrosis, managed with corticosteroids:

  • Cyclophosphamide is not typically associated with pulmonary fibrosis. This complication is more commonly seen with other chemotherapeutic agents or radiation therapy.

Option C - Nephrotoxicity, managed with hydration and diuretics:

  • Nephrotoxicity is not a typical complication of cyclophosphamide. Hydration and diuretics are used to manage nephrotoxicity caused by other medications or conditions.

Option D - Peripheral neuropathy, managed with gabapentin:

  • Peripheral neuropathy is not a direct complication of cyclophosphamide. It is more commonly associated with certain chemotherapy agents like taxanes or platinum-based drugs.

questions.text: Of the following choose the parameter that differentiates iron deficiency anemia from anemia of chronic disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Total Iron binding capacity:

  • In iron deficiency anemia, TIBC is typically elevated as the body attempts to compensate for low iron levels by increasing the capacity to bind iron.
  • In contrast, in anemia of chronic disease, TIBC may be normal or decreased due to the altered iron metabolism associated with inflammation and the retention of iron within macrophages.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Serum iron​​​​​​​:

  • In iron deficiency anemia, serum iron levels are typically decreased due to the insufficient availability of iron for erythropoiesis.
  • In anemia of chronic disease, serum iron levels may also be decreased due to the sequestration of iron within macrophages and decreased absorption, but this is not a consistent finding. Iron levels can sometimes be normal or even elevated due to increased release of iron from stores.

Option B - Serum transferrin saturation​​​​​​​:
