  • In iron deficiency anemia, serum transferrin saturation is typically decreased due to the reduced availability of iron for binding to transferrin.
  • In anemia of chronic disease, serum transferrin saturation may be low-normal despite low serum iron levels, reflecting the altered iron metabolism associated with inflammation.

Option D - None of the above​​​​​​​:

  • This option is incorrect as option C is the correct answer.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication of using methylergometrine?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Induction of labor: 

  • Methylergometrine is not used for the induction of labor as it causes tonic uterine contractions.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, C, and D are indications of using methylergometrine.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with the lesions given below. Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with this finding?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1):

  • Café-au-lait macules are a hallmark feature of NF1, a genetic disorder characterized by multiple neurofibromas and other skin findings.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Tuberous sclerosis: Typically presents with ash-leaf spots and facial angiofibroma, not café-au-lait macules.

Option C - Sturge-Weber syndrome: Presents with facial port-wine stains and neurological abnormalities, not café-au-lait macules.

Option D - Incontinentia pigmenti: Characterized by linear streaks of hyperpigmentation, not café-au-lait macules.

questions.text: Which tongue muscle is not supplied by the hypoglossal nerve?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Palatoglossus:

  • Palatoglossus is the only tongue muscle supplied by the vagus nerve. The hypoglossal nerve supplies all other tongue muscles.

Incorrect Options:

Option B, C, and D - Genioglossus, Hyoglossus, Styloglossus:

  • Genioglossus, Hyoglossus, and Styloglossus are innervated by the hypoglossal nerve.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man is suffering from a headache and left-sided upper extremity weakness. He also complains of difficulty in speech. The doctor suggests an MRI brain which is given below. What does this MRI exhibit?

choices.text: The lesion is regular in shape
Shows a ring pattern of enhancement with intravenous contrast and has a non-enhancing necrotic center
Shows an absence of surrounding white-matter edema

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Shows a ring pattern of enhancement with intravenous contrast and has a non-enhancing necrotic center:

  • MRI shown above shows Glioblastoma multiforme, which crosses the midline, and the image also shows a ring-enhancing lesion with central necrosis.
  • Glioblastoma multiforme
    • Most common primary malignant brain tumor in adults.
    • It is a WHO grade IV astrocytoma that accounts for most high-grade astrocytomas with poor prognosis and survival rate.
    • Known as a butterfly tumor as it crosses the midline of the brain.
    • They usually present in the 6th and 7th decade of life with headaches, seizures, focal deficits, and personality changes.
  • Treatment involves gross total resection with postoperative chemotherapy and radiation therapy. Temozolomide is a new drug used in newly diagnosed GBM and recurrent GBM.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Lesion is regular in shape:

  • Imaging demonstrates a ring-enhancing lesion with central necrosis, surrounding edema, and mass effect.
  • These are irregular lesions in shape and highly infiltrative tumors.
  • The areas of increased T2/FLAIR signal surrounding the main tumor mass contain invading tumor cells

Option B - Well-demarcated from surrounding brain tissue:

  • The lesion is irregular in shape.
  • It is highly infiltrative and hence cannot be well demarcated from surrounding tissue.
  • Lesions in the brain include abscess, sclerosis, and cerebral infarction.

Option D - Shows an absence of surrounding white-matter edema:

  • Surrounding edema is present.
  • In cerebral edema, the additional fluid is accumulated within the brain's white matter.
  • It is usually the response of the brain to an insult. It is of two major types: cytotoxic (gray and white matter) and vasogenic (white matter) edema.
  • Treatment includes hyperventilation, osmotherapy, diuretics, corticosteroids, and surgical decompression.

questions.text: Which of the following tests is used to assess the function of the dorsal interossei muscles of the hand?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Egawa Test:

  • The Egawa test is used to assess the function of the dorsal interossei muscles. The patient places their palm flat on the table and is asked to move their middle finger sideways. The inability to move the finger sideways indicates the involvement of the dorsal interossei muscles.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and C are not used to assess the function of the dorsal interossei muscle.

questions.text: Which of the following paraneoplastic syndromes is associated with thymoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Pure red cell aplasia:

  • Pure red cell aplasia (PRCA) is a paraneoplastic syndrome commonly associated with thymoma.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are not associated with Thymoma.

questions.text: Which day of wound healing is characterized by the maximum presence of granulation tissue and neovascularization?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Day 5:

  • Day 5 is characterized by the maximum presence of granulation tissue and neovascularization. Collagen bridging also begins at this stage.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Day 0: Platelets and fibrin form the initial blood clot in response to injury.

Option B - Day 1: The blood clot remains, and acute inflammation with neutrophils predominates.

Option C - Day 2: The blood clot persists, acute inflammation continues with neutrophils, and a thin epithelial layer begins to form.

questions.text: A 22-year-old female from India presents with symptoms of arm claudication and a significant difference in blood pressure between her left and right arms. On further evaluation, she is found to have renal artery stenosis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Takayasu arteritis:

  • In this scenario, the most likely diagnosis is Takayasu arteritis.
  • Takayasu arteritis is a large-vessel vasculitis commonly affecting young females, particularly from India. It is associated with ostial narrowing of the major arteries, including the renal artery, which can lead to reduced renal blood flow and hypertension.
  • Histologically, there is granulomatous thickening and narrowing of the aortic arch and proximal great vessels.
  • Clinical features:
    • Weak upper extremity pulses, blood pressure difference between left and right arms
    • Arm claudication
    • Fever, night sweats
    • Arthritis, myalgias
    • Skin nodules
    • Ocular disturbances 
  • Investigations: MR angiography is the investigation of choice, and helps stage the disease distribution. CT angiography can also be done.
  • Initial treatment of symptomatic Takayasu arteritis begins with corticosteroids.
  • Surgical revascularization is required in a few patients. 

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Atherosclerosis of the renal artery: While atherosclerosis can cause renal artery stenosis, it typically occurs in older individuals, especially those with a history of smoking. In atherosclerosis, the entire length of the blood vessel narrows, whereas in Takayasu arteritis, only the ostium narrows.

Option B - Fibromuscular dysplasia (FMD): FMD is another cause of renal artery stenosis, typically seen in young females living in the USA. It is characterized by abnormal cell growth within the arterial wall, leading to narrowing. However, in this scenario, the clinical features (arm claudication, significant blood pressure difference) and the patient's origin (India) are more suggestive of Takayasu arteritis.

Option D - Coarctation of the aorta: Coarctation of the aorta is a congenital heart defect characterized by narrowing of the aorta, typically near the insertion of the ductus arteriosus. It causes a difference in blood pressure between the arms and legs, with higher blood pressure in the arms. However, this condition is usually diagnosed in childhood or early adulthood and is not associated with renal artery stenosis.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female librarian is in the emergency department with difficulty swallowing for the last two hours. She has high blood pressure, weakness on the right side of her lower face, and her tongue deviates towards the right side upon protrusion. However, no weakness was observed in her upper or lower limbs. The lesion responsible for these symptoms is located in which of the following areas?

choices.text: Anterior limb of the internal capsule
Genu of the internal capsule, left side

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Genu of the internal capsule, left side:

  • A lesion involving the genu of the internal capsule damages the corticobulbar fibers.
  • The facial nerve nucleus receives bilateral corticobulbar input, the upper face division receives input from both cerebral hemispheres, and the lower face division receives only contralateral input. (So, lesion of left genu will present as right-sided lower face weakness).

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

  • The nucleus of the hypoglossal nerve receives only contralateral corticobulbar input. So, a lesion of the left genu will present as right-side hypoglossal paralysis. Hence, when the tongue is protruded, it deviates to the right (side of LMN lesion) owing to the unopposed activity of the intact genioglossus.
  • Lesion of the Left genu will cause paralysis of the opposite (right) ago-accessory complex. So, the uvula deviates to the left (entire side / opposite site of LMN lesion) when the patient says "ah."

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Anterior limb of the internal capsule:

  • Anterior limb sandwiched between lentiform (lateral) & caudate (medial) functions for emotions, cognition, and decision-making. A lesion in this area will result in psychiatric illness.

Option B - Claustrum:

  • The claustrum is present between the insular cortex and the putamen and supplied by the middle cerebral artery. Any lesion in the claustrum will manifest as loss of consciousness.

Option D - Paracentral lobule, right side:

  • Anterior cerebral artery (major artery on medial cerebrum especially supplying paracentral lobule); controlling lower limb and part of pelvis and perineum. Any block in the anterior cerebral artery causes urinary incontinence, lower limb paralysis, and sensory problems. The manifestation will be on the contralateral side of the lesion.

questions.text: Which is the most common mother-to-child transmitted infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Cytomegalovirus (CMV):

  • Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is the most common infection transmitted from mother to child. If CMV is transmitted from the mother to the fetus before 15 weeks of gestation, approximately 5-6% of babies are affected.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and D are not the most common mother-to-child transmitted infections.

questions.text: What is the prerequisite for intrauterine insemination in couples with infertility and analysis if the husband's semen shows a low sperm count?

choices.text: The fallopian tube should be patent
0.3 to 0.5mL of masturbated semen is inseminated into the uterus
2% of sperms should have normal morphology.
The total number of motile sperms should be 1 million least

questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option A: Fallopian tube should be patent

  • Intrauterine insemination:
    • It is artificial insemination used to treat infertility.
    • It is a procedure in which washed and concentrated sperm are introduced directly into the uterine cavity.
  • Prerequisites
    • Patent fallopian tubes
    • Motile sperms 5-10 million
    • 4% of sperms should have normal morphology
  • Semen is never inseminated into the uterus in intra-uterine insemination. The prostaglandins and the bacteria from the penis can elicit severe crampy pain and PID, respectively.
  • Only the 'washed sperm' is utilized for insemination.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: 0.3 to 0.5mL masturbated semen is inseminated into the uterus

  • Semen is never inseminated directly into the uterus in intrauterine insemination. The prostaglandins and the bacteria from the penis can elicit severe crampy pain and PID, respectively.
  • Only the washed sperm are utilized for insemination.

Option C: 2% of sperms should have normal morphology

  • According to the prerequisites of IUI
  • 4% of sperms should have normal morphology.
  • In sperm morphology, the size and shape of the head and tail defects head’s are considered.
  • Sperm morphology shows a percentage of normal forms of sperm in the semen sample.

Option D: The total number of motile sperm should be 1 million at least.

  • A total motile count of 20 million is considered normal in semen analysis.
  • Oligospermia is an indication of IUI, however, the sperm count should be at least 5-10 million
  • It includes progressive and non-progressive motility.
  • Progressive motility:
    • Sperm can move in a straight line or a circle.
  • Non-progressive motility:
    • It includes sperm movement, which does not result in progression (e.g., minimal linear movement, movement in smaller circles).
  • Immotile sperms have no discernible movement.

questions.text: A 36-year-old G2P1L1 presents with mild vaginal bleeding at 20 weeks. On examination, the uterus is 26 weeks in size and fetal heart sounds are absent. Ultrasound shows a snowstorm appearance and no fetus. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A Suction and evacuation

  • History is suggestive of a complete mole (uterine size > POG, snowstorm appearance, and absence of fetus)
  • Suction evacuation is the treatment of choice for hydatidiform mole, regardless of uterine size.
  • It helps to promptly remove the molar tissue and alleviate the symptoms, as well as reduce the risk of complications such as uterine hemorrhage.
  • In patients with advanced maternal age typically greater than 40 years old and those who have completed childbearing, a hysterectomy is often performed instead of suction evacuation.

Incorrect Options:

Option B:

  • Chemotherapy is typically not the first-line treatment for complete moles. However, it may be considered if there is evidence of persistent or metastatic disease after evacuation.

Option C:

  • Hysterectomy is a more aggressive option and is generally not the primary treatment for complete moles. It is reserved for cases with extensive disease or if the patient has completed childbearing.

Option D: 

  • Monitoring serum beta hCG levels is an essential part of the management of gestational trophoblastic disease. After the evacuation of a complete mole, serial measurements of beta hCG are performed to monitor the resolution of trophoblastic tissue. Persistent elevation may indicate the presence of persistent disease or the development of choriocarcinoma.
  • It is not the treatment option.

questions.text: Which disorder is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner and often presents with respiratory and digestive symptoms such as chronic cough, recurrent lung infections, and pancreatic insufficiency?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Cystic fibrosis:

  • Cystic fibrosis is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner, meaning that both copies of the CFTR gene must be mutated for the disease to manifest.
  • It is characterized by respiratory symptoms such as chronic cough, recurrent lung infections (particularly with Pseudomonas aeruginosa), and bronchiectasis.
  • Digestive symptoms commonly include pancreatic insufficiency, leading to malabsorption of nutrients and steatorrhea.
  • Additionally, cystic fibrosis can affect multiple organs, including the pancreas, liver, and sweat glands.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Albinism

  • Albinism is also an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by a lack of melanin production in the skin, hair, and eyes.
  • It does not typically present with respiratory or digestive symptoms.

Option B - β-Thalassemia

  • β-Thalassemia is an inherited blood disorder characterized by reduced production of hemoglobin, leading to anemia.
  • While it can cause symptoms such as fatigue and shortness of breath due to anemia, it primarily affects the blood and does not involve respiratory or digestive symptoms like cystic fibrosis.

Option D - Galactosemia

  • Galactosemia is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a deficiency of enzymes needed to metabolize galactose, a sugar found in milk and dairy products.
  • It can lead to symptoms such as liver damage, jaundice, and intellectual disability if untreated. However, it does not typically present with respiratory symptoms like chronic cough or recurrent lung infections.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the psychiatric clinic with his wife. He has become increasingly suspicious and accuses his wife of having an affair despite no evidence to support his claims. These suspicions have caused significant strain in their relationship. His wife reports that he recently lost his job and has been consuming alcohol heavily. Despite her reassurances and lack of evidence, he remains convinced that she is unfaithful. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Othello's Syndrome:

  • Othello's Syndrome is characterized by a persistent belief that a partner is unfaithful despite a lack of evidence, often exacerbated by factors like prolonged alcohol use.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - De Clerambault's Syndrome: Also known as Erotomania, this condition involves the delusion that another person, often of higher social status, is in love with the patient. It is unrelated to suspicions of infidelity.

Option B - Delusion of Nihilism: The patient denies the existence of his own body, loved ones, the world, and everything. It is unrelated to suspicions of infidelity.

Option D - Delusion of Persecution: This type of delusion involves a belief that one is being targeted or harassed by others. It is unrelated to suspicions of infidelity.

questions.text: A 28-year-old gardener presents to the clinic with a tender, red, and swollen area on her forearm, showing a central area of necrosis surrounded by an erythematous halo. A skin biopsy reveals eosinophilic material forming radially arranged spikes around the necrotic center. What term describes this histological phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Splendore-Hoeppli phenomenon:

  • Histopathological staining of the biopsy shows a star-shaped body (asteroid body), and the patient's presentation is suggestive of sporotrichosis caused by Sporothrix schenckii.
  • Splendore-Hoeppli phenomenon (asteroid bodies) is the in vivo formation of intensely eosinophilic material (radiate, star-like, asteroid or club-shaped configurations) around microorganisms (fungi, bacteria and parasites) or biologically inert substances.  

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Granuloma: A granuloma is a localized area of inflammation characterized by a persistent immune stimulus that causes the accumulation of macrophages and immune cells, typically lymphocytes. Granulomas are often seen in response to chronic infections, autoimmune diseases, or foreign bodies.

Option B - Acantholysis: Acantholysis is the loss of intercellular connections between keratinocytes in the epidermis. It is a histological feature seen in conditions like pemphigus vulgaris, where autoantibodies target the desmosomal proteins that hold keratinocytes together. Acantholysis does not involve the deposition of eosinophilic material around a necrotic center, as described in the question.

Option D - Koebnerization: The Koebner phenomenon refers to the development of new skin lesions at the site of trauma or injury in individuals with certain skin conditions, such as psoriasis or lichen planus. It does not involve the histological findings described in the question, which focus on eosinophilic material deposition around a central necrotic area.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with morbid obesity presents to the hospital for weight loss surgery. Her Body Mass Index (BMI) is 42 kg/m2. She has a history of hypertension and type-2 diabetes mellitus. All her previous attempts to lose weight via dietary modifications, lifestyle changes and exercise have failed. The surgeon discusses the surgical procedure he wants to perform with the patient. A pictorial diagram of the process is shown below. Which of the following is a feature of this procedure?

choices.text: The side effect is 2- 4 malodorous bowel movements per day
No effect on Type 2 diabetes mellitus

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - The side effect is 2- 4 malodorous bowel movements per day:

  • The procedure shown in the picture is biliopancreatic diversion.
  • It is the most effective type of bariatric surgery
  • It is associated with maximum weight loss
  • The main side effect is 2- 4 bowel malodorous movements per day (due to fat malabsorption)
  • Components of this procedure include:
    • Distal gastrectomy
    • Gastro-ileostomy
    • Jejunoileostomy
    • Cholecystectomy
    • Appendectomy
  • Length of the common channel created by this procedure is 50 cm. The food is allowed to mix with the bile and pancreatic enzymes only in the distal 50 cm of the ileum, causing decreased digestion and fat absorption.
  • It is largely malabsorptive and mildly restrictive
  • Maximum remission of type 2 diabetes mellitus occurs with this surgery

Disadvantage

  • There is a high risk of ulcer at the site of anastomosis of gastroileostomy

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Moderate weight loss:

  • Biliopancreatic diversion is considered to have the maximum weight loss in all bariatric surgeries.

Option B - Mildly malabsorptive and largely restrictive:

  • This procedure results in a largely malabsorptive and mildly restrictive state.

Option D - No effect on type-2 diabetes mellitus:

  • In a biliopancreatic diversion, maximum remission is seen for type-2 diabetes mellitus; therefore, patients with type-2 diabetes benefit greatly from this surgery.

questions.text: Which of the following histological features is characteristic of dysgerminoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Option - B:

  • The given image shows large polygonal cells with clear cytoplasm and dark-stained nucleoli arranged back to back, which are characteristic of Dysgerminoma.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - The given image shows large cuboidal cells with clear cytoplasm known as hobnail appearance. It is characteristic of clear cell carcinoma.

Option C - The given image shows Carl Exner's bodies, which are seen in Granulosa Cell Tumors.

Option D - The given image shows Psammoma bodies which are seen in Serous Cystadenoma.

questions.text: A 30-years-old primigravida with diabetes mellitus at 30 weeks gestation is admitted to the ICU with multiorgan dysfunction. She is oriented in time and place. She has had mild lower abdominal pain for the last few days and reports no trauma history. Her lab parameters suggest thrombocytopenia, decreased fibrinogen, and an INR of 2.1. Her blood sugar level is 180mg/dL. Which of the following is a common underlying cause of such presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B: Abruptio placenta

  • Abruptio placenta is the most common cause of consumptive coagulopathy in obstetrics due to the associated bleeding and activation of the clotting system.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Gestational diabetes

  • Gestational diabetes is diagnosed in pregnant patients after 20 weeks of gestation.
  • Such patients have underlying risk factors, such as obesity and prior gestational diabetes.
  • Patients who have been diagnosed with diabetes mellitus before pregnancy cannot be diagnosed with gestational diabetes.
  • DIC is not caused by GDM, however, chances of DIC are higher in overt diabetics

Option C: Placenta previa

  • Placenta previa is the attachment of the placenta at or near the internal cervical opening instead of its normal attachment site.
  • It causes visible external bleeding.
  • Placenta previa does not cause DIC unless associated with massive hemorrhage​​​

Option D: Rupture of the uterus

  • The uterus rupture is an obstetrics emergency that leads to the rapid demise of the fetus and/or mother.
  • Emergency C-section with the repair of the uterus is indicated.
  • Uterine rupture would cause DIC only if associated with massive hemorrhage

questions.text: Which of the following locations do you think fibrocartilage is present?
questions.solution:
Option C: Intervertebral disc

  • The features of fibrocartilage are perichondrium is absent, more visible collagen fibers, and few chondrocytes. Chondrocytes run in rows alternated by bundles of collagen fibers.
  • Fibrocartilage is the shock absorber that provides strength to cartilage and is found in the intervertebral disc.
  • It is predominantly made of Type 1 collagen
  • It acts as a cushion between two vertebras and the principal joint between two vertebrae.
  • There is a total of 23 discs in the human supine which are 6 cervical, 12 thoracic, and 5 lumbar.
  • It provides flexibility to the supine without compromising on strength.
  • The components of the intervertebral disc are;
    • Inner nucleus pulposus.
    • Outer annulus.

  • Islands of chondrocytes scattered in the hyalos matrix (collagen fibers not visible).
  • The presence of perichondrium is evident. Hyalos: Glass-like.
    • Collagen fibers are not evident to the eye (optical illusion).
    • Refractive index of Collagen fibers = RI of matrix

Option A: Costal cartilage

  • It’s the bar of hyaline cartilage that prolongs the ribs forward.
  • It increases the elasticity of the thorax.

Option B: Nasal septum

  • Nasal septum is made of hyaline cartilage.
  • It is made of Type 2 collagen
  • It divides the nasal cavity into the right and left portions.
  • It allows the air directly enter the lungs.

Options D: Pinna

  • Pinna has elastic cartilage.
  • Elastic cartilage: Prominent elastic fiber, perichondrium, is present.

questions.text: Which of the following structures does not pierce the clavipectoral fascia?
questions.solution:
Option B: Median pectoral nerve

  • The clavipectoral fascia is a layer of collagen fibers that extends from the clavicle downwards towards the pectoralis minor muscle. It splits and envelops the pectoralis minor muscle before continuing inferiorly toward the floor of the axilla.
  • It extends from the clavicle superiorly, costochondral joints medially, and the coracoid process superolaterally.
  • It is divided into several segments: 
    • Costocoracoid membrane: The most superficial part attached to the coracoid process blends with the upper two external intercostal membranes. It encloses the subclavius muscle.
    • Costocoracoid ligament: Between the coracoid process and the first costochondral joint.
    • It continues downward to enclose the pectoralis minor muscle
    • Suspensory ligament of the axilla: Attached to the axillary fascia.
  • Inferior to the costocoracoid ligament is an opening through which two structures enter, and two structures leave the deep compartment of the pectoral girdle
  • The structures entering include: 
    • The cephalic vein
    • The lymphatic vessels from the infraclavicular lymph nodes
  • The structures leaving include: 
    • Lateral pectoral nerve
    • The Thoracoacromial artery

The median pectoral nerve does not pierce the clavipectoral fascia.

Option A: Cephalic vein

  • The cephalic vein enters from the arm through the opening in the clavipectoral fascia to join the axillary vein.

Option C: Lateral pectoral nerve

  • The lateral pectoral nerve is a branch of the lateral cord of the brachial plexus.
  • It passes through the opening in the clavipectoral fascia to exit the deep compartment of the pectoral girdle to their respective muscles.

Option D: Thoracoacromial vessels

  • Thoracoacromial artery or its branches (acromial, deltoid, pectoral, and clavicular) exit the pectoral girdle from the opening in the clavipectoral fascia.

questions.text: All are the correct diagnostic findings of Streptococcal infection except?

choices.text: Pin-point colonies with wide zone hemolysis on blood agar

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Gram-negative cocci in chains:

  • This is an incorrect clinical finding of Streptococcal infection
  • The correct statement is that Streptococci are gram-positive cocci in chains on staining

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D:

  • These are the correct diagnostic findings seen in Streptococcus infection

questions.text:
A 50-year-old female patient presents with complaints characterized by episodic color changes in her fingers in response to cold temperatures or emotional stress. She mentions experiencing these symptoms for several years. Upon further examination, the patient is noted to have thickening and tightening of the skin on her fingers. She also reports occasional episodes of ischemic pain in her digits, particularly during cold weather.

Which of the following antibodies is most likely to be positive in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Anti-Centromere antibody:

  • The patient's presentation, including Raynaud's phenomenon, sclerodactyly (thickening and tightening of the skin on the fingers), and ischemic pain in the digits, is suggestive of limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis.
  • In this, Raynaud's phenomenon often precedes the development of sclerodactyly by several years.
  • One of the characteristic antibodies associated with systemic sclerosis, particularly in limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (lcSSc), is the Anti-Centromere antibody.
  • Autoantibodies in systemic sclerosis
  • Image 1:Anti-Topoisomerase antibodies
  • Image 2:Anti-Centromere antibody
  • Image 3:Anti-RNA Polymerase III

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D:

  • Other antibodies such as Anti-Topoisomerase antibodies (anti-Scl-70), Ku antibody, and U1 RNP may be seen in systemic sclerosis, they are less commonly associated with the limited cutaneous form

questions.text: In bullous impetigo, which of the following is the primary target?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A- Desmoglein-1 (DSG1):

  • In bullous impetigo, the primary target is desmoglein-1 (DSG1). Staphylococcus aureus produces exfoliative toxins, particularly exfoliative toxin A (ETA), which specifically targets and cleaves desmoglein-1. This leads to the separation of keratinocytes within the epidermis, resulting in the formation of bullae.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Desmoglein-3 (DSG3): It is not the primary target in bullous impetigo. Although desmoglein-3 is involved in autoimmune blistering disorders like pemphigus vulgaris, it is not the primary target in bullous impetigo.

Option C - Epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR): It is not the primary target in bullous impetigo. EGFR is a receptor involved in cell signaling pathways and is not directly implicated in the pathogenesis of bullous impetigo.

Option D – Fibronectin: It is not the primary target in bullous impetigo. Fibronectin is an extracellular matrix protein involved in cell adhesion and wound healing processes but is not specifically targeted in bullous impetigo.

questions.text: In a patient receiving amphotericin B who develops extreme lethargy, muscle weakness, and an increase in carbon dioxide levels with hyperventilation, and a serum potassium level of 2.3 mEq/L, what is the appropriate correction of potassium to be given to the patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 140 mEq of KCl/24hrs:

  • For potassium levels less than 3 mEq/L or in patients unable to take oral supplementation due to ileus or illness, intravenous correction with potassium chloride is indicated.
  • Correction should be done slowly via infusion.
  • To increase potassium levels from 2.3 to 3 mEq/L, approximately 200 mEq of KCl should be supplied slowly via IV. Once levels reach 3 mEq/L, oral supplementation can be considered.
  • Additionally, to maintain a rise of 0.7 mEq/L, approximately 140 mEq of KCl should be administered over a 24-hour period.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • A, B and C are incorrect due to the above given reasons.

questions.text: In a community medicine study assessing the efficacy of a new vaccination program, researchers aim to determine if the program reduces the incidence of a specific infectious disease in a population. They set the significance level (α) at 0.05. During analysis, they discover a statistically significant decrease in disease incidence among vaccinated individuals compared to the control group. However, upon further investigation, it is found that the decrease in disease incidence is not actually attributable to the vaccination program. Which of the following is not true about Type 1 error?

choices.text: The null hypothesis is false but rejected

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - The null hypothesis is false but rejected:

  • The correct statement would be: “The null hypothesis is true but rejected.”
  • Type 1 error means stating that there is an effect or difference when none exists (H0 incorrectly rejected in favor of H1).

 

Reality

H1

H0

Study rejects H0

Power (1-β)

Type 1 error (α)

Study does not reject H0

Type 2 error (β)

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - α error:

  • α error refers to the probability of rejecting the null hypothesis when it is actually true. In this case, the researchers set the significance level (α) at 0.05, indicating the threshold for accepting or rejecting the null hypothesis. Therefore, α error is related to this scenario.

Option B - False positive trial:

  • A false positive trial occurs when the intervention appears effective, but in reality, it does not have the intended effect. In this scenario, the apparent decrease in disease incidence among vaccinated individuals constitutes a false positive result because the vaccination program is not the cause of the observed reduction.

Option C - Serious error:

  • Type 1 is a serious error in hypothesis testing as it can lead to incorrect conclusions and potentially harmful decisions, such as implementing an ineffective intervention or treatment.

questions.text: A 66-year-old male presented to the local hospital with complaints of urinary retention with severe pain and burning sensation in the lower urinary tract since yesterday. He also has a poor urinary stream, nocturia, and post-void dribbling. The vital signs and Laboratory tests were normal. On digital rectal examination, there is a palpable, hard, nodular prostate with an obliterated median sulcus. Ultrasound reports showed an enlarged prostate of weight 93 grams. His ratio of free: total PSA is estimated as 20%. The ultrasound of this patient is given below. What diagnosis does the doctor suspect in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Benign prostatic hyperplasia:

It is a suspected case of benign prostatic hyperplasia due to urinary symptoms such as urinary retention, poor urinary stream, nocturia, and postvoid dribbling in the old male.

Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) is a benign enlargement of the prostate that occurs after 50 years, usually between 60 and 70 years. BPH affects both glandular epithelium and connective tissue stroma. 
It is involuntary hyperplasia due to disturbance of the ratio and quantity of circulating androgens and estrogens.

•On digital rectal examination, a palpable prostate with smooth muscle hypertrophy is the typical finding of benign prostatic hyperplasia.

•The free: total prostate-specific antigen ratio discriminates between prostate carcinoma and benign prostate hyperplasia. If it is < 18%, it is suggestive of carcinoma; if it is > 18 %, it suggests benign prostate hyperplasia, as it is 20% in this patient, indicating benign prostate hyperplasia.       

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Tuberculous prostate:

  • As there is no history and symptoms of tuberculosis, this disease does not correlate with the patient's condition.
  • It is diagnosed by urine examination for ZN staining and culture of tubercle bacilli from the first morning urine sample. 

Option C - Acute prostatitis:

  • It is the inflammation of the prostate due to any lower abdominal trauma or secondary to urinary tract infection.
  • On palpation, there is a warm and tender prostate. Leukocytosis is the typical lab finding.

Option D - Carcinoma of the prostate:

  • The free: total ratio of PSA is the differentiating point between carcinoma and benign prostate hyperplasia.
  • If it is > 18%, it is suggestive of benign prostate hyperplasia as this patient has a 20% ratio, so it excludes carcinoma of the prostate.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man presents to the hospital after sustaining a severe motorbike collision. On examination, the patient is hemodynamically stable and alert. X-rays show multiple fractures. A whole-body CT shows a bilateral pulmonary contusion with small hemothorax, a renal contusion, and multiple pelvic fractures. Progressively, the patient becomes hemodynamically unstable. Three units of packed erythrocytes are given together with 1 g of tranexamic acid and 1000 ml hydroxyethyl starch. Laboratory parameter analysis from the blood sample drawn at admission confirms coagulopathy associated with moderate metabolic acidosis. What is the next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: The patient should be prepared for damage control surgery
The patient should be hemodynamically stable for any operative procedure; hence aggressive resuscitation is recommended
Coagulopathy has to be corrected as a part of resuscitation, and then operative control of hemorrhage & contamination is performed
If hemodynamic stability is achieved, conservative management is enough for this patient

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - The patient should be prepared for damage control surgery:

  • The patient had a severe motorbike collision. He has pulmonary and renal contusions, hemothorax and multiple fractures.
  • Labs confirm coagulopathy and metabolic acidosis.
  • As the patient progressively deteriorates, he should be immediately prepared for damage control surgery.
  • This life-saving surgery is needed to control hemorrhage. Definitive surgery can be performed later.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - The patient should be hemodynamically stable for any operative procedure; hence aggressive resuscitation is recommended:

  • The patient is progressively deteriorating.
  • Immediate surgical intervention is needed to control bleeding and contamination.
  • Aggressive resuscitation will fail as the patient has already developed coagulopathy and metabolic acidosis.
  • This patient is a candidate for damage control surgery.

Option C - Coagulopathy has to be corrected as a part of resuscitation, and then operative control of hemorrhage & contamination is performed:

  • Consumptive coagulopathy leads to death in severely injured patients.
  • Coagulopathy occurs as a part of the lethal triad of death which will not resolve without surgical intervention and control of the bleed.
  • Waiting for surgical intervention increases the risk of mortality.

Option D - If hemodynamic stability is achieved, conservative management is enough for this patient:

  • The patient is progressively becoming hemodynamically unstable.
  • Conservative management is not indicated at this stage.
  • The patient will not survive unless damage control surgery is performed.

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly describes a characteristic difference between male and female skeletons?

choices.text: The male pelvis has a wider and greater sciatic notch than the female pelvis.
The female skull has a more prominent glabella and zygomatic arch compared to the male skull.
The male mandible is more obtuse compared to the female mandible.
The female sacrum is shorter and broader, while the male sacrum is longer and narrower

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - The female sacrum is shorter and broader, while the male sacrum is longer and narrower:

  • The female sacrum is shorter and broader, which facilitates childbirth. The male sacrum is longer and narrower.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - The male pelvis has a wider and greater sciatic notch than the female pelvis:

  • The male pelvis is typically narrower and deeper, with a heart-shaped pelvic inlet, while the female pelvis is broader and shallower, with a round or oval pelvic inlet.

Option B - The female skull has a more prominent glabella and zygomatic arch compared to the male skull:

  • The male skull has a more prominent glabella and zygomatic arch, while these features are less prominent in the female skull.

Option C - The male mandible is more obtuse compared to the female mandible:

  • The male mandible is less obtuse, while the female mandible is more obtuse.

questions.text: A 39-year-old female comes to the emergency department experiencing weakness in the upper bilateral extremities, and diffuse abdominal pain for the past two days. Examination shows bilateral loss of the biceps and triceps tendon reflexes. Lab analysis shows elevated levels of porphobilinogen and aminolevulinic acid in the blood. Which of the following is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Acute intermittent porphyria:

  • Autosomal dominant disorder with low penetrance due to deficiency of porphobilinogen deaminase (PBGD), encoded by PBGD gene.
  • Manifestations include acute diffuse abdominal pain (most common), CNS symptoms (hallucinations, psychosis), peripheral neuropathy (proximal upper limb weakness), and red-tinged urine that darkens upon exposure to air or light.
  • Laboratory findings: Elevated porphobilinogen and aminolevulinic acid, hyponatremia, elevated liver function tests.
  • Treatment: Hemin (inhibits first enzyme in heme synthesis) and glucose.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Porphyria cutanea tarda:

  • This condition is caused by a defect in UPG-decarboxylase.
  • It manifests with red-brown or tea-colored urine and skin lesions due to sun exposure. Limb weakness and abdominal symptoms are typically not found in this condition.

Option B - Lead poisoning:

  • Inhibits heme synthesis enzymes like Ferrochelatase and Aminolevulinate dehydratase.
  • Presents with microcytic sideroblastic anemia with ringed sideroblasts.
  • Unlike AIP, lead poisoning doesn't cause red-tinged urine or CNS symptoms.

Option C - Ischemic stroke  :

  • Presents with sudden limb weakness, confusion, but not acute abdominal pain.
  • Unlikely in this patient without risk factors like hypertension or diabetes.
  • Acute mesenteric ischemia would be less likely without relevant risk factors.

questions.text: Which one of the following enzymes synthesizes the Okazaki fragments?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - DNA polymerase III:

  • The most important enzymes responsible for DNA replication are DNA polymerases.
  • DNA polymerase III synthesizes Okazaki fragments during DNA replication.
  • It adds nucleotides to the 3' end of the primer strand.
  • DNA polymerase III synthesizes both the leading and lagging strands of DNA.
  • Okazaki fragments are formed on the lagging strand in a discontinuous manner.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - DNA Polymerase I:

  • Removes RNA primers after DNA polymerase III completes Okazaki and leading strand synthesis and fills gaps in the daughter strand after the removal of RNA primer

Option B - DNA Polymerase II:

  • It is used for proofreading DNA and repair of DNA.

Option D - RNA Polymerase I :

  • Not involved in DNA replication, functions in transcription.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male is diagnosed with vestibular schwannoma expanding into the cerebellopontine angle. A sitting craniotomy under general anesthesia is planned. The most sensitive technique to detect venous air embolism during the intraoperative period in this patient is?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - TEE:

  • The combination of precordial doppler and expired CO2 monitoring has high sensitivity and specificity, rapid response, and quantitatively measures the venous air embolism (VAE) event and indicates the course of recovery from the VAE event, which is in current practice.
  • Transesophageal Echocardiography (TEE) is more sensitive than precordial doppler, which offers the advantage of identifying the right-to-left shunting of air.
  • Expired nitrogen analysis is theoretically attractive and has less sensitivity.
  • For air embolism diagnosis, the most sensitive monitor is TEE, doppler ultrasonography, capnography, ECG, and SpO2.
  • Following are the stages of VAE based on the results of TEE.
Stage TEE
0 No emboli in RA, RV and RVOT
I Single gas bubbles in RA, RV and RVOT
II Gas emboli filling less than half the diameter of RA, RV and RVOT
III Gas emboli filling more than half the diameter of RA, RV and RVOT
IV Gas emboli completely filling the diameter of RA, RV and RVOT

Incorrect Options:

Option A - ECG:

  • ECG is not a sensitive technique to detect VAE. The most preferred one is TEE in terms of sensitivity.

Option C - BIS:

  • The bispectral index monitor processes electroencephalographic signals to obtain a value that reflects the patient's level of consciousness.
  • The bispectral index (BIS) monitor collects raw EEG data through its sensors and uses an algorithm to analyse and interpret the data.
  • BIS does not monoitor VAE.

Option D - Doppler:

  • Precordial is the most sensitive non-invasive technique. However, TEE is invasive but more sensitive than precordial doppler.

questions.text: In a community with a prevalence of trachoma follicles greater than 10%, which of the following interventions would be the most appropriate according to the SAFE strategy?

choices.text: Follow facial hygiene and environmental cleanliness

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Trichiasis surgery:

  • The SAFE strategy, implemented by the WHO, aims to control trachoma in communities.
  • The criteria for implementing the SAFE strategy depend on the prevalence of trachoma follicles in the community.
  • If the prevalence of trachoma follicles is greater than 10%, follow the SAFE strategy. If it is between 5-10 %, follow only the FE strategy.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of an immune complex-mediated hypersensitivity reaction?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Arthus reaction:

  • Deposition of circulating immune complexes occurs in type III hypersensitivity.
  • The antigen-antibody (mostly IgG) complexes activates complement, which attracts neutrophils; neutrophils release lysosomal enzymes.
  • It can be associated with vasculitis and systemic manifestations.
  • Arthus reaction is a local subacute immune complex-mediated hypersensitivity reaction. Intradermal injection of antigen into a pre-sensitized (has circulating IgG) individual leads to the immune complex formation in the skin (e.g., enhanced local reaction to a booster vaccination).
  • Serum sickness is the prototypic immune complex disease. Antibodies to foreign proteins are produced and 1–2 weeks later, antibody-antigen complexes form and deposit in tissues, complement activation inflammation and tissue damage (serum C3, C4).

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Asthma:

  • Asthma is a classic example of a type I hypersensitivity reaction.
  • IgE are already produced and fixed to mast cells- mast cell degranulation causes the release of mediators.
  • This leads to the later recruitment of inflammatory cells.
  • Resulting in vascular dilation, oedema, smooth muscle contraction, mucus production, tissue injury, and inflammation.
  • Examples are anaphylaxis; allergies; bronchial asthma (atopic forms)

Option C - Contact dermatitis:

  • Contact dermatitis is an example of a cell-mediated (type IV) hypersensitivity reaction.
  • Two mechanisms, each involving T cells:
    1. Direct cell cytotoxicity: CD8+ cytotoxic T cells kill targeted cells.
    2. Inflammatory reaction: effector CD4+
  • T cells recognize antigens and release inflammation-inducing cytokines.
  • The response does not involve antibodies (vs types I, II, and III).
  • Examples are contact dermatitis (e.g., poison ivy, nickel allergy) & graft-versus-host disease.
  • This principle is used in clinical tests such as purified protein derivatives for tuberculosis infection, patch tests for contact dermatitis & candida skin test for T cell immune function.

Option D - Rheumatic fever:

  • Rheumatic fever is an example of type II hypersensitivity.
  • IgG hypersensitivity reaction is a type II hypersensitivity reaction.
  • Antibodies to the M protein of group A streptococcus cross-react with self-antigens, and cross-react with myocardial antigen, due to molecular mimicry.
  • Antibodies bind to cell-surface antigens or extracellular matrix and causecellular destruction, inflammation, and cellular dysfunction.
  • Cellular destruction occurs when a cell is opsonized (coated) by antibodies, leading to either phagocytosis and/or activation of the complement system & natural cell killing (antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity).
  • Examples are autoimmune hemolytic anaemia (including drug-induced form), immune thrombocytopenia, transfusion reactions & hemolytic disease of the newborn.
  • Inflammation is mediated by the binding of antibodies to cell surfaces, activation of the complement system, and Fc receptor-mediated inflammation.
  • Examples are Goodpasture syndrome, rheumatic fever & hyperacute transplant rejection.
  • Cellular dysfunction by antibodies binds to cell-surface receptors, abnormal blockade or activation of the downstream process.
  • Examples are myasthenia gravis, graves disease & pemphigus Vulgaris.

questions.text: For the calculation of the positive predictive value of the screening test, the denominator is comprised of:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - True positive + False positive:

  • The positive predictive value (PPV) is the probability that individuals with a positive screening test truly have the disease.
  • It is calculated by dividing the number of true positive results by the sum of true positive and false positive results.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B and D as explained above.

questions.text: Which of the following changes in kinetic parameters is associated with a non-competitive inhibitor?

choices.text: Increase in both Km and Vmax

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Decrease in Vmax:

Non-competitive inhibition

  • Non-competitive inhibitors bind to an enzyme's regulatory site, inducing a change in its configuration, preventing substrate binding and reaction.
  • Increasing substrate concentration does not overcome non-competitive inhibition, leading to decreased apparent Vmax.
  • However, Km remains unchanged, as non-competitive inhibitors do not interfere with substrate binding at the active site.
  • The effect is depicted graphically by a curve with unchanged Km but reduced Vmax.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D: Refer to the explanation of option A.

questions.text: At what age, the child can follow rapidly moving objects?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 1 year:

  • 1 year: Follows rapidly moving objects

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 3 months:

  • Fixates instantaneously on an object shown to him (grasps with eyes)
  • Can follow the red dangling ring to 180 degrees

Option B - 4 months:

  • Binocular vision: Begins to develop by 6 weeks and established by 4 months of age

Option C - 1 month:

  • 4 weeks: Can follow the red dangling ring to 90 degrees

questions.text:
The following are the various signs found in the X-rays of patients with Paget’s disease of the bone. Pair them appropriately.:


	
		
			
			1)

			
			
			
			a) Osteoporosis Circumscripta
			
		
		
			
			2)

			
			
			
			b) Picture Frame Sign
			
		
		
			
			3)

			
			
			
			c) Flame Sign
			
		
		
			
			 
			
			
			d) Codfish Sign
			
		
		
			
			 
			
			
			e) Subperiosteal Hemorrhages
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 1-b, 2-c, 3-a:

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 1-d, 2-e, 3-a

Option B - 1-c, 2-b, 3-e

Option D - 1-d, 2-e, 3-c

  • Codfish vertebrae and subperiosteal hemorrhages are not seen in Paget’s disease.

questions.text: A child was brought to the clinic by his father complaining of fever along with a rash that began on the first day of fever. On examination, the rash is pleomorphic. The doctor explained to the interns that it is caused by a DNA virus from the Herpesviridae family and the incubation period is 10-12 days. Which among the following is not a complication of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Otitis media:

  • The condition that is described in the question is Chickenpox
  • It is caused by Varicella zoster virus
  • Otitis media is not a complication of this disease

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Stroke

Option B - Transverse myelitis

Option C - Optic neuritis

  • These are the complications of Chickenpox

questions.text: In a clinical scenario, a pregnant woman at 32 weeks of gestation is expecting monochorionic twins. Upon evaluation, it is noted that one twin is experiencing anemia, while the other demonstrates polycythemia.There is no differences in weight or amniotic fluid levels between them. What specific diagnosis is associated with this unique presentation in the patient's case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Twin Anemia Polycythemia Sequence (TAPS):

  • TAPS is a rare condition in monochorionic twins where there is a significant difference in hemoglobin levels between the twins. It is characterized by anemia in one twin (donor) and polycythemia in the other twin (recipient).
  • Diagnosis of TAPS is made on fetal Doppler when the donor twin has MCA PSV of > 1.5 MoM, while the recipient twin has MCA

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Twin-to-twin Transfusion Syndrome (TTTS):

  • TTTS is a condition in which there is an imbalance in blood flow between the fetuses sharing the same placenta (monochorionic twins). It results in one twin (donor) giving more blood to the other twin (recipient), leading to volume overload and other complications.

Option C - Monochorionic Monoamniotic (MCMA):

  • MCMA twins share the same chorionic sac and amniotic sac. This condition is associated with higher risks, including cord entanglement and compression.

Option D - Discordant Growth Syndrome (DGS):

  • Discordant Growth Syndrome refers to a situation where one twin is growing at a significantly different rate than the other twin. This can be due to various factors such as differences in placental function.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman presents with complaints of primary amenorrhea. Her height is 153 cm, weight is 51 kg. She has well-developed breasts. She has no pubic or axillary hair and no hirsutism. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option C: Complete androgen insensitivity syndrome.

  • Complete androgen insensitivity syndrome is a condition where a genetic male (XY chromosomes) is resistant to the effects of androgens, resulting in the female external genitalia and lack of pubic or axillary hair. These individuals have well-developed breasts due to the presence of estrogen receptors. However, they do not have a uterus or ovaries, leading to primary amenorrhea.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Turner syndrome 

  • It is characterized by the complete or partial absence of the X chromosome in females. Typical features include short stature, lack of secondary sexual characteristics (such as breast development), and primary amenorrhea. However, women with Turner syndrome do not have well-developed breasts.

Option B: Stein-Leventhal syndrome

  • Also known as polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), is characterized by ovarian cysts, irregular menstrual cycles, and often features such as hirsutism (excessive hair growth) and obesity. The patient in question does not exhibit signs of hirsutism or obesity.

Option C: Premature ovarian failure 

  • It refers to the loss of ovarian function before the age of 40. It can lead to primary or secondary amenorrhea. While this is a possibility, the absence of pubic or axillary hair and well-developed breasts in the given patient suggests an androgen insensitivity syndrome rather than premature ovarian failure.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH)?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 21-hydroxylase deficiency:

  • 21-hydroxylase deficiency is the most common cause of CAH, accounting for about 95% of cases. It leads to decreased mineralocorticoid production, with subsequent excess androgen production causing ambiguous genitalia in females and precocious puberty in males.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and D are not the most common causes of congenital adrenal hyperplasia.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old male presents to the ENT clinic with a history of recurrent, unilateral nasal obstruction and episodes of profuse epistaxis over the past several months. On examination, the following is observed:



What sign is likely to be seen on this patient's CECT scan due to erosion of the wedge of the pterygoid?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Chopstick sign:

  • The given clinical presentation is consistent with the diagnosis of JNAF. The Chopstick sign is seen in JNAF and refers to the appearance of the medial and lateral pterygoid plates resembling separate chopsticks due to erosion of the pterygoid wedge by the tumor.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Holman-Miller sign: This sign refers to the anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus seen in patients of JNAF.

Option B - Hondusa's sign: This sign refers to an increase in distance between the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus and the mandible on a CT scan seen in a patient of JNAF.

Option D - Phelp sign: This sign is seen in glomus tumors and occurs due to erosion of the carotico-jugular spine bone.

questions.text: Which of the following muscle relaxants is most likely to cause malignant hyperthermia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Succinylcholine:

  • Succinylcholine is a muscle relaxant used in anesthesia, particularly for rapid sequence intubation or to facilitate quick muscle relaxation during surgery
  • Malignant hyperthermia is a rare but potentially life-threatening condition triggered by certain drugs, including succinylcholine and inhalational anesthetics like halothane. It is characterized by a rapid rise in body temperature, muscle rigidity, and potentially severe metabolic disturbances.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Doxacurium: Doxacurium is a non-depolarizing muscle relaxant and is not associated with malignant hyperthermia. It acts by competitively blocking acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction.

Option B - Vecuronium: Vecuronium is a non-depolarizing muscle relaxant that does not trigger malignant hyperthermia. It is widely used in anesthesia for its intermediate duration of action and lack of significant side effects related to malignant hyperthermia.

Option C - Rocuronium: Rocuronium is another non-depolarizing muscle relaxant and does not cause malignant hyperthermia. It is commonly used in anesthesia induction and maintenance due to its rapid onset and intermediate duration of action.

questions.text: Wearing clothes of the opposite sex is known as:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Transvestism:

  • Transvestism refers to the practice of wearing clothes traditionally associated with the opposite sex.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Scoptophilia: Scoptophilia, also known as voyeurism, is a condition where a person derives sexual pleasure from watching others without their knowledge or consent, especially in private or intimate situations.

Option C - Somnophilia: Somnophilia is a condition where a person is sexually aroused by a stranger who is asleep.

Option D - Exhibitionism: Exhibitionism involves the act of exposing one's genitals, usually in public, for sexual gratification. It involves streaking, mooning, and flashing.

questions.text: The given condition/findings are most commonly seen due to which deficiency?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Riboflavin Deficiency:

  • Angular stomatitis and Circumcorneal congestion is most commonly associated with a deficiency in riboflavin (vitamin B2), which is essential for maintaining healthy skin and mucous membranes.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Niacin Deficiency: Niacin, also known as vitamin B3, deficiency leads to pellagra, which is characterized by dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. Angular stomatitis is not a hallmark of niacin deficiency but rather a broader symptom of malnutrition that could co-occur with other deficiencies.

Option C - Thiamine Deficiency: Thiamine, or vitamin B1, deficiency leads to beriberi and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, primarily affecting the nervous system and cardiovascular system. Angular stomatitis is not typically associated with thiamine deficiency.

Option D - Folate Deficiency: Folate deficiency primarily leads to megaloblastic anemia and can cause symptoms such as fatigue, weakness, and glossitis. While it can affect mucosal surfaces, angular stomatitis is not a prominent feature.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding Hurler's syndrome, in contrast to Hunter's syndrome?

choices.text: The enzyme defect is iduronate sulphatase.

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Corneal clouding is seen:

  • Hunter's syndrome (Mucopolysaccharidosis II) results in coreal clouding and inguinal hernial.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - The enzyme defect is iduronate sulphatase.:

  • The enzyme defect in Hurler's syndrome is iduronate sulphatase.

  • The enzyme defect in Hurler's syndrome is L-iduronidase, not iduronate sulphatase. Iduronate sulphatase deficiency is associated with Hunter's syndrome (Mucopolysaccharidosis II).

Option B - Relatively milder in severity:

  • Hurler's syndrome is generally milder in severity compared to Hunter's syndrome.

  • Hurler's syndrome is usually more severe compared to Hunter's syndrome, which is considered relatively mild.

Option C - X linked recessive inheritance:

  • Hurler's syndrome is as Autosomal Recessive disease.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman complains of neck pain and swelling along with difficulty swallowing and speaking. On examination, bilateral swelling in the floor of the mouth is noted. Which of the following is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Nasal fiberoptic intubation:

  • The patient likely has Ludwig's Angina, a potentially life-threatening condition characterized by rapidly progressing bilateral submandibular space infection leading to airway compromise. Nasal fiberoptic intubation is preferred in cases of Ludwig's Angina due to potential difficulties with oral intubation caused by swelling.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Intravenous antibiotics: Systemic antibiotics are a part of the management of Ludwig's Angina, but securing the airway takes precedence.

Option B - External incision and drainage: External drainage is done if the infection involves submaxillary space, but securing the airway is the immediate priority.

Option C - Intraoral incision and drainage: Intraoral drainage is done if the infection is localized to the sublingual space, but securing the airway is the immediate priority.

questions.text: What's the likelihood of malignancy in a 32-year-old male with bleeding per rectum, a family history of colon cancer (father and brother affected), and numerous polyps seen on colonoscopy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 100%:

  • Colorectal cancer develops in 100% of untreated FAP patients, often before age 30.

Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP)

  • Autosomal dominant

  • Numerous colorectal adenomas by teenage years.

  • Mutation of adenomatous polyposis coli gene (APC).

  • At least 100 polyps are necessary for the diagnosis of classic FAP,

  • High risk of causing colorectal cancer,

  • Prophylactic colectomy is standard therapy

INCORRECT OPTIONS: 

Options B, C and D are incorrect and the correct option is explained above.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents to the clinic with swelling behind the ears. The child developed a rash 10 days ago on the face and spread to the trunk and extremities. On examination, you notice occipital and postauricular lymphadenopathy. The child's mother mentions that he had a mild fever since yesterday. The pediatrician suspects a viral illness. Which of the following is the secondary attack rate of this illness?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 80%:

  • The child likely has rubella, caused by the rubella virus. Symptoms include a 3-day maculopapular rash, often accompanied by fever, malaise, upper respiratory symptoms, and lymphadenopathy, particularly in the second week after exposure. Subclinical cases or those without a rash are also common.
  • The secondary attack rate (SAR) refers to the proportion of susceptible individuals who develop a specific disease after being exposed to a primary case within a defined period.
  • The SAR for rubella is 80%.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, D:

  • These are not the secondary attack rates for rubella.

questions.text: A known case of papillary carcinoma of the right breast had come to your hospital for surgery. A modified radical mastectomy procedure was done, and on the 2nd postoperative day, the patient presents with the following finding, as shown in the figure below. Which nerve would have been damaged during the operative procedure?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - The long thoracic nerve of Bell:

  • The finding in the image given above is winging of the scapula.
  • Winging of the scapula may be seen after mastectomy due to long thoracic nerve injury.
    • Innervates serratus anterior - It fixes the scapula to the chest wall during shoulder adduction and arm extension.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Musculocutaneous nerve:

  • Its injury can cause weakness in the elbow or shoulder flexion, atrophy of the biceps brachii, and pain or paresthesia at the lateral forearm.

Option C - Intercostobrachial nerve:

  • Injury to this nerve results in cutaneous anesthesia in these areas.

Option D - Thoracodorsal nerve:

  • Injury can cause weakness of internal rotation and abduction of the shoulder.

questions.text: A study is conducted to assess the contraceptive efficacy of a new method among women aged 18-35 years in a rural community. The researchers followed up with the participants for  2.5 years. During this period, there were 23 accidental pregnancies recorded among 390 women who used the new method. Which among the following is the correct representation of the Pearl Index?

choices.text: Pearl index = No. of accidental pregnancies / Total months of exposure × 1200
Pearl index = No. of accidental pregnancies / Total years of exposure × 1200
Pearl index = No. of accidental pregnancies / Total months of exposure × 1400
Pearl index = No. of accidental pregnancies / Total years of exposure × 1400

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Pearl index = No. of accidental pregnancies / Total months of exposure × 1200:

  • This is the correct representation of the Pearl Index.
  • The Pearl Index is a measure of contraceptive efficacy that indicates the number of pregnancies that occur per 100 woman-years of exposure while using a particular contraceptive method.
  • It is often used to compare the effectiveness of different contraceptive methods.
  • It is the most commonly used technique to evaluate the effectiveness of contraceptives.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, D: These formulae are inaccurate regarding the Pearl index.

questions.text: Which nerve fiber type conveys dull aching and throbbing sensations in suspected varicose ulcer-related chronic pain?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C – C-fibers:

  • C-fibers are unmyelinated nerve fibers. C-fibers are primarily responsible for transmitting slow, chronic pain sensations, including the dull aching, and throbbing pain often associated with conditions like varicose ulcers.

Incorrect Options:
Option A - A-delta fibers: A-delta fibers are myelinated nerve fibers. They are responsible for transmitting fast, sharp, acute pain signals. Typically associated with quick, well-localized pain responses.

Option B – B-fibers: B-fibers are myelinated fibers. They are involved in the autonomic nervous system and are not typically associated with pain transmission.

Option D – A-alpha fibers: A-alpha fibers are large-diameter, myelinated fibers. They are primarily involved in motor functions, transmitting signals to skeletal muscles. Not typically associated with pain transmission.

questions.text: A chain of private clinics has initiated a new screening program for a noncommunicable disease. To screen for this disease, sequential testing is done. The test I has a sensitivity of 95% and a specificity of 87%. Test II has a sensitivity of 90% and a specificity of 98%. What happens to these parameters when Test I and Test II are performed in series?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Increased specificity and decreased sensitivity:

  • In sequential testing or series testing, the individual is first subjected to one test. If the first returns positive, then he/she is subjected to the second test.
  • When two tests are used in series, sensitivity decreases while specificity increases compared to using each test individually.
  • In this scenario, Test I, which has higher sensitivity but lower specificity, is followed by Test II, which has higher specificity but lower sensitivity.
  • Test I (high sensitivity test) is used for screening, and if this test is positive, Test II (high specificity test) is used for confirmation.
  • As a result, the combined effect is decreased sensitivity but increased specificity.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and C:

  • These are not the changes seen in parameters when two tests are performed in series.

questions.text: NIKSHAY is an online software for reporting and compliance with treatment. In an area endemic to tuberculosis, this software is being utilized along with other control measures. Several ASHA workers are newly recruited and provided with appropriate training. Among the following options, which one is not part of active case detection of TB?

choices.text: ASHA workers receive an incentive of Rs.100 for notification if the suspect referred is diagnosed to be TB patient by MO
Any community member helping identify presumptive TB cases gets an incentive of Rs. 500
Dwellers, prisoners, difficult-to-reach populations, occupational exposure-silicosis, migrants, tribals, shelter homes, and PLHIV are the vulnerable groups
ASHA workers get Rs. 10 per form filled

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - ASHA workers get Rs.10 per form filled:

  • While ASHA workers are crucial in active case detection, the incentive structure mentioned in this option does not directly contribute to identifying presumptive TB cases.
  • Instead, it focuses on providing an incentive for filling out forms.
  • While documentation is essential for monitoring and reporting purposes, the primary objective of active case detection is to identify potential TB cases in the community.
  • Therefore, this option is not a part of active case detection of TB.
  • It is a part of community-based screening of tuberculosis.

Nikshay

  • It is an online software, for reporting & compliance with treatment.
  • HMIS (Health Management Information System) for TB patients.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - ASHA workers receive an incentive of Rs.100 for notification if the suspect referred is diagnosed to be TB patient by MO

  • ASHA workers play a crucial role in active case detection of TB.
  • They are incentivized to find presumptive cases to encourage their active participation in the program.
  • Offering an incentive of Rs. 100 motivates them to search for potential TB cases in the community actively.
  • Therefore, this option is a part of active case detection of TB.

Option B - Any community member helping identify presumptive TB cases gets an incentive of Rs. 500:

  • Engaging the entire community in identifying presumptive TB cases is an effective strategy to increase case detection.
  • Offering an incentive of Rs. 500 to any community member who helps in identifying presumptive TB cases promotes community involvement and aids in early detection.
  • Hence, this option is also a part of active case detection of TB.

Option C - Dwellers, prisoners, difficult-to-reach populations, occupational exposure-silicosis, migrants, tribals, shelter homes, and PLHIV are the vulnerable groups:

  • This option lists various vulnerable groups and populations who are at higher risk of TB infection or have difficulty accessing healthcare services.
  • Active case detection programs often prioritize these groups for targeted screening and case-finding efforts.
  • Including these groups in the active case detection strategy aligns with the goal of reaching all potentially affected populations, thus making this option a part of active case detection of TB.

questions.text: Which of the following translocations is associated with Burkitt lymphoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - t(8;14):

  • The likely translocation seen in patients with Burkitt lymphoma is t(8;14).
  • Burkitt lymphoma is an aggressive B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma most common in children and young adults, which has two types endemic and sporadic.
  • The endemic (African) form is characterized by the involvement of the face, especially the maxilla or mandible and is associated with EBV.
  • The sporadic (Western) form usually involves the abdominal organs such as the ileocecum and peritoneum.
  • The tumor cells are mature B cells that express surface IgM, CD19, CD20, CD10, and BCL6, a phenotype consistent with a germinal centre B-cell origin.
  • All forms of Burkitt lymphoma are associated with translocations of the MYC gene on chromosome 8.
  • MYC translocation partner is usually IGH locus [t(8;14)], but may also be Ig κ [t(2;8)] or Ig λ [t(8;22)] light chain loci.
  • In Burkitt lymphoma, involved tissues are effaced by a diffuse infiltrate of intermediate-sized lymphoid cells. Cells have a high mitotic index; numerous apoptotic cells are observed. The apoptotic remnants are phagocytosed by many tingible body macrophages, which have abundant clear cytoplasm scattered in between tumor cells giving rise to a 'starry-sky' pattern.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - t(15;17):

  • This translocation is associated with acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL), which typically presents with features such as bleeding tendencies, coagulopathy, and bone marrow involvement.

Option B - t(14;18):

  • This translocation is associated with follicular lymphoma, a low-grade B-cell lymphoma characterized by painless lymphadenopathy and bone marrow involvement.

Option D - t(11;14):

  • This translocation is associated with mantle cell lymphoma, which typically presents with lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, and bone marrow involvement.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presented to the emergency department. He has flat white patches in his oral cavity and unusual bleeding in the mouth. A biopsy is done, and end-stage oral cavity cancer is diagnosed. Which of the following is one of the biggest risk factors for developing oral cavity cancer?
questions.solution:
Option C: Human papillomavirus (HPV) infection

  • A group of >150 viruses commonly cause skin diseases, including anogenital warts (e.g., condylomata acuminata), common warts (verruca vulgaris), and oral warts.
  • Also implicated in the pathogenesis of some types of cancer (e.g., cervical cancer and oropharyngeal cancer).
  • HPV infection, particularly HPV 16, 18, 31, and 33, is an important risk factor for developing oral cavity cancer. However, HPV-positive tumors have a good prognosis since they respond better to chemo- and radiotherapy.
  • Risk factors for the development of oral cavity cancer include:
    • Oral tobacco consumption (e.g., snuff, pan/betel quid), smoking.
    • Long-term alcohol consumption.
    • Poor oral hygiene, and chronic mechanical irritation (e.g., badly positioned dentures).
    • Human papillomavirus, particularly HPV 16, 18, 31, and 33.​​​​​​​
    • Presence of precancerous lesions: leukoplakia, erythroplakia, erythroleukoplakia.

Option A: Age

  • Age is not a risk factor for the development of oral cavity cancer.

Option B: High blood cholesterol

  • High blood cholesterol is not a risk factor for the development of oral cavity cancer. It leads to the development of other cardiovascular disorders.

Option D: Lack of sleep

  • Lack of sleep does not lead to the development of oral cavity cancer. However, it leads to the development of mood disorders and increased risk of suicide, workplace injuries, and reduced quality of life.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman in the 12th week of pregnancy presents to the antenatal clinic with occasional shortness of breath and a desire to breathe deeper. There is no associated symptom, and vital parameters are normal. On general physical examination, the chest auscultation shows normal air entry. Which of the following is the best explanation for such a presentation?

choices.text: Increased residual volume and respiratory rate
Increased respiratory rate and vital capacity
Increased minute ventilation and decreased residual volume
Decreased vital capacity and minute ventilation

questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option C: Increased minute ventilation and decreased residual volume

  • A high level of progesterone during pregnancy increases the minute ventilation by about 40% due to increased chemo-reflex to carbon dioxide at the central level
  • The diaphragm moves upward, reducing the residual volume by about 20%
  • Both of these conditions cause hyperventilation and dyspnea during pregnancy
  • The diaphragm moves upward by around 4cm
  • The subcostal angle increases from 68º to 104º.
  • Transverse diameter of chest expands by 2 cm

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Increased residual volume and respiratory rate

  • Residual volume tends to decrease in pregnancy, not increase.
  • Respiratory rate may increase slightly, but increased residual volume is not a contributing factor.

Option B: Increased respiratory rate and vital capacity

  • Increased respiratory rate is a normal adaptation in pregnancy.
  • Vital capacity tends to increase, not decrease.

Option D: Decreased vital capacity and minute ventilation

  • Vital capacity tends to increase during pregnancy.
  • Minute ventilation increases, and there is no decrease in vital capacity.

questions.text: A 38-year-old truck driver, known to be HIV-positive, presents with shortness of breath accompanied by the use of accessory muscles of respiration, fever, and a nonproductive cough. Chest x-ray is given below which of the following is the investigation of choice for this condition.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Bronchoalveolar Lavage (BAL):
