  • This is the investigation of choice in patients with suspected opportunistic infections or diffuse pulmonary infiltrates. It allows for direct sampling of the lower respiratory tract for microbiological and cytological analysis, aiding in the diagnosis of infectious causes or malignancies.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Sputum Culture: While sputum culture can be useful, especially in productive coughs, it may not provide as comprehensive information as BAL in this case, where a nonproductive cough is noted, and invasive fungal infections are suspected.

Option C - Real-time PCR cannot distinguish colonization of the airways. Thus, it cannot differentiate whether it is infection or colonization.

Option D - Immunofluorescence assay: Immunofluorescence assay can be done with BAL specimen to identify the infection

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents to the neurology clinic with progressive weakness and muscle atrophy in his limbs. He reports difficulty in performing daily activities such as walking and lifting objects. Upon examination, the patient exhibits muscle fasciculations and hyperreflexia. All are the factors contributing to the pathology of this condition except?
questions.solution:
Correct option D - Increased Methionine levels:

  • Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder characterized by the degeneration of upper and lower motor neurons, leading to muscle weakness, atrophy, and eventual paralysis.
  • Several factors contribute to the pathology of ALS:
    • Defective protein degradation in neurons:
    • Defective RNA processing
    • In ALS, dysfunctional glutamate handling mechanisms, such as impaired glutamate uptake by astrocytes and downregulation of glutamate transporters like EAAT2 (excitatory amino acid transporter 2), lead to increased extracellular glutamate levels.
    • Excessive glutamate accumulation overactivates glutamate receptors, triggering calcium influx and subsequent neuronal injury.
    • Excitotoxicity contributes to motor neuron degeneration in ALS and is implicated in disease pathogenesis.
  • There is no increase in the level of Methionine in the pathology of Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, C:

  • These are the factors associated with the pathology of Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presents with complaints of double vision and drooping of the right eyelids. On examination, there is limited adduction, and elevation, along with ptosis and dilation of the pupil. Which of the following conditions is most likely causing these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Third nerve palsy:

  • This patient's presentation is consistent with a third nerve palsy. The third cranial nerve (oculomotor nerve) innervates several eye muscles responsible for eye movements, including the medial rectus, superior rectus, inferior rectus, and inferior oblique muscles. Dysfunction of the third cranial nerve can result in limited eye movements, causing double vision (diplopia). The affected eye may also exhibit ptosis (drooping of the eyelid) due to the involvement of the levator palpebrae superioris muscle. Moreover, the pupil dilation (mydriasis) seen in this patient is due to the involvement of the parasympathetic fibers that control pupillary constriction (miosis).

Incorrect Options:

Option A - fourth nerve palsy: Superior oblique palsy, would present with vertical diplopia that worsens when looking downward and tilting the head toward the affected side. It typically does not cause ptosis or pupillary abnormalities.

Option B - Sixth nerve palsy: Abducens nerve palsy, would result in limited lateral gaze of the affected eye there will be defective or no abduction, leading to horizontal diplopia. It does not affect the levator palpebrae muscle or pupillary function.

Option D - Myasthenia gravis: It is an autoimmune neuromuscular disorder that can cause fluctuating weakness of the eye muscles and other skeletal muscles. While it may present with diplopia and ptosis, it does not usually cause pupillary abnormalities.

questions.text: During a mass casualty incident in a densely populated area, a triage system is implemented to manage the influx of patients effectively. Which among the following is not a feature of blue color coding in the triage system of disaster management?

choices.text: Victims must be helped within 0 to 6 hours
Victims must be helped within 6 to 24 hours
They can wait up to 24 hours

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Victims must be helped within 0 to 6 hours:

  • Blue indicates patients with minor injuries who can wait longer for medical care.
  • Patients in the blue color code:
    • They are of medium priority (option A)
    • Victims must be attended to within 6-24 hours but can wait up to 24 hours. (option C and D)

Option B is, therefore, not a characteristic of the blue color code in triaging.


Incorrect Options: 
Option A - Medium priority: 

Option C - Victims must be helped within 6 TO 24 hours:

Option D - They can wait up to 24 hours

  • These all are correct statements.

questions.text: What is the drug of choice in the treatment of Narcolepsy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Modafinil:

  • Modafinil is an indirectly acting adrenergic drug. They increase the release of catecholamines.
  • It decreases sleep.
  • It is DOC for Daytime sleepiness.
    • Occurs in Narcolepsy
    • Occurs in OSA (obstructive sleep apnea)
      • Apnea due to excess fat around the neck compressing the respiratory tract.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Tiprolisant:

  • Pitolisant is the other name of Tiprolisant
  • It is Histamine (H3) inverse agonist.
  • Cause wakefulness is used for the treatment of Narcolepsy.

Option C - Armodafinil:

  • Armodafinil is enantiomer of modafinil.
  • Used in Obstructive sleep apnea.

Option D - Solriamfetol:

  • It is a new drug approved for Narcolepsy treatment.
  • It increases norepinephrine and dopamine in the brain prevents sleepiness.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male with varicose veins in the lower limbs has developed itching and ulceration around the ankle and calf region for a few days. Which type of ulcer is likely to develop in a long-standing chronic venous ulcer?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Marjolin’s ulcer:

  • Chronic leg ulcers usually develop in varicose veins, venous hypertension, chronic infections, and long-standing vasculitis.
  • Marjolin’s ulcer arises from a long-standing ulcer or burn scar. It is a low-grade squamous cell carcinoma.
  • It destroys nerves and is painless, slow-growing, and radio-resistant.
  • There is no distant metastasis.
  • It is a diagnosis by skin biopsy and treated by wide local excision with flap closure.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Aphthous ulcer:

  • Aphthous ulcer is the most common extraintestinal manifestation of Crohn's disease.
  • It is characterized by an irregular, ulcerated, erythematous area with normal colonic mucosa.

Option C - Pressure sores:

  • Pressure sores are areas of tissue necrosis with ulceration under prolonged pressure along bony prominences
  • Sites of pressure sore are the occiput, sacrum, ischium, and greater trochanter.

Option D - Necrotizing fasciitis:

  • Necrotizing fasciitis is a polymicrobial infection of soft tissues with gram-positive aerobes, gram-negative anaerobes, and beta-hemolytic.
  • It is characterized by pain, edema, crepitus, blistering, fever, and greyish pus.
  • It can lead to shock and multi-organ failure in the advanced stage.
  • Treatment is broad-spectrum antibiotics and surgical excision.

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient presents with blurry vision and a flare in the left eye. Upon examination, you noted mild conjunctival injection, anterior chamber cells, and  keratic precipitates. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Anterior uveitis:

  • In the given scenario, the patient's symptoms of blurry vision and flare, along with the examination findings of mild conjunctival injection, anterior chamber cells, and keratic precipitates, are indicative of anterior uveitis.
  • Anterior uveitis is characterized by inflammation in the anterior chamber of the eye, involving the iris and ciliary body and on examination keratic precipitates (fine and grey in non-granulomatous uveitis), mutton fat KPs (granulomatous uveitis), aqueous cells, aqueous flare, iris nodules, posterior synechiae and sectoral iris atrophy are observed.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Episcleritis: Episcleritis is an inflammation of the episcleral tissue, which is a thin layer located between the conjunctiva (outermost layer) and the sclera (white of the eye). It typically presents with localized redness, discomfort, and occasionally mild irritation. Episcleritis does not usually cause anterior chamber cells and flare, nor does it lead to posterior synechiae.

Option C - Keratitis : Keratitis is inflammation of the cornea, the clear front surface of the eye. While it can cause blurry vision, it is more likely to cause symptoms such as eye pain, photophobia (sensitivity to light), and foreign body sensation. Anterior chamber cells and posterior synechiae are not characteristic features of keratitis.

Option D - Conjunctivitis: Conjunctivitis, also known as pink eye, is inflammation of the conjunctiva, the thin membrane covering the white part of the eye. It typically presents with symptoms of redness, itching, discharge, and mild discomfort. While mild conjunctival injection is mentioned in the scenario, the presence of other findings such as anterior chamber cells, flare, and posterior synechiae suggests involvement beyond the conjunctiva, making conjunctivitis less likely.

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic male presents to the emergency department with complaints of fever, malaise, severe pain, swelling in the genital region, and smell of the affected region. The physical examination shows the blackish discoloration of the scrotal skin, which is described in the image below. There is a gas that can be seen on scrotal ultrasound. Which of the following should be excised during surgery?

choices.text: Skin, subcutaneous tissue and corpora cavernosa
Skin, subcutaneous tissue, corpora cavernosa & testis

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Skin & subcutaneous tissue:

  • The Image shows blackish discoloration of scrotal skin and some part of penile skin: Fournier's gangrene.
  • Aka idiopathic scrotal gangrene.

Fournier's gangrene

  • Fournier's gangrene is a necrotizing fasciitis of the male genitalia and perineum (secondary to infection by aerobic and anaerobic bacteria), affecting predominantly middle-aged and older men with pre-existing comorbidities. It involves the skin and subcutaneous tissues. It is rare for the infection to involve the testicles or deep tissues of the penis because of the tunica vaginalis and  Buck fascia, respectively, so these structures can be preserved. Corpora cavernosa lies under the Buck’s fascia.
  • It is a urological emergency that often presents with swelling, pain, and erythema of the genital region, which may progress to discoloration and frank necrosis accompanied by systemic features such as fever and rigor.
  • The presence of crepitus is virtually diagnostic.
  • It is usually a polymicrobial infection with microaerobes, anaerobes and gram-positive and gram-negative organisms. It spreads along Dartos, Scarpas and Colles' fascia.
  • Risk factors for development include peripheral vascular disease, diabetes mellitus, malnutrition, alcoholism, and other immunocompromised states.
  • Given the potential for rapid spread and tissue destruction, early diagnosis and urgent surgical drainage with aggressive debridement of the necrotic tissue is an essential component of management, along with the broad-spectrum antibiotic cover.
  • It is uncommon for the urethra to be involved, although a defined urinary tract source may be evident such as urethral stricture with perforation and local infection.
  • Mortality is high and related to the level of existing co-morbidity.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Skin:

  • There is necrosis of skin and subcutaneous tissue.
  • Only the excision of skin is not useful for the management, so the subcutaneous tissue should also be excised.

Option C - Skin, subcutaneous tissue, and corpora cavernosa:

  • Fournier's gangrene involves the skin and subcutaneous tissues.
  • It is rare to involve corpora cavernosa so there is no need to excise corpora cavernosa.

Option D - Skin, subcutaneous tissue, corpora cavernosa & testis:

  • It is rare for the infection to involve the testicles or deep tissues of the penis because of the tunica vaginalis and  Buck fascia.
  • So these structures can be preserved.
  • Corpora cavernosa lies under the Buck’s fascia.

questions.text: Which level of the Fisch Classification corresponds to glomus tumor restricted to the tympanomastoid site?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Type B:

  • According to Fisch classification, Type B corresponds to tumors restricted to the tympanomastoid site.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Type A: Tumors restricted to the middle ear (e.g., glomus tympanicum tumor).

Option C- Type C: Tumors involving the infra-labyrinth portion towards the petrous apex.

Option D - Type D2: Tumor with intracranial invasion (>2cm).

questions.text: Which of the following histopathological images corresponds to the findings of Cushing’s disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D:

  • The image given in option D shows Crooke hyaline changes. These changes are seen in the pituitary gland and are caused by Cushing's disease.

Incorrect Options:

Option A:

  • Shows Mallory Denk bodies. They are commonly seen in patients with alcoholic liver disease.

Option B:

  • Shows intracytoplasmic Russel bodies. It is caused by increased antibody production.

Option C:

  • Shows intranuclear Dutcher bodies. It is caused by increased antibody production.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male who is a known case of HTN, DM and heart failure on medications has an ABG analysis. ABG analysis shows pH 7.38, PCO2 of 30mmHg, and HCO3 of 18mEq/L. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Fully Compensated metabolic acidosis:

Normal parameters of ABG-

  • pH-7.35-7.45
  • pO2-60-100
  • pCO2-35-45mmHg
  • HCO3-22-26mEq
  • Anion gap-Na-(Cl+HCO3)
  • Always look for pH ,pCO2 and HCO3 first

 

  • pH: 7.38-normal
  • PCO2 – 30(reduced)
  • HCO3 – 18(reduced)
  • pH is normal hence this either a case of compensated acid-base disorder or a normal ABG
  • If abnormal, the lower end of normal range pH suggests an acidotic disorder
  • PCO2 is reduced. This would not cause acidosis.
  • HCO3 is reduced. Hence this is likley a case of Metabolic Acidosis
  • Since there is reduced CO2, there is compensatory respiratory alkalosis
  • pH has normalised with compensatory respiratory alkalosis
  • Hence this is an ABG of Compensated Metabolic Acidosis

questions.text: A 38-year-old man with a family history of MEN2 presents with an intermittent and severe headache, palpitations, and excessive sweating. A palpable mass is detected in his upper left abdomen during the physical examination and his blood pressure is 180/100 mmHg. What is the investigation of choice for this patient?

choices.text: Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Plasma fractionated metanephrine
level:

  • This clinical scenario is suggestive of a pheochromocytoma, a catecholamine-secreting tumor typically arising from the adrenal medulla. Pheochromocytomas can cause paroxysmal hypertension, severe headaches, palpitations, and sweating. The presence of a palpable mass in the left upper abdomen further supports this diagnosis.
  • Measurement of plasma-free metanephrines is the most sensitive and specific initial test for detecting pheochromocytomas. Plasma-free metanephrines (metanephrine and normetanephrine) are the breakdown products of catecholamines and are elevated in the setting of a pheochromocytoma.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen: It is a valuable imaging modality to localize the tumor once the diagnosis of pheochromocytoma is confirmed. However, it is not the initial investigation of choice.

Option B - A 24-hour urine collection for vanillylmandelic acid (VMA): It is an older test that measures the breakdown product of epinephrine and norepinephrine. Although it can be used in the workup of pheochromocytoma, it is less sensitive and specific compared to plasma-free metanephrines.

Option D - MRI of the abdomen: It can provide detailed anatomical information about the tumor and surrounding structures. However, it is not the initial investigation of choice in this scenario.

questions.text: A 7-week old female infant presented with jaundice and abnormal laboratory findings significant for direct hyperbilirubinemia, transaminitis and elevated alkaline phosphatase and gamma-glutamyl transferase (GGT). The total bilirubin level was 6.4, and the direct bilirubin level was 3.2. The baby was exclusively breastfed and otherwise healthy. Ultrasound was done, which revealed the following finding. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Kasai:

  • The given ultrasound image shows a Triangular cord sign which is seen in Biliary atresia
  • Biliary atresia
    • The extrahepatic bile ducts are progressively destroyed by an inflammatory process that starts around the time of birth. 
    • Intrahepatic changes eventually occur, causing biliary cirrhosis and portal hypertension. Untreated, death from the consequences of liver failure occurs before the age of 3 years.
    • Treatment of choice for biliary atresia: Kasai portoenterostomy 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Billroth I: Billroth I is the gastroduodenal anastomosis; this procedure is performed for gastric ulcers

Option B - Billroth II: Billroth II is the gastrojejunostomy; this procedure is done for refractory peptic ulcers and gastric adenocarcinoma.

Option D - Mayo: Mayo repair is used for umbilical hernia repair

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct about the definition of steroid dependent nephrotic syndrome?

choices.text: Two consecutive relapses when on alternate day steroid therapy
Two or more relapses in the initial 6-month period
More than 3 relapses in any 12 months
Two consecutive relapses within 3 weeks of its discontinuation.

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Two consecutive relapses when on alternate day steroid therapy:

  • Steroid dependent nephrotic syndrome is characterized by Two consecutive relapses when on alternate day steroid therapy or within 14 days of its discontinuation.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Two or more relapses in the initial 6-month period

Option C - More than 3 relapses in any 12 months

B and C are both features of frequent relapse

questions.text: Identify the antigen antibody reaction test given in the image below
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Oudin test and Oakley-Fulthorpe test:

  • The image given in the question os of Oudin test and Oakley-Fulthorpe test
  • It is a precipitation reaction for soluble antigen and antibody

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B & D:

questions.text:
Match the following conditions with their respective types of respiratory failure


	
		
			
			1. ARDS
			
			
			a. Respiratory failure type 2
			
		
		
			
			2. Status asthmaticus
			
			
			b. Respiratory failure type 4
			
		
		
			
			3. Peri-operative atelectasis
			
			
			c. Respiratory failure type 1
			
		
		
			
			4. Cardiogenic shock
			
			
			d. Respiratory failure type 3
questions.solution:
Correct option: C - 1-c, 2-a, 3-d, 4-b

1. ARDS

c. Respiratory failure type 1

2. Status asthmaticus

a. Respiratory failure type 2

3. Peri-operative atelectasis

d. Respiratory failure type 3

4. Cardiogenic shock

b. Respiratory failure type 4

Respiratory Failure

Respiratory Failure

Examples

Management

Type I

ARDS, CHF
  • Low volume ventilation
  • Prone position and neuromuscular blockage

Type II

Status asthmaticus, acute exacerbation of COPD
  • Tight fitting face mask (NIV)
  • ET tube with IPPV - If due to diaphragmatic paralysis

Type III

Peri-operative atelectasis
  • O2 supplementation
  • Chest physiotherapy

Type IV

Decreased perfusion of respiratory muscles
  • ET tube with IPPV

Incorrect options: A, B and D - Refer to the above explanation

questions.text: What characteristic radiological finding is observed in the X-ray of the affected knee joint in a child presenting with joint pain, swelling, and tenderness?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Wimberger's ring:

  • Wimberger's ring is a radiological finding seen in scurvy, a nutritional vitamin C deficiency. It appears as a ring-like radiolucency or hypodensity around the epiphysis of long bones, particularly at the ends of the femur and humerus.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Fraying: This radiological finding is seen in rickets. It refers to irregular margins.

Option B - White line of Frankel: This radiological finding is seen in healing rickets.

Option D - Candle flame sign: This radiological finding is seen in Paget’s disease. It refers to lytic lesions in the femur start in the metaphysis and extend into the diaphysis.

questions.text: Which of the following viruses is an enveloped virus?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Influenza virus:

  • The influenza virus is an enveloped virus in the Orthomyxoviridae family, characterized by its lipid bilayer envelope.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and D are non-enveloped viruses.

questions.text: What marker indicates the site of Bochdalek hernia?
questions.solution:
Option D: D

  • This is a case of Bochdalek hernia.
  • In Bochdalek hernia, the patient typically presents with shortness of breath and decreased breath sound on auscultation at the affected site.
  • Site for Bochdalek hernia (Left postero-lateral) due to deficiency in the pleuroperitoneal membrane.
  • Bochdalek hernia is a defect in the postero-lateral area of the diaphragm.
  • It results in herniation of abdominal viscera into the thorax.
  • It causes mechanical compression on the lung parenchyma, which is under development.
  • Occasionally, it can also cause hypoplasia of the lungs.
  • These symptoms usually manifest in children and tend to be respiratory.
  • Rarely an adult diagnosed with such symptoms

Option A: A

  • Site for eventration of the diaphragm.

Option B: B

  • Site for Morgagni hernia (Right Antero-medial).

Option C: C

  • Esophageal opening at T10 → this opening can cause sliding hiatus hernia.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of cyclosporine?

choices.text: Blockade of tissue responses to inflammatory mediators
Inhibition of gene transcription of interleukins

questions.solution:
Option C: Inhibition of gene transcription of interleukins

  • The main mechanism of action of cyclosporine is the inhibition of the production of cytokines involved in the regulation of T-cell activation. In particular, cyclosporine inhibits the transcription of interleukin 2
  • Cyclosporine forms a complex with cyclophilin, a cytoplasmic-receptor protein present in target cells.
  • This complex binds to calcineurin, inhibiting Ca2+-stimulated dephosphorylation of the cytosolic component of NFAT.
  • When cytoplasmic NFAT is dephosphorylated, it translocates to the nucleus and complexes with nuclear components required for complete T-cell activation, including transactivation of IL-2 and other lymphokine genes.
  • Calcineurin phosphatase activity is inhibited after physical interaction with the cyclosporine/cyclophilin complex.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Activation of NK cells

  • This statement is incorrect. Cyclosporine does not activate natural killer (NK) cells. Instead, it primarily targets T-cell-mediated immune responses.

Option B: Blockade of tissue responses to inflammatory mediators

  • This statement is incorrect. Cyclosporine does not directly block tissue responses to inflammatory mediators. Its mechanism of action involves inhibition of T-cell activation and proliferation.

Option D: Interference with antigen recognition

  • This statement is incorrect. Cyclosporine does not interfere with antigen recognition. Instead, it acts downstream in the signaling pathway by inhibiting interleukin gene transcription and T-cell activation.

questions.text:
Match the following appropriately

questions.text: A 17-year-old female presents to the clinic with significantly low body weight, intense fear of weight gain, and distorted body image. She admits to restricting her food intake and engaging in excessive exercise. The treatment plan is discussed with the patient. Which of the following treatment options is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Nutritional rehabilitation and weight restoration only
A combination of psychotherapy, nutritional rehabilitation, and pharmacotherapy

questions.solution:
Correct Option D: A combination of psychotherapy, nutritional rehabilitation, and pharmacotherapy

  • In the treatment of Anorexia Nervosa, a multidisciplinary approach is typically recommended. The combination of psychotherapy, nutritional rehabilitation, and pharmacotherapy has been found to be most effective in addressing the complex nature of the disorder.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Psychotherapy alone: Is not sufficient for the comprehensive treatment of Anorexia Nervosa. Psychotherapy, such as cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) or family-based therapy (FBT), is an important component but should be combined with other interventions.

Option B - Nutritional rehabilitation and weight restoration only: Addresses the physical aspect of the disorder but neglects the psychological and emotional components. Psychotherapy is crucial in helping the patient address distorted body image, fear of weight gain, and underlying psychological issues.

Option C -Pharmacotherapy with SSRIs only: May be beneficial for co-occurring mood disorders, but it is not the standalone treatment for Anorexia Nervosa. Medications alone do not address the core symptoms and psychological factors associated with the disorder.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male with a 15-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of dimunition of vision in his left eye for the past three months. Optical coherence tomography (OCT) is performed, showing the findings given below.What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Cystoid macular edema :

  • The OCT examination in the above patient shows presence of cystoid spaces filled with fluid . These findings along with the presenting clinical features indicate the presence of cystoid macular edema.

CME (Cystoid Macular Edema)

Cystoid macular edema (CME) is swelling of the layers of the neurosensory retina within the macula. When excess fluid builds in the retina, it typically collects in “pockets,” referred to as “cysts.”

Signs and Symptoms:

  • Slow, painless loss of vision
  • Metamorphopsia (distortion of shape)
  • Micropsia (objects appear small and distorted) or macropsia (objects appear large and distorted)

Diagnostic Tools:

  • Amsler's grid
  • +90 D lens (best instrument to examine CME)

Investigations:

Fluorescein Angiography (FA):

  • Dye used: Fluorescein Sodium
  • Arm retina circulation time: 12 seconds
  • Pattern of leak indicates pathology
  • Limitations: invasive and may cause allergy

Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT):

  • Gold standard investigation for all macular disorders
  • Non-invasive
  • Provides a cross-sectional view of the retina

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Central serous retinopathy: It typically presents with serous retinal detachment and fluid accumulation underneath the neurosensory retina, often occurring in younger patients and often associated with stress or corticosteroid use.

Option C - Retinal detachment : It involves the separation of the neurosensory retina from the underlying retinal pigment epithelium and is associated with symptoms like flashes of light and a sensation of a "curtain" coming down over the vision.

Option D - Age related macular degeneration : It is characterized by the gradual deterioration of the macula, often leading to central vision loss, but it usually presents with drusen and pigmentary changes, rather than cystic spaces seen in CME.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man complains of itching and a red, scaly rash in the groin area. He reports that he is active in the gym for long periods of time and repeats his clothes. What is the term for this condition, and what is its commonly used colloquial name?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Tinea Cruris; Dhobi Itch:

  • Tinea cruris is a fungal infection that commonly occurs in the groin area, often referred to colloquially as Dhobi Itch or Jock Itch. It is characterised by itching, redness, and a scaly rash, especially in regions with skin folds. The fungus tends to thrive in warm and moist environments, such as those caused by constant sweating. T. rubrum, T. mentagrophytes, and E. floccosum causes tinea cruris.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Tinea Pedis; Athlete's Foot: Tinea Pedis, commonly known as Athlete's Foot, is a fungal infection that affects the feet, typically causing itching, scaling, and redness between the toes.

Option B - Tinea Versicolor; Sunspots: Tinea Versicolor is a fungal infection that presents with hypo- or hyperpigmented macules on the skin. It is not commonly referred to as "Sunspots."

Option D - Tinea Capitis; Ringworm: Tinea Capitis is a fungal infection affecting the scalp, often colloquially referred to as Ringworm. It causes hair loss and characteristic circular or annular lesions on the scalp.

questions.text: A hypochondriac 20-year-old male comes to the hospital with fatigue, a swollen left knee, loss of appetite, and headache for three weeks. His temperature and vital signs are normal. He admits he does not take regular home-cooked meals and often eats outside. He also frequently suffers from foodborne infections. His blood investigations show raised ESR, Hb 12 g/dL, and WBC 10,000 cells/mm3. A knee X-ray is ordered and returned, as shown in the image below. Subsequent aspiration of the knee yields no signs of infection. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Brodie’s Abscess:

  • A three-week history of systemic symptoms such as fatigue, loss of appetite, and headache in a patient with a swollen knee indicates a systemic condition.
  • Sterile pus is aspirated from the knee. This finding, coupled with a cavity surrounded by a sclerotic rim in the upper end of the tibia on the X-ray, points towards a diagnosis of subacute osteomyelitis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Osteoid Osteoma:

  • Brodie's abscess can be confused with osteoid osteoma, due to overlapping features of pain with or without swelling. However, the pain in osteoid osteoma is specifically nocturnal in nature, and patients will often report pain relief following consumption of NSAIDs. The X-ray findings are also very different.

Option C - TB Osteomyelitis:

  • This patient has no features or history suggestive of TB infection.

Option D - Eosinophilic Granuloma:

  • There are no hematological abnormalities in this patient's blood work. This condition often affects the skull.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding use of Beta Blockers in congestive heart failure?

choices.text: β blockers should be started at a very low dose and slowly titrated upwards
They are contraindicated in chronic heart failure.
Mortality is increased in CHF patients using β blockers
Carvedilol is a selective β2 blocker and can be used in CHF

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - β blockers should be started at a very low dose and slowly titrated upwards:

  • This is a case of congestive heart failure in which the patient presents to the cardiologist for follow-up.
  • The dose of β blockers should be gradually titrated upwards in HFbecause a high dose may cause decompensation, leading to Acute Heart Failure.
  • The process of dose escalation should be gradual, requiring time (for instance, doubling the dosage every 4 weeks in ambulatory settings, following the principle of "start low, go slow").
  • In this manner, the heart is allowed to adapt to reduced catecholamine stimulation, ultimately reaching a new balance with a diminished adrenergic drive.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - They are contraindicated in chronic heart failure:

  • β blockers are commonly used in chronic heart failure to reverse adverse cardiac changes and reduce arrhythmias.
  • Not to be used in acute decompensated heart failure.

Option C - Mortality is increased in heart failure patients using β blockers:

  • β blockers reduce mortality, especially in patients with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF).
  • Protect the heart from adverse long-term consequences of adrenergic overstimulation, commonly used in HF treatment.

Option D - Carvedilol is a selective β2 blocker:

Carvedilol is ta non-selective beta blocker and also has alpha-1 receptor-blocking activity

  • It is indicated in mild to moderate CHF

questions.text: Below are the various options showing the order of appearance of serum markers in Hepatitis B infection. Pick the correct answer.
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - HBsAg → HBeAg → IgM → Anti-HBeAg → Anti-HBsAg:

  • Initially, HBsAg (hepatitis B surface antigen) is detected during the acute phase of infection.
  • Subsequently, as the infection progresses, HBeAg (hepatitis B e antigen) appears.
  • IgM antibodies against hepatitis B core antigen (IgM anti-HBc) appear early in infection and indicate recent exposure.
  • As the infection resolves, IgG antibodies against HBsAg (anti-HBs) and HBeAg (anti-HBe) develop, with anti-HBeAg before anti-HBsAg.

Incorrect Options: Options A, B, and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.text: What mechanisms are involved in the pathogenesis of cellular aging?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Defective degradation of proteins:

  • Cellular aging is due to a gradual decline in cellular function and viability. This is a result of genetic abnormalities and the accumulation of cellular and molecular damage due to the effects of exogenous influences.

  • The following signaling pathways affect the aging of cells:

    • Mutations, DNA damage, and faulty DNA repair.

    • Replication of cells, the shortening or attrition of telomeres, and the death of cells.

    • Protein homeostasis declines with age, which causes problems with the regular folding of proteins and the removal of proteins that have become misfolded (there is decrease in normal proteins & increase in damaged proteins).

    • Caloric restriction is believed to enhance longevity through two main mechanisms: reducing the signaling intensity of the IGF-1 pathway and increasing sirtuins..

  • Proteins that do not fold correctly have been linked to the following diseases:

    • Retinitis pigmentosa, which is caused by abnormal folding of rhodopsin.

    • Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, which is caused by abnormal folding of PrPsc.

    • Alzheimer's disease, which is caused by the abnormal folding of A peptide.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Decreased protein synthesis:

  • The pathogenesis of aging does not include decreased protein synthesis.

  • Protein homeostasis declines with age, which causes problems with the regular folding of proteins and the removal of proteins that have become misfolded.

Option B - Telomere lengthening:

  • The pathogenesis of aging includes telomere shortening.

  • Therefore this option is incorrect

Option D - Decreased immune response:

  • The pathogenesis of aging does not include decreased immune response.

  • Therefore this option is incorrect

questions.text: A pediatrician orders a Guthrie bacterial inhibition assay in a child suspected of phenylketonuria. Which of the following will this test detect?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - All of the above:

Guthrie's bacterial inhibition test:

  • Screening test for phenylketonuria (PKU).
  • Detects abnormal presence of phenylalanine metabolites in blood.
  • Procedure involves taking a small blood sample from the infant's heel and placing it in a medium with Bacillus subtilis, a bacteria requiring phenylalanine for growth.
  • Positive result indicates presence of phenylalanine metabolites, suggesting PKU.
  • Mass spectrometry analysis of blood is the preferred modern method for newborn screening, offering high sensitivity and ability to detect multiple metabolites rapidly.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and C: Refer to the explanation of D.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions Oschner-Sherren's regimen is used as management?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Appendicular mass:

  • Oschner-Sherren is indicated in appendicular mass.
  • If an appendix mass is present and the patient's condition is satisfactory, the standard treatment is the conservative Oschner-Sherren regime.
    • Temperature, pulse and Fluid record should be recorded 4 hourly.
    •  
    • The extent of mass should be marked and examined regularly.
    • NPO And IV fluid supplement.
    • Antibiotics and Analgesics.
    • Allow oral liquid on subsequent days.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Appendicular abscess:

  • The appendicular abscess is a collection of pus resulting from necrosis of the tissue superimposed with infection in an inflamed appendix.
  • Treatment of appendicular abscesses usually involves drained radiologically.

Option B - Chronic appendicitis:

  • Chronic appendicitis is along-standing inflammation or fibrosis of the appendix that presents clinically as prolonged or intermittent abdominal pain.
  • The preferred treatment for chronic appendicitis is surgical removal of the appendix (appendectomy) rather than conservative management.

Option D - Acute appendicitis:

  • Acute appendicitis is an inflammatory condition of the appendix characterized by acute severe right iliac fossa pain and leukocytosis and requires urgent appendectomy.

questions.text: Which of the following options is a physiological uncoupler?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Thyroxine: 

  • This is a physiological uncoupler. Thyroxine increases uncoupler proteins in the inner mitochondrial membrane, promoting heat production through non-shivering thermogenesis.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C and D are artificial uncouplers

questions.text: A 32-year-old female named Sarah recently survived a severe car accident. She was trapped in the wreckage for several hours before being rescued. Since the accident, she has been experiencing recurrent distressing dreams about the event, avoiding driving or even being near cars, and constantly feeling on edge. Which of the following best describes Sarah's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C : Hypervigilance and avoidance behavior.

  • Based on the scenario, Sarah is experiencing several symptoms consistent with Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD). These symptoms include recurrent distressing dreams about the traumatic event (intrusion symptoms), avoiding driving or cars (avoidance), and constantly feeling on edge (hypervigilance). Therefore, option C is the most appropriate choice that reflects Sarah's symptoms.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Anterograde amnesia: Anterograde amnesia pertains to a specific type of memory impairment, rather than the set of symptoms she is experiencing.

Option B - Social withdrawal and isolation: While avoidance behavior is present in PTSD, it specifically refers to avoiding reminders of the traumatic event, not necessarily social withdrawal or isolation.

Option D - Excessive sleepiness and fatigue: While sleep disturbances can occur in PTSD, the scenario does not mention excessive sleepiness and fatigue as primary symptoms experienced by Sarah.

questions.text: Use of BCG vaccine for treatment of bladder cancer comes under which type of mode of prevention?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Secondary Prevention:

  • The application of the BCG vaccine for bladder cancer constitutes secondary prevention, utilizing immunotherapy to bolster the body's defense against cancer cells in the bladder, aiming to halt disease recurrence or progression.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Health Promotion: It focuses on promoting overall health and preventing the onset of diseases through education, lifestyle modifications, and environmental changes.

Option B - Specific Protection: Specific protection measures include immunization and other targeted interventions aimed at protecting individuals from specific diseases or hazards.

Option D - Quaternary Prevention: Quaternary prevention focuses on preventing over diagnosis, overtreatment, and unnecessary medical interventions. It aims to protect individuals from potential harm caused by excessive medicalization.

questions.text: Following are the true statements about Itraconazole except:

choices.text: Itraconazole is the drug of choice for maintenance therapy in penicilliosis

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Causes Hypertension Leading to CHF

Explanation:

Itraconazole can reduce cardiac contractility and precipitate or worsen heart failure in predisposed patients. However, hypertension leading to CHF is not a recognized mechanism. Thus, the statement that itraconazole causes hypertension leading to CHF is inaccurate.

 

Itraconazole:

  • Triazole antifungal is used to treat various fungal infections, including penicilliosis, blastomycosis, histoplasmosis, sporotrichosis, and eumycetoma.
  • It inhibits fungal cytochrome P450-dependent 14α-demethylase, disrupting ergosterol synthesis in fungal cell membranes.
  • Role in Specific Fungal Infections:
    • Penicilliosis, Blastomycosis, Histoplasmosis, Sporotrichosis:
      • Amphotericin B is the drug of choice for induction therapy in severe cases due to its potent antifungal activity for these systemic fungal infections.
      • Itraconazole is used for maintenance therapy or treatment of mild-to-moderate cases, as per CDC and WHO guidelines for opportunistic infections (e.g., in HIV/AIDS for penicilliosis) and IDSA guidelines for endemic mycoses. (Option D)
    • Eumycetoma: Itraconazole is the first-line treatment for eumycetoma (fungal mycetoma, e.g., caused by Madurella mycetomatis), often requiring prolonged therapy (6–12 months or longer), sometimes with surgical debridement, as per WHO guidelines. (Option B)
  • Side Effects of Itraconazole:
    • Hepatotoxicity (Option A)
    • GI Disturbances: Nausea, vomiting, and abdominal discomfort are common side effects.
    • Heart Failure
    • Hypertension and Hypokalemia

questions.text: All of the following are subject bias, except:
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Golem bias:

  • Golem bias is indeed a type of investigator bias, not subject bias. It occurs when the motivation of the investigator influences the performance or response of the subjects.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Hawthorne Bias: Hawthorne Bias is subject bias, where subjects modify their behavior due to being observed. It's commonly seen in cohort studies.

Option B - Recall Bias: Recall Bias is also subject bias, occurring when subjects inaccurately remember and report past events. It's commonly seen in case-control studies.

Option C - Reporting Bias: Reporting Bias is subject bias, where subjects over or under-report due to pragmatic reasons like stigma. It can occur in both cohort and case-control studies.

questions.text: A laborer's young child is brought to the outpatient department with a swollen belly and a dull expression. The child has mostly been fed rice water (rice milk). Investigations reveal low serum protein and low albumin levels. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Kwashiorkor:

  • Kwashiorkor is a form of severe protein-energy malnutrition characterized by edema (swollen belly), skin changes, and low serum protein and albumin levels. It typically occurs in children when there is adequate calorie intake but insufficient protein intake.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Marasmus: Marasmus is another form of severe malnutrition but is characterized by severe calorie deficiency, leading to significant weight loss, muscle wasting, and usually without edema.

Option C - Indian childhood cirrhosis: Indian childhood cirrhosis presents with liver dysfunction and is not associated with the classic signs of malnutrition like edema or low serum proteins.

Option D - Kawasaki disease: Kawasaki disease presents with fever, rash, conjunctivitis, mucositis, and adenopathy.

questions.text: In spinal anesthesia, which local anesthetic is most commonly used due to its widespread clinical application?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Bupivacaine:

  • Bupivacaine is favored in spinal anesthesia for its long-lasting effects, making it suitable for procedures requiring prolonged pain relief.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Lidocaine: While lidocaine is commonly used for local anesthesia in various procedures, it is not typically the first choice for spinal anesthesia due to its shorter duration of action compared to other agents

Option C - Procaine: Procaine is an older local anesthetic but is less commonly used in spinal anesthesia due to its shorter duration of action and lower potency compared to newer agents like bupivacaine.

Option D - Articaine: Articaine is more commonly used in dental procedures and has a different pharmacological profile compared to bupivacaine, making it less suitable for spinal anesthesia applications.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents with cardiomegaly, hypotonia, and respiratory distress. The parents report that the child has had difficulty feeding and gaining weight, showing signs of failure to thrive. A biopsy reveals glycogen accumulation in cardiac and skeletal muscle cells. Which of the following is the most likely enzyme deficiency?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Acid maltase (alpha-glucosidase) deficiency:

  • Enzyme replacement therapy
  • This describes Pompe disease, a lysosomal storage disorder and glycogen storage disorder. The defect in acid maltase (alpha-glucosidase) leads to glycogen accumulation in lysosomes, primarily affecting cardiac and skeletal muscles.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency:

  • Dietary management
  • This refers to Von Gierke's disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type I), which primarily affects the liver and does not typically present with cardiomegaly or skeletal muscle involvement.

Option C - Hexosaminidase A deficiency:

  • Supportive care
  • This describes Tay-Sachs disease, a different lysosomal storage disorder affecting the central nervous system, presenting with neurological symptoms rather than cardiomegaly and muscle hypotonia.

Option D - Galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase deficiency;

  • Lactose-free diet
  • This describes Classic Galactosemia, a disorder of galactose metabolism, not a glycogen storage or lysosomal storage disorder, and it primarily presents with liver dysfunction and cataracts.

questions.text: Which Leopold maneuver is most informative in determining the engagement, degree of descent, and presentation of the fetus?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Fourth Leopold maneuver:

  • Fourth Leopold maneuver is the most informative as it assesses engagement by checking if the part is engaged (fingers cannot be approximated, then the fingers are divergent). It also evaluates the degree of descent and confirms fetal presentation.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and C are not the most informative Leopold maneuver.

questions.text: In Brown-Sequard syndrome, what sensations are lost on the opposite side of the lesion?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Pain and temperature:

  • In Brown-Sequard syndrome, there is damage to one-half (hemisection) of the spinal cord. As a result, the sensations that are typically lost on the opposite side of the lesion include pain and temperature perception.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Proprioception and vibration: These sensations are typically lost on the same side as the lesion.

Option C - Crude touch and pressure: Crude touch and pressure sensations are lost on the same side as the lesion.

Option D - Tactile discrimination: Sensations of tactile discrimination are lost on the same side as the lesion

questions.text: Identify the malampatti classification?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Class 2:

  • Hard palate, soft palate, uvula and tonsil pillars are visible
  • The tip of the uvula is not visible

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, C and D are incorrect as given below

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presented to the OPD complaining of pale-coloured skin, dark-coloured urine, fatigue, shortness of breath and weakness. She has been non-diabetic but hypertensive for 15 years. Her past medical history includes SLE and recurrent typhoid fever treated with intravenous ceftriaxone. A palpable spleen is found on physical examination. Her peripheral blood smear shows spherocytes. Which of the following is the best investigation to diagnose her condition?
questions.solution:
Option C: Coombs test

Spherocytes in adult patients indicate the presence of autoimmune haemolytic anaemia; hence, Coombs test should be performed.

Autoimmune haemolytic anaemia (AIHA):

  • It is idiopathic normocytic anaemia.
  • In this condition, the body’s immune system produces autoantibodies directed against its own RBC that attack and destroy RBC.
  • These autoantibodies bind to RBC cell surface antigens and cause them to clump together, which is termed RBC agglutination
  • The best test to diagnose AIHA is Coombs test.
  • Coombs test is of 2 types-
    • Direct
    • Indirect
  • The direct Coombs test detects agglutinated RBCs in AIHA.
  • The peripheral blood smear will show spherocytes, so RBC osmotic fragility will also increase in AIHA.
  • But increased osmotic fragility merely reflects the presence of spherocytes and does not distinguish hereditary spherocytosis from other spherocytic hemolytic disorders.

Option A: Reticulocyte count

  • Reticulocyte count is increased hemolytic anaemia as bone marrow makes more reticulocytes to replace destroyed RBC.
  • But it cannot specify the different types of haemolytic anaemia.

Option B: Osmotic fragility test

  • It is done to diagnose hereditary spherocytosis.
  • The presence of spherocytes alone is insufficient for diagnosing hereditary spherocytosis.
  • Osmotic fragility of RBC will also increase in other causes of hemolytic anaemia with spherocytes.

Option D: Bone marrow aspiration

  • This test is done to confirm the diagnosis of aplastic anaemia.
  • It cannot diagnose AIHA.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with a two-day history of nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. He reports feeling extremely thirsty and has been urinating frequently. On examination, his breath has a fruity odor. His blood glucose level is 380 mg/dL (21.1 mmol/L). An arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis is performed. Which of the following ABG findings would be most consistent with the patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - pH 7.30, PaCO2 30 mmHg, HCO3- 18 mEq/L:

  • The clinical presentation of nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, fruity breath odor, and elevated blood glucose levels suggests diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), a potentially life-threatening complication of uncontrolled diabetes. DKA is characterized by metabolic acidosis resulting from the accumulation of ketone bodies (such as beta-hydroxybutyrate and acetoacetate) due to insulin deficiency and increased gluconeogenesis.
  • In DKA, ABG analysis typically reveals a low pH (acidosis), low bicarbonate (HCO3-) levels due to metabolic acidosis, and low partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2) as a compensatory response to increased ventilation and decreased carbon dioxide levels. Option A presents the most consistent ABG findings for DKA, with a pH of 7.30 (normal range 7.35 - 7.45), PaCO2 of 30 mmHg (lower than the normal range of 35-45 mmHg), and HCO3- of 18 mEq/L (lower than the normal range of 22-28 mEq/L).

Incorrect Options:

Option B - pH 7.45, PaCO2 40 mmHg, HCO3- 24 mEq/L: represents a normal pH and ABG values within the reference range, not indicative of DKA.

Option C - pH 7.50, PaCO2 50 mmHg, HCO3- 28 mEq/L: suggests respiratory alkalosis rather than metabolic acidosis seen in DKA.

Option D - pH 7.40, PaCO2 45 mmHg, HCO3- 28 mEq/L: represents a normal pH and ABG values within the reference range, not indicative of DKA.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman comes to the clinic complaining of pain in the right upper quadrant of abdomen for the last 5 days. The pain especially increases after meals. Ultrasound reveals gallstones in the bile duct. ERCP done and the gallstones are removed. Which of the following is the most common complication after ERCP?
questions.solution:
Option A: Acute pancreatitis

  • The most common complication after ERCP is Acute pancreatitis
  • ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography)
  • indication:
    •           1. Malignancy-irregular filling defect.
    •           2. Chronic pancreatitis-'chain-of-lakes' appearance.
      • 3. Congenital anomalies-Stones.
        4. Stricture of biliary tree-Choledochal cyst.
        5. For sampling of biliary and pancreatic juices for analysis and cytology.
        6. Brush biopsy from tumor site.
  • Uses (diagnostic and therapeutic)
    • Biopsy
    • Brush cytology
    • Placement of stents to relieve obstruction
    • Drain a pseudocyst
    • Stone removal
    • Diagnosis and staging of chronic pancreatitis

Complications of ERCP:

  • Pancreatitis (5%) - Most common complication post ERCP

Risk factors for post-ERCP pancreatitis

  • Suspected Sphincter of Oddi dysfunction
  • Young age
  • Normal bilirubin
  • Prior ERCP-related pancreatitis
  • Difficult cannulation
  • Pancreatic duct contrast injection
  • Pancreatic sphincterotomy
  • Balloon dilatation of the biliary sphincter

Hemorrhage

  • Rare complication
  • Most commonly seen with sphincterotomy

Infection

  • A serious complication of ERCP
  • Most common - Cholangitis, cholecystitis
  • Cholangitis most commonly occurs when there is failed or incomplete biliary drainage

Perforation (0.5% to 2.1%)

  • The most common type- is retroperitoneal perforation
  • Associated with sphincterotomy

Option A: Acute cholangitis

  • Acute Cholangitis most commonly occurs when there is  incomplete biliary drainage during ERCP, but acute pancreatitis is more common as a complication of ERCP

Option C: Acute cholecystitis

  • Acute cholecystitis is a rare complication of ERCP due to the seeding of enteric bacteria that enter by a retrograde route to the gallbladder, causing acute cholecystitis

Option D: Duodenal perforation

ERCP-related perforations can occur during handling or manipulation of the endoscope, endoscopic sphincterotomy, or insertion of the guidewire. But it is a rare complication nowadays.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy with a history of intellectual disability and seizures comes to the doctor with shortness of breath for a month. His BP was 138/82 mm Hg, pulse was 75/min, and BMI was 21 kg/m2.On physical examination, the doctor notices numerous papules on the boy's face. In addition, echocardiography shows tumor-like growth in the left ventricle. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Rhabdomyoma:

  • Tuberous sclerosis is an autosomal dominant condition characterized by developing hamartomas and benign neoplasms involving the brain and other tissues.

  • The most frequent clinical manifestations are seizures, autism, and mental retardation.

  • Hamartomas within the CNS take the form of cortical tubers, subependymal nodules, and subependymal giant-cell astrocytomas.

  • Half of the patients with tuberous sclerosis develop rhabdomyomas, primary tumours of cardiac muscle that, although benign, may compromise cardiac function.

  • They may be found on atrioventricular valves or ventricle walls, causing outflow obstruction.

  • The nuclei of the rhabdomyoma cells are central or eccentrically located. In some cells, eosinophilic septa stretch from the cell membrane to a centrally placed nucleus, imparting a spiderlike appearance to the cell known as 'spider cells'

  • Spider cells are pathognomonic for cardiac rhabdomyomas and represent degenerating rhabdomyocytes.

 Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Lipoma:

  • Lipoma can create ball valve obstruction, and with a history suggesting tuberous sclerosis, a lipoma is less likely.

Option B - Myxomas:​​​​​​​

  • Myxomas are almost exclusively seen in adults and are usually located in the atria, making this a less likely diagnosis.

Option D - Dilated cardiomyopathy:

  • Dilated cardiomyopathy involves hypertrophy, dilation, and eventually heart failure and is not associated with tuberous sclerosis.

questions.text: A primigravida presented in labor at term pregnancy. An emergency LSCS had to be performed due to fetal distress. During the cesarean section, placenta delivery was followed by heavy bleeding from the placental bed. In order, the obstetrician injected oxytocin, injection methergine, rectal misoprostol, and intramyometrial prostodin. However, the bleeding did not stop. A few compression sutures over the uterus were taken, which also did not stop the bleeding completely, and the uterus remained atonic. Which is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient?

choices.text: Two-layer closure of the uterine incision

questions.solution:
Correct Option: B

  • This is a case of atonic PPH, where medical management has failed.
  • Uterine artery ligation is a surgical procedure that involves ligating or tying off the uterine arteries to reduce blood flow to the uterus. This intervention is often considered in cases of persistent uterine atony when other measures have failed.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Two-layer closure of the uterine incision

  • This option involves reinforcing the closure of the uterine incision during the cesarean section. While it may contribute to hemostasis, it is not the primary intervention for managing persistent uterine atony.

Option C: Tranexamic acid

  • Tranexamic acid is an antifibrinolytic medication that can be used to reduce bleeding. It works by inhibiting the breakdown of blood clots. While it can be a helpful adjunct, especially in cases of postpartum hemorrhage, it does not directly address uterine atony.

Option D: Uterine massage

  • Uterine massage is the first line of management of the uterine atony.
  • However, this is a case of refractory atony. Massage has likely already been tried along with other therapies, and is unlikely to help more.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with painful, recurrent abscesses and nodules in the axillary and groin regions. The lesions are interconnected and often lead to the formation of tunnels and scarring. There is a notable history of these symptoms recurring for more than six months. What is the most likely diagnosis based on these clinical features?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Hidradenitis suppurativa:

  • Hidradenitis suppurativa is a chronic skin condition characterized by painful and recurrent abscesses and nodules in areas containing apocrine sweat glands, such as the axillary and groin regions. The lesions often form interconnected tracts and can lead to scarring. For a confirmed diagnosis, the symptoms must be present for more than six months, as this condition is chronic in nature.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pilonidal cysts:

  • Pilonidal cysts are cystic lesions that typically occur near the cleft of the buttocks and contain hair and debris. They are not associated with the formation of tunnels or abscesses in the axillary and groin regions like those seen in hidradenitis suppurativa.

Option C - Folliculitis decalvans: 

  • Folliculitis decalvans is a chronic, inflammatory disorder that primarily affects the hair follicles on the scalp, leading to hair loss and scarring. It does not commonly involve the axillary and groin regions, nor does it present with interconnected tunnels and abscesses like hidradenitis suppurativa.

Option D - Cellulitis:

  • Cellulitis is a bacterial skin infection (it can involve epidermis, the dermis and subcutaneous tissue, making it a deeper skin infection) that typically presents with red, swollen, and tender skin. While it can occur in various body regions, it is not specifically associated with the axillary and groin regions. Additionally, cellulitis does not lead to the formation of interconnected tunnels and scarring as seen in hidradenitis suppurativa.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a histopathological feature of oligodendroglioma?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Perivascular pseudo rosettes:

  • Perivascular pseudorosettes are not a characteristic feature of oligodendrogliomas. Perivascular pseudorosettes are typically associated with ependymomas.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and D are features of oligodendroglioma.

questions.text: What is a characteristic histological feature of Paget's disease seen in biopsy findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Empty cells in the epithelium:

  • In Paget's disease, characteristic histological findings include the presence of "Paget cells," which are large, pale, vacuolated cells found within the epithelium. These cells appear empty or contain clear cytoplasm. They are indicative of Paget’s disease.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are not seen in Paget’s disease.

questions.text: Which among the following drugs is synthetic heparin which is unsafe in renal disease has longest t1/2?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Idraparinux:

  • Idraparinux is synthetic ULMWH (1500KDa)
  • Pentasaccharide
  • Other drug is Fondaparinux
  • MOA: inhibition of clotting factor X.
  • It has the longest t1/2
  • Unsafe in renal failure patients.
  • ROA: Subcutaneous.
  • aPTT monitoring is required in case of Renal failure
    • Monitor factor Xa assay
  • Uses:
    • Prophylaxis of DVT/PE
      • ICU patients
    • Af with MS
    • After knee and hip surgery

Incorrect Options:

Option B, C and D - Enoxaparin, Dalteparin, Tinzaparin:

  • These drugs are Fractionated LMWH.
  • MOA: Inhibition of clotting factors X>>>>II
  • Unsafe in renal failure patient.
  • ROA: Subcutaneous.
  • Uses are same as ULMWH.

questions.text: A 55-year old male presents to the emergency department with acute right flank pain for the past 3 hours. He was prescribed painkillers and discharged. The next day, he presented again with severe pain and was referred to the urology department. A ureteric calculus associated with hydronephrosis is identified on the ultrasound abdomen. He is managed with a procedure shown in the following image. Which of the following is correct about the given procedure?

choices.text: Gold standard lithotripter is Dornier unmodified HM-3
Steinstrasse is seen in cases of proximal ureteric obstruction
The maximum size of the stone removed is 1.5 cm

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Gold standard lithotripter is Dornier unmodified HM-3:

  • Clinical signs: Right flank pain, ureteric calculus, and hydronephrosis are indications of a renal stone.
  • ESWL- Extracorporeal Shock wave Lithotripsy:
    • Gold standard Lithotripter- Dornier Unmodified HM-3
    • Shock waves recognize the stone with the help of density changes in the body→ erosion and shattering of stones → fragmentation of stones → excreted via the ureter.
    • If there is an obstruction in the ureter (distal ureter- 64%, proximal ureter - 29% and mid ureter -8%), stone fragments are collected in the proximal part of the ureter leading to a complication known as Steinstrasse (also known as Street of stones/ Columnation of Gravel).
    • The maximum size of stone removed by ESWL is 2cm.
  • Absolute contraindications of ESWL:
    • Pregnancy
    • Bleeding disorders
  • Relative contraindications of ESWL:
    • Pacemaker
    • UTI
    • Distal obstruction
    • Obesity
    • Orthopaedic abnormalities like Scoliosis and Kyphoscoliosis
    • Uncontrolled HTN
    • Aneurysm
    • Renal failure
  • Whenever ESWL cannot be used→, PCNL is preferred

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Steinstrasse is seen in cases of proximal ureteric obstruction:

  • Steinstrasse is a complication of ESWLseen in cases of distal ureteric obstruction.
  • Distal obstruction is responsible for this.

Option C - Pregnancy is an Indication:

  • In pregnancy, it is contraindicated.

Option D - Maximum size of stone removed is 1.5 cm:

  • The maximum size of stone removed by ESWL is 2 cm.
  • It is not 1.5cm; stones up to 2 cm could be removed.

questions.text: Which tapeworm species is leaf-like, lacks suckers, and has two grooves ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D- Diphyllobothrium latum:

  • Diphyllobothrium latum is characterized by its leaf-like appearance.
  • It lacks suckers on its scolex.
  • Instead of suckers, it possesses two suctorial grooves, also known as bothria, which are longitudinal channels used for attachment to the host's intestine.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- Taenia solium: Taenia solium, also known as the pork tapeworm, has suckers and hooks, which are used for attachment to the host's intestinal wall. It does not have a leaf-like appearance and does not possess two grooves.

Option B- Taenia saginata: Taenia saginata, known as the beef tapeworm, is similar to Taenia solium in that it has suckers but no hooks for attachment to the host's intestinal wall. It does not have the leaf-like characteristics or the presence of two grooves.

Option C- Echinococcus: Echinococcus tapeworms, specifically Echinococcus granulosus and Echinococcus multilocularis, are known for their small size and the formation of cysts in various organs of the host, such as the liver and lungs. It possesses both suckers and hooks. They do not have a leaf-like appearance or two grooves.

questions.text: Which of the following is the anticoagulant used in a green vacutainer?
questions.solution:
Correct Option  D) Sodium Heparin :

  • Sodium Heparin is the anticoagulant used in a green vacutainer tube.
  • Green tubes are used for : Osmotic fragility testing, immunophenotyping, Arterial Blood Gas studies.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B and C are incorrect. Correct option is explained above.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about the poisoning caused by the seeds shown below?

choices.text: Uncrushed seeds will not lead to poisoning
Inhibits neurotransmitter glycine effect at the pre-synaptic receptor

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Toxin potentiates neurotransmitter glycine effect at pre-synaptic receptor:

  • The above given image is of Strychnine Seeds aka Dog Buttons
  • It is used to kill stray dogs, hence called Dog-buttons.
    • Seeds shape is concavo-convex.
    • It is odorless and bitter in taste.
    • Fatal dose: One crushed seed
  • Toxin potentiates neurotransmitter glycine which does not effect the pre synaptic receptor.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pleurosthotonus:

  • Pleurosthotonus: Lateral flexion of the spine, which is a feature of Strychnine poisoning.

Option B - Post mortem caloricity:

  • After death ‘Postmortem caloricity’ phenomenon occurs i.e., initially after death, the patient remains warm for few hours.

Option C - Uncrushed seeds will not lead to poisoning:

  • Unbroken seeds when ingested are not poisonous, as the hard pericarp is not soluble in digestive juices.

questions.text: How much oxygen does one gram of Haemoglobin carry when fully saturated in arterial blood?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 1.34 mL of oxygen:

  • One gram of pure Hemoglobin (Hb) can combine with 1.39 ml of O2.
  • When fully saturated, each gram (g) of normal hemoglobin contains 1.39 mL of O2. However, blood normally contains small quantities of inactive hemoglobin derivatives, and the measured value in vivo is thus slightly lower. The traditional estimate of saturated hemoglobin in vivo, is 1.34 mL of O2

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of option B.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a history of recurrent miscarriages at 8 weeks of gestation, a previous stillbirth at 30 weeks, and a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in her left leg. Lab findings reveal elevated IgG and IgM. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Antiphospholipid Antibody Syndrome (APS):

  • Antiphospholipid Antibody Syndrome is characterized by recurrent venous or arterial thrombosis and pregnancy complications such as recurrent miscarriages, stillbirths, or preterm deliveries due to placental insufficiency.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, C, and D do not present with recurrent pregnancy losses and stillbirths.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents with recurrent episodes of infantile spasms, accompanied by hypsarrhythmia on EEG. This infant is also diagnosed with tuberous sclerosis. What is the drug of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Vigabatrin:

  • Vigabatrin is the drug of choice for infantile spasms associated with tuberous sclerosis complex due to its effectiveness in controlling seizures in TSC patients.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Prednisolone: While corticosteroids like prednisolone may be used in isolated cases of infantile spasms, they are not the first-line treatment for those associated with tuberous sclerosis.

Option C - Levetiracetam: Levetiracetam is not typically used as the initial treatment for infantile spasms or for seizures associated with tuberous sclerosis. It is more commonly used for generalized seizures or focal seizures.

Option D - Diazepam: Diazepam may be used for acute seizure management, but it is not considered the primary treatment for infantile spasms associated with tuberous sclerosis.

questions.text: A group of first-year medical students gives a presentation on intercellular junctions. They describe various types of intercellular junctions and their structure. Which pair is correctly matched?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D – Adherens junction: Catenin:

  • In adherens junctions, cadherins are transmembrane proteins that mediate cell-cell adhesion, and catenins are cytoplasmic proteins that link cadherins to the actin cytoskeleton.

Incorrect Options:

Option A – Gap junction: Occludin: This is incorrect. Gap junctions are formed by connexins, not occludins. Connexins form channels that allow the direct exchange of ions and small molecules between adjacent cells.

Option B – Tight junction: Cadherin: This is incorrect. Tight junctions are primarily composed of claudins and occludins, not cadherins. Tight junctions play a role in forming a barrier that restricts the passage of substances between cells.

Option C – Desmosome: Cadherin: This is incorrect. Desmosomes are formed by desmogleins found in the myocardium cell membrane.

questions.text: Which of the following stages of NEC has portal vein gas as a feature on abdominal X-rays?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Stage IIB:

  • Stage IIB shows portal vein gas on abdominal X Ray

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Stage IIA:

  • Stage IIA shows Pneumatosis intestinalis (Air in the wall of the intestine).

Option C- Stage IA:

  • Stage IA shows occult blood positive in the stool.

Option D - Stage IB:

  • Stage IB: Fresh blood present in the stool of the baby.

questions.text:
Below are images of different types of surgical knots. Match them with their corresponding names. 


	
		
			
			1.
			
			
			a. Granny knot
			
		
		
			
			2. 
			
			
			b. Square knot
			
		
		
			
			3.
			
			
			c. Surgeon's knot
questions.solution:
Correct Option A- 1-c, 2-a, 3-b:

  • Surgeon’s knot: It consists of two throws. There are two wraps in the first throw and one in the second, and crossing occurs in each throw.
  • Granny knot: This knot, also called a pseudo square knot, involves two throws taken without crossing. One end is above, and the other is below. The granny knot is more prone to slip and is relatively unstable.
  • Square knot: This knot, also known as the reef knot, consists of two throws, and crossing is done in each throw. It is relatively secure.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child was admitted to the emergency department with extensive burns sustained from a house fire. The burns covered approximately 25% of the child's body surface area. Considering the provided information, what is the most appropriate fluid resuscitation strategy for this pediatric burn patient according to the modified ATLS version of the Parkland formula?

choices.text: Administer 2 ml of fluid per kg body weight × % BSA.
Administer 3 ml of fluid per kg body weight × % BSA.
Administer 4 ml of fluid per kg body weight × % BSA .
Calculate fluid resuscitation based solely on age and type of injury.

questions.solution:
Correct Option B- Administer 3 ml of fluid per kg body weight × % BSA.

  • According to the modified ATLS Parkland formula for children <14 years and ≤30 kg weight, the fluid resuscitation rate is 3 ml × body weight × % BSA. Since this child is 10 years old and falls within the specified weight range, the appropriate fluid resuscitation strategy involves calculating fluid volume based on this formula.

Burn resuscitation fluid rates and Target Urine output by Burn type and Age

Category of Burn

Age and Weight

Adjusted Fluid rates

Urine Output

Flame or Scald

Adult and older 14 children (>14 years old)

2 ml LR x kg x % TBSA

0.5 ml / kg/hr 30-50 ml/kg/hr

Children (<14 years old)

3 ml LR x Kg x % TBSA

1 ml / kg / hr

Infant and young children (£ 30 kg)

3 ml LR x kg x % TBSA

Plus a sugar - containing solution at maintenance rate

1 ml/kg/hr

Electrical injury

All ages

4 ml LR x Kg x % TBSA until urine clears

1-1.5 ml/ kg / hr until urine clears

LR: Lactated Ringer’s solution

TBSA: Total Body Surface Area

Half of the fluid is given over the course of 8 hours and the remaining half is provided over a span of 16 hours. The rate of fluid administration should be titrated to effect using a target urine output of 0.5 ml/kg/hr in adults or 1 ml/kg/hr in children who are hemodynamically normal. Boluses are reserved for unstable patients.

Incorrect Choices:

Option A- Administer 2 ml of fluid per kg body weight × % BSA: This choice suggests a fluid resuscitation rate that is lower than the appropriate formula. For pediatric patients, the modified ATLS Parkland formula involves a higher fluid volume per body weight and percentage of burned surface area.

Option C- Administer 4 ml of fluid per kg body weight × % BSA : This choice suggests a fluid resuscitation rate that is higher than the appropriate formula. For pediatric patients, the modified ATLS Parkland formula is used. 

Option D- Calculate fluid resuscitation based solely on age and type of injury. Fluid resuscitation strategies should consider both age and weight along with the type and extent of burns. The modified ATLS Parkland formula takes into account these factors to provide a comprehensive approach to fluid resuscitation.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of intense itching, watering, and ropy discharge from both eyes. On examination, you observe giant papillae on the upper tarsal conjunctiva, and there are small, white, gelatinous accumulations of eosinophils at the limbus. What type of hypersensitivity reaction is most likely responsible for the pathophysiology of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Type I hypersensitivity reaction:

  • The clinical picture of itching, ropy discharge, giant papillae i.e., cobblestone appearance and small, white, gelatinous accumulations of eosinophils i.e., Horner trantas spots are typical of Vernal conjunctivitis. VKC is primarily an IgE-mediated hypersensitivity reaction, involving mast cell degranulation and release of inflammatory mediators such as histamine.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Type II hypersensitivity reaction: Type II hypersensitivity reactions involve antibody-mediated cytotoxicity, which is not the primary mechanism in VKC.

Option C - Type III hypersensitivity reaction: Type III hypersensitivity reactions involve immune complex deposition, which is not the primary mechanism in VKC.

Option D - Type IV hypersensitivity reaction: Type IV hypersensitivity reactions, or delayed-type hypersensitivity reactions, are mediated by T cells. VKC is primarily an IgE-mediated reaction.

questions.text: A patient is presented to the hospital after a road traffic accident. He has contusions on his chest. He presented with respiratory distress, tachypnea and hypotension. What is the next step in the investigation of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - E-FAST:

  • A trauma patient is screened for peritoneal fluid, pericardial fluid, pneumothorax, and hemothorax using the bedside ultrasonographic approach known as E-FAST (Extended Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma).

Technique

  • Patient in the supine position.
  • 3.5-5.0 MHz convex transducer.
  • The pericardial view, also known as the subcostal or subxiphoid view, can be used to examine five different areas of the heart. The liver in the epigastric area is most frequently used as a sonographic window to the heart to assess the pericardium.
  • In detecting free intraperitoneal and intrathoracic fluid, this protocol has a high specificity and sensitivity, over 90%.
  • The extended FAST includes further testing of the anterior and lateral pleural areas to look for pneumothorax or pleural fluid, which, unless proven otherwise in the context of trauma , is thought to be a hemothorax. It is considered positive if any free fluid is seen during a scan.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - FAST:

  • The FAST (Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma) test visualizes 10 structures or spaces in four locations and searches for the presence of fluid, which is considered to represent blood in clinical scenario of trauma:
    • Pericardial
    • Perihepatic
    • Perisplenic
    • Pelvic
  • Over the past three decades, focused assessment with sonography in trauma (FAST) has been extensively used and researched in blunt and penetrating trauma. Before FAST, invasive procedures such as diagnostic peritoneal lavage and exploratory laparotomy were commonly used to diagnose an intra abdominal injury.
  • The right upper quadrant (RUQ) visualizes the hepatorenal recess, also known as Morrison's pouch, the right paracolic gutter, the hepato-diaphragmatic area, and the caudal edge of the left liver lobe.
  • Since FAST does not evaluate the pleural spaces adequately, eFAST is a better alternative.

Option C - MRI:

  • MRI cannot be done in emergency conditions due to longer duration of imaging and is mostly done for brain and spinal cord-related disorders.
