  • A magnetic field and radio waves produced by a computer are used in magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) to provide precise images of thebody's organs and tissues.

Option D - Ultrasound:

  • An ultrasound imaging scan employs sound waves to produce a sonogram, or image, of the organs, tissues, and other internal body components. Ultrasound does not use radiation as x-rays do.
  • E FAST is a specific form of USG scan used in trauma patients to screen potential sites of fluid accumulation after trauma.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true for a patient with hematuria and the given renal histopathology slide?



1. It is a Type III Hypersensitivity reaction.

2. Streptococcus pyogenes: strains 12, 4, and 1 are responsible.

3. Gross findings on the kidney show flea-bitten appearance.

4. Linear immunofluorescence is seen.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 1,2 and 3 are true:

The image shows hypercellular glomerulus, increased inflammatory (neutrophilic) infiltrate, proliferative changes in endothelium and mesangial cells

The likely diagnosis in this patient is post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis.

1. It is a Type III Hypersensitivity reaction (Immune complex mediated)

2. Streptococcus pyogenes: strains 12, 4 and 1 are responsible.

3. Gross findings on the kidney show a flea-bitten appearance.

These statements are true regarding PSGN.

Incorrect Options:

4. Linear immunofluorescence is seen.

This statement is not true, linear immunofluorescence is seen in good pasture syndrome. In PSGN immunofluorescence shows starry sky appearance.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents to the clinic with a recent onset of palpable reddish spots on his legs and buttocks and diffuse abdominal pain. Lab tests reveal a normal complete blood count. A renal biopsy reveals IgA deposition. What is the most likely diagnosis and appropriate initial management for this patient?

choices.text: Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura; initiate corticosteroids immediately
Henoch-Schoenlein Purpura; monitor and provide supportive care
Systemic lupus erythematosus; start immunosuppressive therapy

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Henoch-Schoenlein Purpura; monitor and provide supportive care:

  • The patient presents with classic symptoms of HSP, including palpable purpura, abdominal pain, and a biopsy showing IgA deposition. Most cases of HSP are self-limiting and require supportive care.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura; initiate corticosteroids immediately: This diagnosis is unlikely as thrombocytopenia is absent in this patient.

Option C - Systemic lupus erythematosus; start immunosuppressive therapy: This diagnosis is less likely as there is no thrombocytopenia in this patient.

Option D - Kawasaki disease; administer intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG): The classical features of Kawasaki disease include fever for >5 days with any 4 out of 5 features:

  • C - Conjunctivitis, B/L non-purulent
  • R - Rash involving the trunk
  • E - Erythema & Edema of palms & soles along with desquamation
  • A - Adenopathy (usually unilateral, cervical)
  • M - Mucositis (Strawberry Tongue)

questions.text: A primary health center in a remote area has received a new shipment of vaccines for an upcoming vaccination drive. The medical officer in charge is reviewing the protocol for administering vaccines safely. Which of the following is not a condition followed under the Open Vial Policy?

choices.text: The expiry date has not passed
An aseptic technique has been used to withdraw all doses
Vaccines are stored strictly under an appropriate temperature (+3° C to +4° C) range during transportation and storage at cold chain point
Vaccine vial monitor has not reached the discard point

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Vaccines are stored strictly under an appropriate temperature (+3° C to +4° C) range during transportation and storage at cold chain point:

  • This statement is inaccurate.
  • Under the Open Vial Policy, vaccines are typically stored at recommended temperatures to maintain their potency and effectiveness.
  • Vaccines are stored strictly under an appropriate temperature (+2 to +8 °C) range during transportation and storage at cold chain point.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A -The expiry date has not passed:

  • Expired vaccines can lose their efficacy or even become harmful, so it is essential to ensure that the expiry date has not passed before administering any vaccine, a condition followed under the Open Vial Policy.

Option B - An aseptic technique has been used to withdraw all doses:

  • Maintaining sterility during the withdrawal of vaccine doses is essential to prevent contamination, a requirement under the Open Vial Policy.

Option D - Vaccine vial monitor has not reached the discard point:

  • Monitoring the Vaccine vial monitor (VVM) is an essential aspect of vaccine management, followed under the Open Vial Policy.

questions.text: The 25-year-old man was one of the victims of the recent hate crime. During the autopsy of the victim, the wound on the forehead was observed to have a patterned abrasion and a stellate laceration. What clue about the range of shots does that give to the examining doctor?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Contact shot:

  • The stellate wound is a characteristic of a contact wound.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Close shot:

  • The body lies within the range of flame, smoke and powder blast, i.e. within 2–3 inches (5–8 cm).
  • The entry wound is small and circular in shape having inverted and contused lacerated margins.

Option C - Range within 60 cm:

  • Tattooing becomes discrete as the range increases, no trace of powder marks will be found when the range is beyond 24 inches, i.e. normally beyond arm’s length.
  • For handguns, powder tattooing extends to a maximum distance of 18–24 inches (45–60 cm).

Option D - Distant shot:

  • Gunshot entry wounds with no associated soot or gunpowder stippling are referred to as ‘distant’ wounds, i.e. range is beyond 2 feet.
  • The entry wound is usually circular in shape, smaller than the bullet, because of the elasticity of the skin, with lacerated, inverted skin margins, a bigger dirt collar and the usual zone of an abraded collar.

questions.text: At which vertebral level does the hemiazygos vein cross from left to right?
questions.solution:
Option B: T8

  • The hemiazygos vein is, also known as the inferior azygos vein, formed in the upper abdomen by the union of:
    • Left ascending lumbar vein
    • Left subcostal vein
  • It runs superiorly, passing through the left crus of the diaphragm to enter the thoracic cavity. It courses upwards in the posterior mediastinum along the left side of the vertebra. It then courses to the right, crossing the aorta, oesophagus and thoracic duct posteriorly, to enter the azygos vein at the level of the T8 vertebra.

Option A: T7

  • T7 corresponds to the inferior angle of the scapula in our body.

Option C: T10

  • At the level of T10, an esophagal opening in the diaphragm is present.

Option D: T12

  • The level of T12 represents the aortic opening in the diaphragm is present.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 16-year-old girl with primary amenorrhea, absent vaginal opening, and normal ovaries with an absent uterus?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option B: MRKH (Mayer Rokitansky Kuster Hauser syndrome

  • The absence of the uterus and vagina but the presence of normal ovaries suggests the diagnosis of Mayer Rokitansky Kuster Hauser syndrome.
  • Mayer Rokitansky Kuster Hauser (MRKH) syndrome is a disorder of the female genital tract characterized by vaginal aplasia and underdeveloped or absence of Mullerian structures (uterus, cervix, fallopian tubes, upper vagina).
  • Patients have normal external female genitalia. The genotype is 46XX.
  • Diagnosis is commonly made when there is delayed puberty and absence of menses till 15 years of age.
  • Reproduction is possible through assisted reproductive techniques with surrogacy.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Androgen insensitivity syndrome

  • Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome (AIS) involves reduced response to male hormones (androgens) in 46,XY individuals.
  • AIS exhibits a spectrum of phenotypes: Complete (CAIS), Partial (PAIS), and Mild (MAIS).
  • Features include feminization of external genitalia, abnormal secondary sexual development, and infertility.

Option C: Turner syndrome

  • Turner syndrome is characterized by 45 XO karyotypes. Features may include short stature, webbed neck, and cardiac abnormalities. However, in Turner syndrome, the ovaries are usually streak gonads, and the uterus is absent or underdeveloped.

Option D: Pure gonadal dysgenesis

  • These patients have a female phenotype, with XX or XY genotype. The individual fails to develop secondary sexual characteristics and presents clinically with primary amenorrhea.

questions.text:
In a physiology class, you are being taught about feedback mechanisms. The professor describes the importance of feedback mechanisms and various types of feedback mechanisms. Which among the following are examples of positive feedback mechanisms?

1. Oxytocin in parturition

2. Action potential of neuron from RMP to the action potential

3. LH surge leading to ovulation

4. Platelet plug/clot formation
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 1,2,3 and 4:

 

  1. Oxytocin release during parturition: Stretching of the cervix and pressure from the baby's head stimulate oxytocin release, enhancing contractions in a positive feedback loop until delivery.

  2. Neuronal action potential: Depolarization of the neuron triggers more sodium channels to open, leading to further depolarization and creating a positive feedback loop, resulting in an action potential.

  3. LH surge and ovulation: Rising estrogen levels prompt the hypothalamus to release GnRH, stimulating the anterior pituitary to release LH. LH further boosts estrogen production, reinforcing the surge and triggering ovulation in a positive feedback loop.

  4. Platelet plug/clot formation: Platelets adhere to exposed collagen at a wound site, releasing chemicals that attract more platelets, leading to further activation and aggregation, ultimately forming a clot to stop bleeding in a positive feedback loop.

 

Incorrect Options: 

  • Option A, B & C are incorrect.

questions.text: In a municipal corporation, there has been a surge in biomedical waste generated due to the recent opening of a hospital in the vicinity. To efficiently manage this waste and prevent environmental pollution, the authorities decide to implement a dual chamber incinerator. Which among the following is the temperature range used in the Dual Chamber Incinerator?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 800-1100°C:

  • The optimal temperature range for the primary combustion chamber of a dual chamber incinerator is 800-1100°C, ensuring thorough destruction of biomedical waste and minimizing environmental and public health risks.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are not applicable as they do not provide the correct temperature range for the dual chamber incinerator.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about bile acid sequestrants (resins) is true in the context of pregnancy?

choices.text: Resins are used for managing Type 1 diabetes mellitus during pregnancy.
Resins are a safe option for reducing blood cholesterol during pregnancy.
Resins are used for managing chronic kidney disease during pregnancy.
Colesevelam is specifically approved for hypercholesterolemia in pregnancy.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Resins are a safe option for reducing blood cholesterol during pregnancy.

Explanation:

  • In pregnancy, hypercholesterolemia is typically managed with lifestyle interventions (e.g., low-cholesterol diet, exercise) due to limited safety data on lipid-lowering drugs.
  • Statins, the standard for hypercholesterolemia, are contraindicated (FDA Category X) due to teratogenic risks (e.g., fetal skeletal abnormalities).
  • Bile acid sequestrants are considered relatively safe in pregnancy (FDA Category B for cholestyramine, Category C for colesevelam) because they are not systemically absorbed, minimizing fetal exposure.
  • They are used in severe cases, such as FH with high cardiovascular risk (e.g., LDL-C >190 mg/dL or vascular disease), when benefits outweigh risks. However, resins are the preferred pharmacologic option when therapy is unavoidable, as per AHA and ACOG guidance.
  • Close monitoring is required for maternal nutrient deficiencies (e.g., fat-soluble vitamins A, D, E, K) and potential fetal risks (e.g., vitamin K deficiency affecting coagulation).

 

Resins are used for managing Type 1 diabetes mellitus during pregnancy (Option A): Resins are lipid-lowering agents used for hypercholesterolemia, not diabetes management, and have no role in controlling blood glucose or insulin requirements.

Resins are used for managing chronic kidney disease during pregnancy (Option C): Resins are not used for CKD management, as they target hypercholesterolemia, not renal function or CKD-specific issues. While CKD patients may have dyslipidemia, lipid management in pregnancy follows the same principles as for hypercholesterolemia, with resins considered only for severe hyperlipidemia, not CKD itself.

Colesevelam is specifically approved for hypercholesterolemia in pregnancy (Option D): Colesevelam, a bile acid sequestrant, is FDA-approved for hypercholesterolemia and glycemic control in type 2 diabetes (non-pregnant adults). No bile acid sequestrant, including colesevelam, has specific FDA approval for hypercholesterolemia in pregnancy due to insufficient safety data.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman, currently in her 28th week of pregnancy, seeks emergency care due to the abrupt onset of intense abdominal pain and fever. Pelvic ultrasound indicates a healthy fetus and identifies a sizable submucosal fibroid characterized by a hyperechoic mass within the uterine wall. Laboratory tests reveal leukocytosis and a raised ESR. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option C: Red degeneration of fibroid

  • This complication of uterine myomas develops most frequently during pregnancy.
  • Red degeneration of a fibroid occurs when the blood supply to the fibroid is compromised, leading to bleeding within the fibroid. This can result in abdominal pain, tenderness, and, occasionally, fever. Given the symptoms described, red degeneration of a fibroid is a plausible diagnosis.
  • Although the patient is febrile with moderate leucocytosis and raised ESR, the condition is an aseptic one

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Preterm labor

  • Preterm labor involves the onset of contractions and cervical changes before 37 weeks of pregnancy. While abdominal pain can be associated with preterm labor, the combination of fever, leukocytosis, and the presence of a sizable submucosal fibroid on ultrasound makes preterm labor less likely.

Option B: Torsion of Fibroid

  • In the case of torsion of fibroid, severe abdominal pain is there, but fever and raised leucocyte count are not seen.
  • Torsion may be seen rarely in subserous pedunculated fibroids.

Option D: Calcareous degeneration

  • Calcareous degeneration involves calcium deposition within a fibroid, leading to a hardened, calcified mass. This is a less common degenerative change and is unlikely to present with sudden-onset abdominal pain, fever, and leukocytosis.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of abdominal discomfort for the past 3 weeks. She reports some dull pain around the epigastric region, especially after she eats. Her previous medical history is notable for one episode of gallstone pancreatitis 5 weeks ago. A physical examination demonstrates an abdominal mass and tenderness in the epigastric region. The X-ray was unremarkable. Which of the following is the next best step in managing this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Conservative management:

  • The patient had an episode of pancreatitis 5 weeks ago and now presents with epigastric pain for the last 3 weeks, and an abdominal mass on the epigastric region points toward the formation of a pseudocyst of the pancreas, which is a complication of post-acute pancreatitis
  • Pseudocyst is a chronic collection of pancreatic amylase-rich fluid surrounded by a non-epithelialized wall of granulation tissue and fibrosis
  • They comprise the most common complication of chronic pancreatitis. They also arise following a mild attack of acute pancreatitis and lie outside but close to the pancreas, especially in the lesser sac but can be found in the pelvis, scrotum, mediastinum, or thorax
  • Formation of a pseudocyst requires 4 weeks or more from the onset of acute pancreatitis. Pseudocysts usually cause symptoms of pain, fullness, or early satiety. The fluid from a pseudocyst typically has a low CEA level, high amylase level, and absence of mucin
  • Most cases are managed conservatively. If the pseudocyst fails to resolve with conservative therapy and symptoms persist, internal drainage is usually preferred to external drainage to avoid the complication of a pancreatico-cutaneous fistula. Internal drainage may be performed with either endoscopic methods ( transgastric or transduodenal puncture and multiple stent placements) or surgical methods
  • Pseudocysts that are thick-walled or large (over 6 cm in diameter), has lasted for a long time (over 12 weeks), or have arisen in the context of chronic pancreatitis are less likely to resolve spontaneously

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Percutaneous drainage: Percutaneous drainage through endoscopy or surgical method would be necessary if the patient does not recover from conservative management, which is the first line of treatment

Option B - Laparotomy: Laparotomy would have been necessary if the pseudocyst had ruptured and there was hemodynamic instability. There are no signs of peritonitis in this patient, which presents with guarding and rebound tenderness and pneumoperitoneum(air under the diaphragm) on x-ray

Option C - Cystogastrostomy: Cystogastrostomy is a surgery to create an opening between a pancreatic pseudocyst and the stomach when the cyst is in a suitable position to be drained into the stomach. This conserves pancreatic juices that would otherwise be lost. But the first line of management is conservative management in the case of pseudocyst

questions.text: Which of the following factors will act on intraglomerular mesangial cells, increasing the glomerular filtration rate?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - PGE2:

  • Prostaglandin E2 (PGE2) acts on intraglomerular mesangial cells resulting in their relaxation. This relaxation causes dilation of the glomerular capillaries, which increases the renal blood flow and, consequently, the glomerular filtration rate (GFR).

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D - (PGF2, Endothelins & Angiotensin II):

  • PGF2, endothelins, and angiotensin II act on intraglomerular mesangial cells, resulting in their contraction. This contraction causes constriction of the glomerular capillaries, decreasing the renal blood flow and the glomerular filtration rate.

questions.text: Identify the given instrument and specify it’s use:

choices.text: Asch forceps, For correction of nasal bone
Walsham forceps, For correction of nasal bone
Asch forceps, For correction of nasal septum
Walsham forceps, For correction of nasal septum

questions.solution:
Correct Option B- Walsham forceps, For correction of nasal bone:

  • The image shows Walsham forceps. Their blades are not elevated. Walsham's forceps have a rubber guard on one of the ends to prevent any orbital trauma, as only one end goes inside the nose. Walsham forceps are used to correct the nasal bone during the management of fracture of the nasal septum.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- Asch forceps, for correction of nasal bone: The tip of the Asch forceps is elevated, not straight. They are used to correct the nasal septum, not the nasal bone.

Option C- Asch forceps, for correction of nasal septum: The tip of the Asch forceps is elevated, not straight. They are used to correct the nasal septum.

Option D- Walsham forceps, for correction of nasal septum: Walsham forceps are primarily used to correct the nasal bone, not the nasal septum.

questions.text: A body is discovered hanging from a ceiling fan. Upon examination, the forensic pathologist notes that the deceased's right eye is open, and the right pupil is dilated. The knot of the noose is found on the right side of the neck. Based on the described scenario, what is the term for the observed finding?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - La Facies Sympathique:

  • La Facies Sympathique refers to the important finding in cases of antemortem hanging where the eye on the same side as the knot remains open, and the pupil is dilated due to the stimulation of the cervical sympathetic chain by the knot.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Tardieu Spots: These are petechial hemorrhages found in the visceral pleura due to an acute rise in venous pressure.

Option C - Amussat's Sign: It refers to a horizontal or transverse tear in the carotid artery.

Option D - Suggilation: This refers to the settling of blood in the dependent parts of the body after death, causing a purplish-red discoloration of the skin.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents with cardiomegaly, hypotonia, and respiratory distress. The parents report that the child has had difficulty feeding and gaining weight, showing signs of failure to thrive. A biopsy reveals glycogen accumulation in cardiac and skeletal muscle cells. Which of the following is the most likely enzyme deficiency?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Acid maltase (alpha-glucosidase) deficiency:

  • Enzyme replacement therapy
  • This describes Pompe disease, a lysosomal storage disorder and glycogen storage disorder. The defect in acid maltase (alpha-glucosidase) leads to glycogen accumulation in lysosomes, primarily affecting cardiac and skeletal muscles.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency:

  • Dietary management
  • This refers to Von Gierke's disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type I), which primarily affects the liver and does not typically present with cardiomegaly or skeletal muscle involvement.

Option C - Hexosaminidase A deficiency:

  • Supportive care
  • This describes Tay-Sachs disease, a different lysosomal storage disorder affecting the central nervous system, presenting with neurological symptoms rather than cardiomegaly and muscle hypotonia.

Option D - Galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase deficiency:

  • Lactose-free diet
  • This describes Classic Galactosemia, a disorder of galactose metabolism, not a glycogen storage or lysosomal storage disorder, and it primarily presents with liver dysfunction and cataracts.

questions.text: Which mutation is not associated with a 32-year-old woman who has a gradually increasing painless neck mass revealing a firm irregular mass in the right thyroid lobe on examination and the following FNAC findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - CASR mutation:

  • The features described, along with the cytological findings, are suggestive of papillary thyroid carcinoma
  • It is associated with Autosomal-Dominant Hypoparathyroidism. A gain of function mutation in the calcium-sensing receptor (CASR) gene is seen in Autosomal-Dominant Hypoparathyroidism. Loss of function mutation of CASR may cause familial parathyroid adenomas.
  •  

    Papillary Carcinoma Thyroid

    Genetic Mutations
    • BRAF V600E mutation: Most common mutation in PTC.
    • RET-PTC fusion: Resulting from a translocation (t(10:17)).
    • NTRK mutation: Associated with PTC.

    Other Risk Factors
    • History of Hashimoto's thyroiditis.
    • Long-standing thyroglossal cyst.
    • History of radiation exposure (may manifest years later).

    Clinical Features
    • Anterior neck nodule.
    • Lymphadenopathy.
    • Lymphatic spread (except for follicular carcinoma).

    Microscopic Characteristics
    • Fingerlike projections (true papilla).
    • True papillae have blood vessels (fibrovascular core).
    • Optically clear nucleus. (Orphan Annie eye nuclei
    • Intranuclear cytoplasmic inclusions (INCI).
    • Nuclear groove or coffee bean nucleus.
    • Presence of psammoma bodies.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - RET/PTC fusion gene, Option B - NTRK1 mutation, and Option D - BRAF mutation:

  • RET/PTC fusion gene and NTRK1 mutation are genetic alterations that can be associated with thyroid cancer, particularly papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC). These mutations can lead to abnormal activation of signaling pathways promoting thyroid cell proliferation.
  • BRAF mutation is commonly found in papillary thyroid carcinoma, especially the V600E mutation. It plays a role in the MAP kinase signaling pathway, contributing to the development and progression of thyroid cancer.
